dhamma@an7.72@1@an7.72:14.4@Yañca kho so, bhikkhave, dussīlo pāpadhammo …pe… kasambujāto khattiyamahāsālānaṁ vā brāhmaṇamahāsālānaṁ vā gahapatimahāsālānaṁ vā saddhādeyyaṁ mañcapīṭhaṁ paribhuñjati. Tañhi tassa, bhikkhave, hoti dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati. 
dhamma@an7.72@3@an7.72:14.4@But when such an unethical man enjoys the use of beds and seats given in faith by well-to-do aristocrats or brahmins or householders, that brings him lasting harm and suffering. When his body breaks up, after death, he’s reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. 
dhamma@an7.72@1@an7.72:15.3@“Etadeva, bhante, varaṁ—yaṁ khattiyamahāsālānaṁ vā brāhmaṇamahāsālānaṁ vā gahapatimahāsālānaṁ vā saddhādeyyaṁ vihāraṁ paribhuñjeyya, dukkhañhetaṁ, bhante, yaṁ balavā puriso uddhampādaṁ adhosiraṁ gahetvā tattāya lohakumbhiyā pakkhipeyya ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya—so tattha pheṇuddehakaṁ paccamāno sakimpi uddhaṁ gaccheyya sakimpi adho gaccheyya sakimpi tiriyaṁ gaccheyyā”ti. 
dhamma@an7.72@3@an7.72:15.3@“Sir, it would be much better to enjoy the use of dwellings given in faith by well-to-do aristocrats or brahmins or householders. For it would be painful to have a strong man grab you, turn you upside down, and shove you in a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing, where you’re seared in boiling scum, and swept up and down and round and round.” 
dhamma@an7.72@1@an7.72:16.3@Tatonidānañhi so, bhikkhave, maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ, na tveva tappaccayā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjeyya. 
dhamma@an7.72@3@an7.72:16.3@Because that might result in death or deadly pain. But when his body breaks up, after death, it would not cause him to be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. 
dhamma@an7.72@1@an7.72:16.4@Yañca kho so, bhikkhave, dussīlo pāpadhammo …pe… kasambujāto khattiyamahāsālānaṁ vā brāhmaṇamahāsālānaṁ vā gahapatimahāsālānaṁ vā saddhādeyyaṁ vihāraṁ paribhuñjati. Tañhi tassa, bhikkhave, hoti dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati. 
dhamma@an7.72@3@an7.72:16.4@But when such an unethical man enjoys the use of dwellings given in faith by well-to-do aristocrats or brahmins or householders, that brings him lasting harm and suffering. When his body breaks up, after death, he’s reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. 
dhamma@an7.74@1@an7.74:1.4@‘appakaṁ, brāhmaṇa, jīvitaṁ manussānaṁ parittaṁ lahukaṁ bahudukkhaṁ bahupāyāsaṁ mantāyaṁ boddhabbaṁ, kattabbaṁ kusalaṁ, caritabbaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, natthi jātassa amaraṇaṁ. 
dhamma@an7.74@3@an7.74:1.4@‘Brahmins, life as a human is short, brief, and fleeting, full of suffering and distress. Be thoughtful and wake up! Do what’s good and lead the spiritual life, for no-one born can escape death. 
dhamma@an7.74@1@an7.74:2.2@evamevaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, ussāvabindūpamaṁ jīvitaṁ manussānaṁ parittaṁ lahukaṁ bahudukkhaṁ bahupāyāsaṁ mantāyaṁ boddhabbaṁ, kattabbaṁ kusalaṁ, caritabbaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, natthi jātassa amaraṇaṁ. 
dhamma@an7.74@3@an7.74:2.2@In the same way, life as a human is like a dewdrop. It’s brief and fleeting, full of suffering and distress. Be thoughtful and wake up! Do what’s good and lead the spiritual life, for no-one born can escape death. 
dhamma@an7.74@1@an7.74:3.2@evamevaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, udakabubbuḷūpamaṁ jīvitaṁ manussānaṁ parittaṁ lahukaṁ bahudukkhaṁ bahupāyāsaṁ mantāyaṁ boddhabbaṁ, kattabbaṁ kusalaṁ, caritabbaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, natthi jātassa amaraṇaṁ. 
dhamma@an7.74@3@an7.74:3.2@In the same way, life as a human is like a bubble. … 
dhamma@an7.74@1@an7.74:8.2@evamevaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, govajjhūpamaṁ jīvitaṁ manussānaṁ parittaṁ lahukaṁ bahudukkhaṁ bahupāyāsaṁ mantāyaṁ boddhabbaṁ, kattabbaṁ kusalaṁ, caritabbaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, natthi jātassa amaraṇan’ti. 
dhamma@an7.74@3@an7.74:8.2@In the same way, life as a human is like a cow being slaughtered. It’s brief and fleeting, full of suffering and distress. Be thoughtful and wake up! Do what’s good and lead the spiritual life, for no-one born can escape death.’ 
dhamma@an7.74@1@an7.74:9.5@‘appakaṁ, brāhmaṇa, jīvitaṁ manussānaṁ parittaṁ lahukaṁ bahudukkhaṁ bahupāyāsaṁ mantāyaṁ boddhabbaṁ, kattabbaṁ kusalaṁ, caritabbaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, natthi jātassa amaraṇan’ti. 
dhamma@an7.74@3@an7.74:9.5@‘Life as a human is short, brief, and fleeting, full of suffering and distress. Be thoughtful and wake up! Do what’s good and lead the spiritual life, for no-one born can escape death.’ 
dhamma@an7.74@1@an7.74:10.2@‘appakaṁ jīvitaṁ manussānaṁ parittaṁ lahukaṁ bahudukkhaṁ bahupāyāsaṁ mantāyaṁ boddhabbaṁ, kattabbaṁ kusalaṁ, caritabbaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, natthi jātassa amaraṇan’ti. 
dhamma@an7.74@3@an7.74:10.2@‘Life as a human is short, brief, and fleeting, full of suffering and distress. Be thoughtful and wake up! Do what’s good and lead the spiritual life, for no-one born can escape death.’ 
dhamma@an7.74@1@an7.74:11.1@Tatrime bhattantarāyā kapimiddhopi bhattaṁ na bhuñjati, dukkhitopi bhattaṁ na bhuñjati, byādhitopi bhattaṁ na bhuñjati, uposathikopi bhattaṁ na bhuñjati, alābhakenapi bhattaṁ na bhuñjati. 
dhamma@an7.74@3@an7.74:11.1@Things that prevent you from eating include anger, pain, sickness, sabbath, or being unable to get food. 
dhamma@an7.96-614@1@an7.96-614:1.3@Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo cakkhusmiṁ dukkhānupassī viharati …pe… 
dhamma@an7.96-614@3@an7.96-614:1.3@First, take a person who meditates observing suffering in the eye. … 
dhamma@an7.96-614@1@an7.96-614:12.7@dukkhānupassī viharati … 
dhamma@an7.96-614@3@an7.96-614:12.7@meditates observing suffering … 
dhamma@an7.96-614@1@an7.96-614:15.2@aniccaṁ dukkhamanattā; 
dhamma@an7.96-614@3@an7.96-614:15.2@
dhamma@an7.617@1@an7.617:1.3@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā—
dhamma@an7.617@3@an7.617:1.3@The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, and not-self in suffering. 
dhamma@an8.5@1@an8.5:1.3@Lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṁsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañca. 
dhamma@an8.5@3@an8.5:1.3@Gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:1.3@Lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṁsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañca. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:1.3@Gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:2.1@Assutavato, bhikkhave, puthujjanassa uppajjati lābhopi alābhopi yasopi ayasopi nindāpi pasaṁsāpi sukhampi dukkhampi. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:2.1@An unlearned ordinary person encounters gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, and pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:2.2@Sutavatopi, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa uppajjati lābhopi alābhopi yasopi ayasopi nindāpi pasaṁsāpi sukhampi dukkhampi. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:2.2@And so does a learned noble disciple. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:3.7@so ca kho anicco dukkho vipariṇāmadhammo’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:3.7@It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They don’t truly understand it. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:3.14@uppajjati dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:3.14@pain. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:3.16@‘uppannaṁ kho me idaṁ dukkhaṁ; 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:3.16@‘I’ve encountered this pain. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:3.17@tañca kho aniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhamman’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:3.17@It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They don’t truly understand it. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:4.1@Tassa lābhopi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, alābhopi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, yasopi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, ayasopi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, nindāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, pasaṁsāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, sukhampi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, dukkhampi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:4.1@So gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, and pleasure and pain occupy their mind. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:4.5@uppannaṁ sukhaṁ anurujjhati, dukkhe paṭivirujjhati. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:4.5@They favor pleasure and oppose pain. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:4.6@So evaṁ anurodhavirodhasamāpanno na parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:4.6@Being so full of favoring and opposing, they’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:4.7@‘Na parimuccati dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:4.7@They’re not freed from suffering, I say. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:5.4@so ca kho anicco dukkho vipariṇāmadhammo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:5.4@It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They truly understand it. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:5.11@uppajjati dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:5.11@pain. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:5.13@‘uppannaṁ kho me idaṁ dukkhaṁ; 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:5.13@‘I’ve encountered this pain. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:5.14@tañca kho aniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhamman’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:5.14@It’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’ They truly understand it. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:6.1@Tassa lābhopi cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, alābhopi cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, yasopi cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, ayasopi cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, nindāpi cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, pasaṁsāpi cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, sukhampi cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, dukkhampi cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:6.1@So gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, and pleasure and pain don’t occupy their mind. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:6.5@uppannaṁ sukhaṁ nānurujjhati, dukkhe nappaṭivirujjhati. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:6.5@They don’t favor pleasure or oppose pain. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:6.6@So evaṁ anurodhavirodhavippahīno parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:6.6@Having given up favoring and opposing, they’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@an8.6@1@an8.6:6.7@‘Parimuccati dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@an8.6@3@an8.6:6.7@They’re freed from suffering, I say. 
dhamma@an8.10@1@an8.10:11.6@dukkhassantaṁ karissathā”ti. 
dhamma@an8.10@3@an8.10:11.6@make an end of suffering.” 
dhamma@an8.11@1@an8.11:13.5@sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāmi. 
dhamma@an8.11@3@an8.11:13.5@With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@an8.11@1@an8.11:14.2@So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarāmi, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarāmi. 
dhamma@an8.11@3@an8.11:14.2@I recollected many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. I remembered: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@an8.11@1@an8.11:18.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ; 
dhamma@an8.11@3@an8.11:18.2@I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

dhamma@an8.30@1@an8.30:7.1@Yato kho tvaṁ, anuruddha, ime aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakke vitakkessasi, tato tvaṁ, anuruddha, yāvadeva ākaṅkhissasi, sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharissasi. 
dhamma@an8.30@3@an8.30:7.1@Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, you’ll enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@an8.30@1@an8.30:20.3@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@an8.30@3@an8.30:20.3@It’s for a mendicant who’s wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

dhamma@an8.51@1@an8.51:4.1@Atha kho mahāpajāpatī gotamī “na bhagavā anujānāti mātugāmassa tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajjan”ti dukkhī dummanā assumukhī rudamānā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi. 
dhamma@an8.51@3@an8.51:4.1@Then Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī thought, “The Buddha does not permit females to go forth.” Miserable and sad, weeping, with a tearful face, she bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on her right, before leaving. 
dhamma@an8.51@1@an8.51:5.6@Atha kho mahāpajāpatī gotamī sūnehi pādehi rajokiṇṇena gattena dukkhī dummanā assumukhī rudamānā bahidvārakoṭṭhake aṭṭhāsi. 
dhamma@an8.51@3@an8.51:5.6@Then Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī stood crying outside the gate, her feet swollen, her limbs covered with dust, miserable and sad, with tearful face. 
dhamma@an8.51@1@an8.51:6.1@Addasā kho āyasmā ānando mahāpajāpatiṁ gotamiṁ sūnehi pādehi rajokiṇṇena gattena dukkhiṁ dummanaṁ assumukhiṁ rudamānaṁ bahidvārakoṭṭhake ṭhitaṁ. 
dhamma@an8.51@3@an8.51:6.1@Venerable Ānanda saw her standing there, 
dhamma@an8.51@1@an8.51:6.3@“kiṁ nu tvaṁ, gotami, sūnehi pādehi rajokiṇṇena gattena dukkhī dummanā assumukhī rudamānā bahidvārakoṭṭhake ṭhitā”ti? 
dhamma@an8.51@3@an8.51:6.3@“Gotamī, why do you stand crying outside the gate, your feet swollen, your limbs covered with dust, miserable and sad, with tearful face?” 
dhamma@an8.51@1@an8.51:7.2@“esā, bhante, mahāpajāpatī gotamī sūnehi pādehi rajokiṇṇena gattena dukkhī dummanā assumukhī rudamānā bahidvārakoṭṭhake ṭhitā: 
dhamma@an8.51@3@an8.51:7.2@“Sir, Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī is standing crying outside the gate, her feet swollen, her limbs covered with dust, miserable and sad, with tearful face.

dhamma@an8.76@1@an8.76:8.2@Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto paññavā hoti …pe… sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.

dhamma@an9.1@1@an9.1:9.1@Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@an9.1@3@an9.1:9.1@Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@an9.1@1@an9.1:13.2@paññavā bhavissati udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@an9.1@3@an9.1:13.2@be wise … 
dhamma@an9.3@1@an9.3:14.1@Puna caparaṁ, meghiya, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@an9.3@3@an9.3:14.1@Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@an9.3@1@an9.3:18.1@Kalyāṇamittassetaṁ, meghiya, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṁ kalyāṇasahāyassa kalyāṇasampavaṅkassa: ‘paññavā bhavissati …pe… sammādukkhakkhayagāminiyā’. 
dhamma@an9.3@3@an9.3:18.1@A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to be wise … 
dhamma@an9.12@1@an9.12:7.2@So tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karoti. 
dhamma@an9.12@3@an9.12:7.2@With the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, they’re a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@an9.12@1@an9.12:8.2@So tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā ekabījī hoti, ekaṁyeva mānusakaṁ bhavaṁ nibbattetvā dukkhassantaṁ karoti. 
dhamma@an9.12@3@an9.12:8.2@With the ending of three fetters, they’re a one-seeder. They will be reborn just one time in a human existence, then make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@an9.12@1@an9.12:9.2@So tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā kolaṅkolo hoti, dve vā tīṇi vā kulāni sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karoti. 
dhamma@an9.12@3@an9.12:9.2@With the ending of three fetters, they go from family to family. They will transmigrate between two or three families and then make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@an9.12@1@an9.12:10.2@So tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sattakkhattuparamo hoti, sattakkhattuparamaṁ deve ca manusse ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karoti. 
dhamma@an9.12@3@an9.12:10.2@With the ending of three fetters, they have at most seven rebirths. They will transmigrate at most seven times among gods and humans and then make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@an9.13@1@an9.13:3.1@“Kiṁ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, ‘yaṁ kammaṁ sukhavedanīyaṁ, taṁ me kammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ vussatī”ti? 
dhamma@an9.13@3@an9.13:3.1@“Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds to be experienced as pleasant be experienced by me as painful’?”

dhamma@an9.13@1@an9.13:4.1@“Kiṁ panāvuso, sāriputta, ‘yaṁ kammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ, taṁ me kammaṁ sukhavedanīyaṁ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ vussatī”ti?

dhamma@an9.16@1@an9.16:1.3@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā—
dhamma@an9.16@3@an9.16:1.3@The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, and fading away. 
dhamma@an9.22@1@an9.22:4.2@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@an9.22@3@an9.22:4.2@It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@an9.22@1@an9.22:5.2@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.

dhamma@an9.22@3@an9.22:6.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@an9.27@1@an9.27:3.2@Yaṁ, gahapati, pāṇātipātī pāṇātipātapaccayā diṭṭhadhammikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, samparāyikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti, pāṇātipātā paṭivirato neva diṭṭhadhammikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, na samparāyikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, na cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@an9.27@3@an9.27:3.2@Anyone who kills living creatures creates dangers and threats both in the present life and in lives to come, and experiences mental pain and sadness. Anyone who refrains from killing living creatures creates no dangers and threats either in the present life or in lives to come, and doesn’t experience mental pain and sadness. 
dhamma@an9.27@1@an9.27:4.4@surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhāyī surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānapaccayā diṭṭhadhammikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, samparāyikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato neva diṭṭhadhammikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, na samparāyikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, na cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@an9.27@3@an9.27:4.4@Anyone who uses alcoholic drinks that cause negligence creates dangers and threats both in the present life and in lives to come, and experiences mental pain and sadness. Anyone who refrains from using alcoholic drinks that cause negligence creates no dangers and threats either in the present life or in lives to come, and doesn’t experience mental pain and sadness. 
dhamma@an9.28@1@an9.28:2.2@Yaṁ, bhikkhave, pāṇātipātī pāṇātipātapaccayā diṭṭhadhammikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, samparāyikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati, cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti, pāṇātipātā paṭivirato …pe… 
dhamma@an9.28@3@an9.28:2.2@Anyone who kills living creatures creates dangers and threats both in the present life and in lives to come, and experiences mental pain and sadness. Anyone who refrains from killing living creatures creates no dangers and threats either in the present life or in lives to come, and doesn’t experience mental pain and sadness.

dhamma@an9.28@3@an9.28:3.2@Anyone who uses alcoholic drinks that cause negligence creates dangers and threats both in the present life and in lives to come, and experiences mental pain and sadness. Anyone who refrains from using alcoholic drinks that cause negligence creates no dangers and threats either in the present life or in lives to come, and doesn’t experience mental pain and sadness.

dhamma@an9.34@1@an9.34:8.5@Yo kho panāvuso, ābādho dukkhametaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā. 
dhamma@an9.34@3@an9.34:8.5@And affliction has been called suffering by the Buddha. 
dhamma@an9.34@1@an9.34:9.3@Seyyathāpi, āvuso, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya; 
dhamma@an9.34@3@an9.34:9.3@Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them. 
dhamma@an9.34@1@an9.34:9.5@Yo kho panāvuso, ābādho dukkhametaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā. 
dhamma@an9.34@3@an9.34:9.5@And affliction has been called suffering by the Buddha. 
dhamma@an9.35@1@an9.35:6.2@‘yannūnāhaṁ sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti. 
dhamma@an9.35@3@an9.35:6.2@‘Why don’t I, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.’ 
dhamma@an9.36@1@an9.36:2.4@So yadeva tattha hoti rūpagataṁ vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ, te dhamme aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassati. 
dhamma@an9.36@3@an9.36:2.4@They contemplate the phenomena there—included in form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self. 
dhamma@an9.36@1@an9.36:3.3@So yadeva tattha hoti rūpagataṁ vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ, te dhamme aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassati. 
dhamma@an9.36@3@an9.36:3.3@They contemplate the phenomena there—included in form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self. 
dhamma@an9.36@1@an9.36:4.5@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.

dhamma@an9.36@1@an9.36:8.5@So yadeva tattha hoti vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ, te dhamme aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassati. 
dhamma@an9.36@3@an9.36:8.5@They contemplate the phenomena there—included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self. 
dhamma@an9.36@1@an9.36:9.3@So yadeva tattha hoti vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ, te dhamme aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassati. 
dhamma@an9.36@3@an9.36:9.3@They contemplate the phenomena there—included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self. 
dhamma@an9.37@1@an9.37:2.2@Yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sambādhe okāsādhigamo anubuddho sattānaṁ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya. 
dhamma@an9.37@3@an9.37:2.2@How this Blessed One who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, has found an opportunity amid confinement. It’s in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment. 
dhamma@an9.38@1@an9.38:4.14@Na cāhaṁ, brāhmaṇā, appatvāva lokassa antaṁ dukkhassa antakiriyaṁ vadāmi. 
dhamma@an9.38@3@an9.38:4.14@But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world. 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:7.17@Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya; 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:7.17@Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them. 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:8.15@Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya; 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:8.15@Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them. 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:9.15@Seyyathāpi, ānanda, sukhino dukkhaṁ uppajjeyya yāvadeva ābādhāya; 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:9.15@Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them. 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:10.2@‘yannūnāhaṁ sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti. 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:10.2@‘Why don’t I, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness?’ 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:10.3@Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, adukkhamasukhe cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato. 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:10.3@But my mind wasn’t secure in being without pleasure and pain; it wasn’t confident, settled, and decided about it. I didn’t see it as peaceful. 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:10.5@‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo, yena me adukkhamasukhe cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’? 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:10.5@‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind isn’t secure in being without pleasure and pain, and not confident, settled, and decided about it? Why don’t I see it as peaceful?’ 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:10.7@‘upekkhāsukhe kho me ādīnavo adiṭṭho, so ca me abahulīkato, adukkhamasukhe ca ānisaṁso anadhigato, so ca me anāsevito. 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:10.7@‘I haven’t seen the drawbacks of bliss with equanimity, and so I haven’t cultivated that. I haven’t realized the benefits of being without pleasure and pain, and so I haven’t developed that. 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:10.8@Tasmā me adukkhamasukhe cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato’. 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:10.8@That’s why my mind isn’t secure in being without pleasure and pain, and not confident, settled, and decided about it. And it’s why I don’t see it as peaceful.’ 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:10.10@‘sace kho ahaṁ upekkhāsukhe ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulaṁ kareyyaṁ, adukkhamasukhe ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseveyyaṁ, ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati yaṁ me adukkhamasukhe cittaṁ pakkhandeyya pasīdeyya santiṭṭheyya vimucceyya etaṁ santanti passato’. 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:10.10@‘Suppose that, seeing the drawbacks of bliss with equanimity, I were to cultivate that. And suppose that, realizing the benefits of being without pleasure and pain, I were to develop that. It’s possible that my mind would be secure in being without pleasure and pain; it would be confident, settled, and decided about it. And I would see it as peaceful.’ 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:10.11@So kho ahaṁ, ānanda, aparena samayena upekkhāsukhe ādīnavaṁ disvā taṁ bahulamakāsiṁ adukkhamasukhe ānisaṁsaṁ adhigamma tamāseviṁ. 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:10.11@And so, after some time, I saw the drawbacks of bliss with equanimity and cultivated that, and I realized the benefits of being without pleasure and pain and developed that. 
dhamma@an9.41@1@an9.41:10.12@Tassa mayhaṁ, ānanda, adukkhamasukhe cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati etaṁ santanti passato. 
dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:10.12@Then my mind was secure in being without pleasure and pain; it was confident, settled, and decided about it. I saw it as peaceful.

dhamma@an9.41@3@an9.41:12.15@Suppose a happy person were to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.

dhamma@an9.93@1@an9.93:1.3@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā—
dhamma@an9.93@3@an9.93:1.3@The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, and fading away. 
dhamma@an10.11@1@an10.11:2.7@paññavā hoti, udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@an10.11@3@an10.11:2.7@They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@an10.17@1@an10.17:1.2@Dukkhaṁ, bhikkhave, anātho viharati. 
dhamma@an10.17@3@an10.17:1.2@Living without a protector is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.17@1@an10.17:10.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@an10.17@3@an10.17:10.1@Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@an10.17@1@an10.17:10.2@Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā, 
dhamma@an10.17@3@an10.17:10.2@
dhamma@an10.17@1@an10.17:11.2@Dukkhaṁ, bhikkhave, anātho viharati. 
dhamma@an10.17@3@an10.17:11.2@Living without a protector is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.18@1@an10.18:2.2@Dukkhaṁ, bhikkhave, anātho viharati. 
dhamma@an10.18@3@an10.18:2.2@Living without a protector is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.18@1@an10.18:11.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@an10.18@3@an10.18:11.1@Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@an10.18@1@an10.18:11.2@‘Paññavā vatāyaṁ bhikkhu udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā’ti therāpi naṁ bhikkhū vattabbaṁ anusāsitabbaṁ maññanti, majjhimāpi bhikkhū … navāpi bhikkhū vattabbaṁ anusāsitabbaṁ maññanti. 
dhamma@an10.18@3@an10.18:11.2@Knowing this, the mendicants—whether senior, middle, or junior—think that mendicant is worth advising and instructing. 
dhamma@an10.18@1@an10.18:12.2@Dukkhaṁ, bhikkhave, anātho viharati. 
dhamma@an10.18@3@an10.18:12.2@Living without a protector is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.20@1@an10.20:10.2@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@an10.20@3@an10.20:10.2@It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@an10.21@1@an10.21:10.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, tathāgato anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe, ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti, iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@an10.21@3@an10.21:10.1@Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ Thus he recollects his many past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:10.3@Ekadhamme, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:10.3@Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding one thing, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:10.6@imasmiṁ kho, bhikkhave, ekadhamme bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:10.6@Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding this one thing, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:11.3@Dvīsu, bhikkhave, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:11.3@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:11.6@imesu kho, bhikkhave, dvīsu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:11.6@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:12.3@Tīsu, bhikkhave, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:12.3@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:12.6@imesu kho, bhikkhave, tīsu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:12.6@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:13.3@Catūsu, bhikkhave, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:13.3@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:13.6@imesu kho, bhikkhave, catūsu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:13.6@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:14.3@Pañcasu, bhikkhave, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:14.3@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:14.6@imesu kho, bhikkhave, pañcasu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:14.6@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:15.3@Chasu, bhikkhave, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:15.3@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:15.6@imesu kho, bhikkhave, chasu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:15.6@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:16.3@Sattasu, bhikkhave, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:16.3@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:16.6@imesu kho, bhikkhave, sattasu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:16.6@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:17.3@Aṭṭhasu, bhikkhave, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:17.3@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:17.6@imesu kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhasu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:17.6@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:18.3@Navasu, bhikkhave, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:18.3@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:18.6@imesu kho, bhikkhave, navasu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:18.6@
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:19.3@Dasasu, bhikkhave, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:19.3@Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding ten things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.27@1@an10.27:19.6@imesu kho, bhikkhave, dasasu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.27@3@an10.27:19.6@Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these ten things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:4.3@Ekadhamme, āvuso, bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:4.3@Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding one thing, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:4.6@imasmiṁ kho, āvuso, ekadhamme bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:4.6@Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding this one thing, seeing its limits and fully comprehending its meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:5.3@Dvīsu, āvuso, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:5.3@
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:5.8@imesu kho, āvuso, tīsu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:5.8@
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:6.3@Catūsu, āvuso, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā subhāvitacitto sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:6.3@With a mind well developed in four things—seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:6.6@imesu kho, āvuso, catūsu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā subhāvitacitto sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:6.6@With a mind well developed in these four things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. … 
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:7.3@Pañcasu, āvuso, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā subhāvitacitto sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:7.3@
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:7.12@imesu kho, āvuso, aṭṭhasu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā subhāvitacitto sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:7.12@
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:8.3@Navasu, āvuso, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:8.3@Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding nine things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:8.6@imesu kho, āvuso, navasu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:8.6@Becoming completely disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding these nine things, seeing their limits and fully comprehending their meaning, a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:9.3@Dasasu, āvuso, dhammesu bhikkhu sammā subhāvitacitto sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:9.3@Becoming well developed in ten things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.28@1@an10.28:9.6@imesu kho, āvuso, dasasu dhammesu bhikkhu sammā subhāvitacitto sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṁ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@an10.28@3@an10.28:9.6@With a mind well developed in these ten things—seeing their limits and fully fathoming their meaning—a mendicant makes an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@an10.29@1@an10.29:15.3@Dukkhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā, 
dhamma@an10.29@3@an10.29:15.3@Painful practice with slow insight, 
dhamma@an10.29@1@an10.29:15.4@dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā, 
dhamma@an10.29@3@an10.29:15.4@painful practice with swift insight, 
dhamma@an10.30@1@an10.30:11.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhante, bhagavā anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@an10.30@3@an10.30:11.1@Furthermore, the Buddha recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so he recollects his many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@an10.50@1@an10.50:13.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paññavā hoti, udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@an10.50@3@an10.50:13.1@Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@an10.50@1@an10.50:13.2@Yampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paññavā hoti, udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā, 
dhamma@an10.50@3@an10.50:13.2@When a mendicant is wise, 
dhamma@an10.56@1@an10.56:1.3@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā—
dhamma@an10.56@3@an10.56:1.3@The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, and not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation. 
dhamma@an10.60@1@an10.60:1.2@Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā girimānando ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. 
dhamma@an10.60@3@an10.60:1.2@Now at that time Venerable Girimānanda was sick, suffering, gravely ill. 
dhamma@an10.60@1@an10.60:2.1@“Āyasmā, bhante, girimānando ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. 
dhamma@an10.60@3@an10.60:2.1@“Sir, Venerable Girimānanda is sick, suffering, gravely ill. 
dhamma@an10.60@1@an10.60:7.3@‘bahudukkho kho ayaṁ kāyo bahuādīnavo. Iti imasmiṁ kāye vividhā ābādhā uppajjanti, seyyathidaṁ—
dhamma@an10.60@3@an10.60:7.3@‘This body has much suffering and many drawbacks. For this body is beset with many kinds of affliction, such as the following. 
dhamma@an10.65@1@an10.65:2.1@“Kiṁ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, sukhaṁ, kiṁ dukkhan”ti? 
dhamma@an10.65@3@an10.65:2.1@“Reverend Sāriputta, what is happiness and what is suffering?” 
dhamma@an10.65@1@an10.65:2.2@“Abhinibbatti kho, āvuso, dukkhā, anabhinibbatti sukhā. 
dhamma@an10.65@3@an10.65:2.2@“Rebirth is suffering, reverend, no rebirth is happiness. 
dhamma@an10.65@1@an10.65:2.3@Abhinibbattiyā, āvuso, sati idaṁ dukkhaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ—
dhamma@an10.65@3@an10.65:2.3@When there is rebirth, you can expect this kind of suffering. 
dhamma@an10.65@1@an10.65:2.5@Abhinibbattiyā, āvuso, sati idaṁ dukkhaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ. 
dhamma@an10.65@3@an10.65:2.5@When there is rebirth, this is the kind of suffering you can expect. 
dhamma@an10.66@1@an10.66:2.1@“Kiṁ nu kho, āvuso, sāriputta, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye sukhaṁ, kiṁ dukkhan”ti? 
dhamma@an10.66@3@an10.66:2.1@“Reverend Sāriputta, in this teaching and training, what is happiness and what is suffering?” 
dhamma@an10.66@1@an10.66:2.2@“Anabhirati kho, āvuso, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye dukkhā, abhirati sukhā. 
dhamma@an10.66@3@an10.66:2.2@“Reverend, in this teaching and training dissatisfaction is suffering and satisfaction is happiness. 
dhamma@an10.66@1@an10.66:2.3@Anabhiratiyā, āvuso, sati idaṁ dukkhaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ—
dhamma@an10.66@3@an10.66:2.3@When you’re dissatisfied, you can expect this kind of suffering. 
dhamma@an10.66@1@an10.66:2.14@Anabhiratiyā, āvuso, sati idaṁ dukkhaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ. 
dhamma@an10.66@3@an10.66:2.14@When you’re dissatisfied, this is the kind of suffering you can expect. 
dhamma@an10.71@1@an10.71:8.1@Ākaṅkheyya ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘khamo assaṁ sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ, duruttānaṁ durāgatānaṁ vacanapathānaṁ uppannānaṁ sārīrikānaṁ vedanānaṁ dukkhānaṁ tibbānaṁ kharānaṁ kaṭukānaṁ asātānaṁ amanāpānaṁ pāṇaharānaṁ adhivāsakajātiko assan’ti, sīlesvevassa …pe… brūhetā suññāgārānaṁ. 
dhamma@an10.71@3@an10.71:8.1@A mendicant might wish: ‘May I endure cold, heat, hunger, and thirst. May I endure the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles. May I endure rude and unwelcome criticism. And may I put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.’ So let them fulfill their precepts … 
dhamma@an10.75@1@an10.75:11.3@Tañhi tesaṁ, ānanda, hoti dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya. 
dhamma@an10.75@3@an10.75:11.3@This will be for their lasting harm and suffering. 
dhamma@an10.75@1@an10.75:24.3@Tañhi tesaṁ, ānanda, hoti dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya. 
dhamma@an10.75@3@an10.75:24.3@This will be for their lasting harm and suffering. 
dhamma@an10.81@1@an10.81:2.11@dukkhehi kho, vāhana … 
dhamma@an10.81@3@an10.81:2.11@suffering … 
dhamma@an10.92@1@an10.92:3.2@Yaṁ, gahapati, pāṇātipātī pāṇātipātapaccayā diṭṭhadhammikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati samparāyikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti, pāṇātipātā paṭivirato neva diṭṭhadhammikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati na samparāyikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati na cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@an10.92@3@an10.92:3.2@Anyone who kills living creatures creates dangers and threats both in the present life and in lives to come, and experiences mental pain and sadness. Anyone who refrains from killing living creatures creates no dangers and threats either in the present life or in lives to come, and doesn’t experience mental pain and sadness. 
dhamma@an10.92@1@an10.92:4.4@surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhāyī surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānapaccayā diṭṭhadhammikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati samparāyikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato neva diṭṭhadhammikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati na samparāyikampi bhayaṁ veraṁ pasavati na cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@an10.92@3@an10.92:4.4@Anyone who uses alcoholic drinks that cause negligence creates dangers and threats both in the present life and in lives to come, and experiences mental pain and sadness. Anyone who refrains from using alcoholic drinks that cause negligence creates no dangers and threats either in the present life or in lives to come, and doesn’t experience mental pain and sadness. 
dhamma@an10.92@1@an10.92:6.15@jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti, 
dhamma@an10.92@3@an10.92:6.15@Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. 
dhamma@an10.92@1@an10.92:6.16@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti; 
dhamma@an10.92@3@an10.92:6.16@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@an10.92@1@an10.92:6.18@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī’ti. 
dhamma@an10.92@3@an10.92:6.18@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’ 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:9.8@Yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:9.8@And what’s impermanent is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:9.9@Yaṁ dukkhaṁ tadeveso āyasmā allīno, tadeveso āyasmā ajjhupagato. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:9.9@What he clings to and holds to is just suffering. 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:10.7@Yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:10.7@And what’s impermanent is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:10.8@Yaṁ dukkhaṁ tadeveso āyasmā allīno, tadeveso āyasmā ajjhupagato. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:10.8@What he clings to and holds to is just suffering. 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:11.14@Yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:11.14@And what’s impermanent is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:11.15@Yaṁ dukkhaṁ tadeveso āyasmā allīno, tadeveso āyasmā ajjhupagato”ti. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:11.15@What he clings to and holds to is just suffering.” 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:12.5@Yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:12.5@And what’s impermanent is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:12.6@‘Yaṁ dukkhaṁ taṁ netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:12.6@And what’s suffering is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self. 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:13.2@Yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:13.2@And what’s impermanent is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:13.3@Yaṁ dukkhaṁ tadeva tvaṁ, gahapati, allīno, tadeva tvaṁ, gahapati, ajjhupagato”ti. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:13.3@What you cling to and hold to is just suffering.” 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:14.2@Yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:14.2@And what’s impermanent is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.93@1@an10.93:14.3@‘Yaṁ dukkhaṁ taṁ netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, nameso attā’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ. 
dhamma@an10.93@3@an10.93:14.3@And I’ve truly seen clearly with right wisdom that what’s suffering is not mine, I am not this, it’s not my self. 
dhamma@an10.95@1@an10.95:7.1@“Abhiññāya kho ahaṁ, uttiya, sāvakānaṁ dhammaṁ desemi sattānaṁ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti. 
dhamma@an10.95@3@an10.95:7.1@“Uttiya, I teach my disciples from my own insight in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to end the cycle of suffering, and to realize extinguishment.” 
dhamma@an10.95@1@an10.95:8.1@“Yaṁ panetaṁ bhavaṁ gotamo abhiññāya sāvakānaṁ dhammaṁ desesi sattānaṁ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, sabbo vā tena loko nīyati upaḍḍho vā tibhāgo vā”ti? 
dhamma@an10.95@3@an10.95:8.1@“But when Master Gotama teaches in this way, is the whole world saved, or half, or a third?” 
dhamma@an10.95@1@an10.95:9.4@Tadassa uttiyassa paribbājakassa dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti. 
dhamma@an10.95@3@an10.95:9.4@That would be for his lasting harm and suffering.” 
dhamma@an10.97@1@an10.97:9.1@Anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhapaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhapaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti, iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@an10.97@3@an10.97:9.1@They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ Thus they recollect their many past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@an10.104@1@an10.104:1.2@yañca kāyakammaṁ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṁ samādinnaṁ yañca vacīkammaṁ yañca manokammaṁ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṁ samādinnaṁ yā ca cetanā yā ca patthanā yo ca paṇidhi ye ca saṅkhārā, sabbe te dhammā aniṭṭhāya akantāya amanāpāya ahitāya dukkhāya saṁvattanti. 
dhamma@an10.104@3@an10.104:1.2@Whatever bodily, verbal, or mental deeds they undertake in line with that view, their intentions, aims, wishes, and choices all lead to what is unlikable, undesirable, disagreeable, harmful, and suffering. 
dhamma@an10.104@1@an10.104:2.5@yañca manokammaṁ yathādiṭṭhi samattaṁ samādinnaṁ yā ca cetanā yā ca patthanā yo ca paṇidhi ye ca saṅkhārā, sabbe te dhammā aniṭṭhāya akantāya amanāpāya ahitāya dukkhāya saṁvattanti. 
dhamma@an10.104@3@an10.104:2.5@Whatever bodily, verbal, or mental deeds they undertake in line with that view, their intentions, aims, wishes, and choices all lead to what is unlikable, undesirable, disagreeable, harmful, and suffering. 
dhamma@an10.107@1@an10.107:2.1@Ahañca kho, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ dhovanaṁ desessāmi, yaṁ dhovanaṁ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati, yaṁ dhovanaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti, jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti, maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti. 
dhamma@an10.107@3@an10.107:2.1@I will teach a noble washing that leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. Relying on that washing, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things. 
dhamma@an10.107@1@an10.107:3.1@“Katamañca taṁ, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ dhovanaṁ, yaṁ dhovanaṁ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati, yaṁ dhovanaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti, jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti, maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti? 
dhamma@an10.107@3@an10.107:3.1@“And what is that noble washing? 
dhamma@an10.107@1@an10.107:6.4@Idaṁ kho taṁ, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ dhovanaṁ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati, yaṁ dhovanaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti, jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti, maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccantī”ti. 
dhamma@an10.107@3@an10.107:6.4@This is the noble washing that leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. Relying on this washing, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things.”
dhamma@an10.108@1@an10.108:2.1@Ahañca kho, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ virecanaṁ desessāmi, yaṁ virecanaṁ sampajjatiyeva no vipajjati, yaṁ virecanaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti, jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti, maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti. 
dhamma@an10.108@3@an10.108:2.1@I will teach a noble purgative that works without fail. Relying on that purgative, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things. 
dhamma@an10.108@1@an10.108:3.1@“Katamañca taṁ, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ virecanaṁ, yaṁ virecanaṁ sampajjatiyeva no vipajjati, yaṁ virecanaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti, jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti, maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti? 
dhamma@an10.108@3@an10.108:3.1@“And what is the noble purgative that works without fail? 
dhamma@an10.108@1@an10.108:6.4@Idaṁ kho taṁ, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ virecanaṁ yaṁ virecanaṁ sampajjatiyeva no vipajjati, yaṁ virecanaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti …pe… sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccantī”ti. 
dhamma@an10.108@3@an10.108:6.4@This is the noble purgative that works without fail. Relying on this purgative, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things.”
dhamma@an10.109@1@an10.109:2.1@Ahañca kho, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ vamanaṁ desessāmi, yaṁ vamanaṁ sampajjatiyeva no vipajjati, yaṁ vamanaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti, jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti, maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti. 
dhamma@an10.109@3@an10.109:2.1@I will teach a noble emetic that works without fail. Relying on that emetic, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things. 
dhamma@an10.109@1@an10.109:3.1@Katamañca taṁ, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ vamanaṁ, yaṁ vamanaṁ sampajjatiyeva no vipajjati, yaṁ vamanaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti …pe… sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti? 
dhamma@an10.109@3@an10.109:3.1@And what is that noble emetic that works without fail? 
dhamma@an10.109@1@an10.109:6.4@Idaṁ kho taṁ, bhikkhave, ariyaṁ vamanaṁ yaṁ vamanaṁ sampajjatiyeva no vipajjati, yaṁ vamanaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti …pe… sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccantī”ti. 
dhamma@an10.109@3@an10.109:6.4@This is the noble emetic that works without fail. Relying on this emetic, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things.”
dhamma@an10.143@1@an10.143:0.3@Dukkhudrayasutta 
dhamma@an10.143@3@an10.143:0.3@With Suffering as Outcome 
dhamma@an10.143@1@an10.143:1.1@“Dukkhudrayañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṁ desessāmi sukhudrayañca. 
dhamma@an10.143@3@an10.143:1.1@“I will teach you the principle that has suffering as outcome, and that which has happiness as outcome. … 
dhamma@an10.143@1@an10.143:1.3@katamo ca, bhikkhave, dukkhudrayo dhammo? 
dhamma@an10.143@3@an10.143:1.3@And what is the principle whose outcome is suffering? 
dhamma@an10.143@1@an10.143:1.5@ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhudrayo dhammo. 
dhamma@an10.143@3@an10.143:1.5@This is the principle whose outcome is suffering. 
dhamma@an10.144@1@an10.144:0.3@Dukkhavipākasutta 
dhamma@an10.144@3@an10.144:0.3@Result in Suffering 
dhamma@an10.144@1@an10.144:1.1@“Dukkhavipākañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṁ desessāmi sukhavipākañca. 
dhamma@an10.144@3@an10.144:1.1@“I will teach you the principle that results in suffering and that which results in happiness. … 
dhamma@an10.144@1@an10.144:1.3@katamo ca, bhikkhave, dukkhavipāko dhammo? 
dhamma@an10.144@3@an10.144:1.3@And what principle results in suffering? 
dhamma@an10.144@1@an10.144:1.5@ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhavipāko dhammo. 
dhamma@an10.144@3@an10.144:1.5@This is called the principle that results in suffering.

dhamma@an10.216@1@an10.216:4.2@ye vā ekantadukkhā nirayā yā vā saṁsappajātikā tiracchānayoni. 
dhamma@an10.216@3@an10.216:4.2@in an exclusively painful hell, or among the species of creepy animals.

dhamma@an10.216@3@an10.216:6.2@in an exclusively painful hell, or among the species of creepy animals. 
dhamma@an10.217@1@an10.217:1.3@Na tvevāhaṁ, bhikkhave, sañcetanikānaṁ kammānaṁ katānaṁ upacitānaṁ appaṭisaṁveditvā dukkhassantakiriyaṁ vadāmi. 
dhamma@an10.217@3@an10.217:1.3@And I don’t say that suffering is ended without experiencing intentional deeds that have been performed and accumulated. 
dhamma@an10.217@1@an10.217:2.1@Tatra, bhikkhave, tividhā kāyakammantasandosabyāpatti akusalasañcetanikā dukkhudrayā dukkhavipākā hoti; 
dhamma@an10.217@3@an10.217:2.1@Now, there are three kinds of corruption and failure of bodily action that have unskillful intention, with suffering as their outcome and result. 
dhamma@an10.217@4@an10.217:2.1@akusalasañcetanikā dukkhudrayā dukkhavipākā → akusalaṁ sañcetanikaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākaṁ (mr)

dhamma@an10.217@3@an10.217:2.2@There are four kinds of corruption and failure of verbal action that have unskillful intention, with suffering as their outcome and result. 
dhamma@an10.217@1@an10.217:2.3@tividhā manokammantasandosabyāpatti akusalasañcetanikā dukkhudrayā dukkhavipākā hoti. 
dhamma@an10.217@3@an10.217:2.3@There are three kinds of corruption and failure of mental action that have unskillful intention, with suffering as their outcome and result.

dhamma@an10.217@3@an10.217:3.1@And what are the three kinds of corruption and failure of bodily action?

dhamma@an10.219@1@an10.219:5.1@“Akarontaṁ kho pana pāpakammaṁ api nu kho dukkhaṁ phuseyyā”ti? 
dhamma@an10.219@3@an10.219:5.1@“Not doing any bad deed, would they still experience any suffering?” 
dhamma@an10.219@1@an10.219:5.3@Akarontañhi, bhante, pāpakammaṁ kuto dukkhaṁ phusissatī”ti. 
dhamma@an10.219@3@an10.219:5.3@For if they don’t do any bad deed, from where would suffering afflict them?”

dhamma@an10.219@3@an10.219:10.3@For if they don’t do any bad deed, from where would suffering afflict them?” 
dhamma@an10.237@1@an10.237:1.3@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā—
dhamma@an10.237@3@an10.237:1.3@The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, and not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation. 
dhamma@an11.14@1@an11.14:12.2@seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattārīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@an11.14@3@an11.14:12.2@That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

dhamma@dn1@1@dn1:1.31.2@Seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekānipi jātisatāni anekānipi jātisahassāni anekānipi jātisatasahassāni: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.

They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

dhamma@dn1@1@dn1:1.32.3@Seyyathidaṁ—ekampi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭaṁ dvepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tīṇipi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattāripi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni pañcapi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni dasapi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@dn1@3@dn1:1.32.3@That is: one eon of the cosmos contracting and expanding; two, three, four, five, or ten eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

dhamma@dn1@1@dn1:2.38.16@‘Ekantadukkhī attā hoti …. 
dhamma@dn1@3@dn1:2.38.16@experiences nothing but suffering … 
dhamma@dn1@1@dn1:2.38.17@‘Sukhadukkhī attā hoti …. 
dhamma@dn1@3@dn1:2.38.17@experiences both happiness and suffering … 
dhamma@dn1@1@dn1:2.38.18@‘Adukkhamasukhī attā hoti arogo paraṁ maraṇā saññī’ti naṁ paññapenti. 
dhamma@dn1@3@dn1:2.38.18@experiences neither happiness nor suffering.’ 
dhamma@dn1@1@dn1:3.21.5@Kāmā hi, bho, aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, tesaṁ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā. 
dhamma@dn1@3@dn1:3.21.5@Because sensual pleasures are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Their decay and perishing give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@dn1@1@dn1:3.24.6@Yato kho, bho, ayaṁ attā sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati, ettāvatā kho, bho, ayaṁ attā paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānaṁ patto hotī’ti. 
dhamma@dn1@3@dn1:3.24.6@But giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, this self enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in the present life.’ 
dhamma@dn1@1@dn1:3.71.12@yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā pubbantakappikā ca aparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantakappikā ca pubbantāparantānudiṭṭhino pubbantāparantaṁ ārabbha anekavihitāni adhimuttipadāni abhivadanti dvāsaṭṭhiyā vatthūhi, sabbe te chahi phassāyatanehi phussa phussa paṭisaṁvedenti tesaṁ vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṁ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti. 
dhamma@dn1@3@dn1:3.71.12@Now, when those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the past and the future on these sixty-two grounds, all of them experience this by repeated contact through the six fields of contact. Their feeling is a condition for craving. Craving is a condition for grasping. Grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:20.6@Sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:20.6@All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth. 
dhamma@dn2@4@dn2:20.6@sukhadukkhaṁ → sukhañca dukkhañca (sya-all) 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:20.7@Cuddasa kho panimāni yonipamukhasatasahassāni saṭṭhi ca satāni cha ca satāni pañca ca kammuno satāni pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā dvaṭṭhantarakappā chaḷābhijātiyo aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasate ekūnapaññāsa paribbājakasate ekūnapaññāsa nāgāvāsasate vīse indriyasate tiṁse nirayasate chattiṁsa rajodhātuyo satta saññīgabbhā satta asaññīgabbhā satta nigaṇṭhigabbhā satta devā satta mānusā satta pisācā satta sarā satta pavuṭā satta pavuṭasatāni satta papātā satta papātasatāni satta supinā satta supinasatāni cullāsīti mahākappino satasahassāni, yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:20.7@There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600. There are 500 deeds, and five, and three. There are deeds and half-deeds. There are 62 paths, 62 sub-eons, six classes of rebirth, and eight stages in a person’s life. There are 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,900 wanderers, and 4,900 naked ascetics. There are 2,000 faculties, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dust. There are seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, and seven knotless embryos. There are seven gods, seven humans, and seven goblins. There are seven lakes, seven rivers, 700 rivers, seven cliffs, and 700 cliffs. There are seven dreams and 700 dreams. There are 8.4 million great eons through which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering. 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:20.9@Doṇamite sukhadukkhe pariyantakate saṁsāre, natthi hāyanavaḍḍhane, natthi ukkaṁsāvakaṁse. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:20.9@Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse. 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:20.11@evameva bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissantī’ti. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:20.11@In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’ 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:26.3@Te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṁ byābādhenti, nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:26.3@They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other. 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:26.5@Pathavikāyo, āpokāyo, tejokāyo, vāyokāyo, sukhe, dukkhe, jīve sattame—
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:26.5@The substances of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh. 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:26.7@Te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṁ byābādhenti, nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:26.7@They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other. 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:70.1@Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso ābādhiko assa dukkhito bāḷhagilāno; bhattañcassa nacchādeyya, na cassa kāye balamattā. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:70.1@Suppose there was a person who was sick, suffering, gravely ill. They’d lose their appetite and get physically weak. 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:70.4@‘ahaṁ kho pubbe ābādhiko ahosiṁ dukkhito bāḷhagilāno; 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:70.4@
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:81.1@Puna caparaṁ, mahārāja, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:81.1@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:93.2@So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe, ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:93.2@They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:94.3@So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe, ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:94.3@
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:97.2@So idaṁ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:97.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@dn2@1@dn2:98.3@‘So idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@dn2@3@dn2:98.3@
