dhamma@dn6@1@dn6:13.4@Puna caparaṁ, mahāli, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karoti. 
dhamma@dn6@3@dn6:13.4@Furthermore, a mendicant—with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion—is a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@dn8@1@dn8:3.4@Idhāhaṁ, kassapa, ekaccaṁ tapassiṁ appadukkhavihāriṁ passāmi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannaṁ. 
dhamma@dn8@3@dn8:3.4@I see some fervent mortifier who takes it easy reborn in a place of loss. 
dhamma@dn8@1@dn8:3.5@Idha panāhaṁ, kassapa, ekaccaṁ tapassiṁ appadukkhavihāriṁ passāmi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannaṁ. 
dhamma@dn8@3@dn8:3.5@But I see another fervent mortifier who takes it easy reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm. 
dhamma@dn9@1@dn9:13.1@“Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@dn9@3@dn9:13.1@“Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@dn9@1@dn9:13.3@Adukkhamasukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, adukkhamasukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti. 
dhamma@dn9@3@dn9:13.3@At that time they have a subtle and true perception of neutral feeling. 
dhamma@dn9@1@dn9:29.2@“Idaṁ dukkhanti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākataṁ. Ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākataṁ. Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākataṁ. Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākatan”ti. 
dhamma@dn9@3@dn9:29.2@“I have declared this: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.” 
dhamma@dn9@1@dn9:33.21@Idaṁ dukkhanti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto. 
dhamma@dn9@3@dn9:33.21@‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@dn9@1@dn9:33.22@Ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto. 
dhamma@dn9@1@dn9:33.23@Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto. 
dhamma@dn9@1@dn9:33.24@Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto. 
dhamma@dn9@1@dn9:40.4@‘saṅkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṁ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati, dukkho ca kho vihāro’ti. 
dhamma@dn9@3@dn9:40.4@‘Corrupting qualities will be given up and cleansing qualities will grow. One will enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with one’s own insight in this very life. But such a life is suffering.’ 
dhamma@dn9@1@dn9:41.4@‘saṅkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṁ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati, dukkho ca kho vihāro’ti. 
dhamma@dn9@1@dn9:42.4@‘saṅkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodāniyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṁ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissati, dukkho ca kho vihāro’ti. 
dhamma@dn10@1@dn10:2.8.1@Seyyathāpi, māṇava, puriso ābādhiko assa dukkhito bāḷhagilāno; bhattañcassa nacchādeyya, na cassa kāye balamattā. 
dhamma@dn10@3@dn10:2.8.1@Suppose there was a person who was sick, suffering, gravely ill. They’d lose their appetite and get physically weak. 
dhamma@dn10@1@dn10:2.8.4@‘ahaṁ kho pubbe ābādhiko ahosiṁ dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, bhattañca me nacchādesi, na ca me āsi kāye balamattā. 
dhamma@dn10@1@dn10:2.18.1@Puna caparaṁ, māṇava, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@dn10@3@dn10:2.18.1@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@dn10@1@dn10:2.18.6@yampi, māṇava, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@dn10@1@dn10:2.30.2@So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. Seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto. So tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto; so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@dn10@3@dn10:2.30.2@They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@dn10@1@dn10:2.34.2@So idaṁ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti; 
dhamma@dn10@3@dn10:2.34.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@dn10@1@dn10:2.36.4@So idaṁ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti …pe… 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:1.13.3@Yatra hi nāma tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarissati, nāmatopi anussarissati, gottatopi anussarissati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarissati, sāvakayugatopi anussarissati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarissati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:1.13.3@For he is able to recollect the birth, names, clans, life-span, chief disciples, and gatherings of disciples of the Buddhas of the past who have become completely extinguished, cut off proliferation, cut off the track, finished off the cycle, and transcended suffering. 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:1.13.5@“Kiṁ nu kho, āvuso, tathāgatasseva nu kho esā dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati: ‘evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipi, evaṁnāmā evaṅgottā evaṁsīlā evaṁdhammā evaṁpaññā evaṁvihārī evaṁvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipī’ti, 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:1.13.5@Is it because the Realized One has clearly comprehended the principle of the teachings that he can recollect all these things? 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:1.13.6@udāhu devatā tathāgatassa etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ, yena tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati: ‘evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipi, evaṁnāmā evaṅgottā evaṁsīlā evaṁdhammā evaṁpaññā evaṁvihārī evaṁvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ itipī’”ti. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:1.13.6@Or did deities tell him?” 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:1.14.7@Yatra hi nāma tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarissati, nāmatopi anussarissati, gottatopi anussarissati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarissati, sāvakayugatopi anussarissati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarissati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:1.14.7@
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:1.14.9@Kiṁ nu kho, āvuso, tathāgatasseva nu kho esā dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:1.14.9@
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:1.14.11@Udāhu devatā tathāgatassa etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ, yena tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:1.14.11@
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:1.15.1@“Tathāgatassevesā, bhikkhave, dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:1.15.1@“It is because the Realized One has clearly comprehended the principle of the teachings that he can recollect all these things. 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:1.15.3@Devatāpi tathāgatassa etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ, yena tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:1.15.3@And the deities also told me. 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.2.12@Tatra sudaṁ, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro antepuraṁ gato dukkhī dummano pajjhāyati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.2.12@Back at the royal compound, the prince brooded, miserable and sad: 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.3.15@So kho, deva, kumāro antepuraṁ gato dukkhī dummano pajjhāyati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.3.15@
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.6.1@Addasā kho, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro uyyānabhūmiṁ niyyanto purisaṁ ābādhikaṁ dukkhitaṁ bāḷhagilānaṁ sake muttakarīse palipannaṁ semānaṁ aññehi vuṭṭhāpiyamānaṁ aññehi saṁvesiyamānaṁ. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.6.1@Along the way he saw a man who was ill, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in his own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others. 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.6.12@Tatra sudaṁ, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro antepuraṁ gato dukkhī dummano pajjhāyati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.6.12@Back at the royal compound, the prince brooded, miserable and sad: 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.7.5@‘Addasā kho, deva, kumāro uyyānabhūmiṁ niyyanto purisaṁ ābādhikaṁ dukkhitaṁ bāḷhagilānaṁ sake muttakarīse palipannaṁ semānaṁ aññehi vuṭṭhāpiyamānaṁ aññehi saṁvesiyamānaṁ. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.7.5@And the charioteer told the king about seeing the sick man and the prince’s reaction. 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.7.15@So kho, deva, kumāro antepuraṁ gato dukkhī dummano pajjhāyati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.7.15@
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.10.18@Tatra sudaṁ, bhikkhave, vipassī kumāro antepuraṁ gato dukkhī dummano pajjhāyati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.10.18@Back at the royal compound, the prince brooded, miserable and sad: 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.11.22@So kho, deva, kumāro antepuraṁ gato dukkhī dummano pajjhāyati: 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.11.22@
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.18.2@‘kicchaṁ vatāyaṁ loko āpanno, jāyati ca jīyati ca mīyati ca cavati ca upapajjati ca, atha ca panimassa dukkhassa nissaraṇaṁ nappajānāti jarāmaraṇassa, 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.18.2@‘Alas, this world has fallen into trouble. It’s born, grows old, dies, passes away, and is reborn, yet it doesn’t understand how to escape from this suffering, from old age and death. 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.18.3@kudāssu nāma imassa dukkhassa nissaraṇaṁ paññāyissati jarāmaraṇassā’ti? 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.18.3@Oh, when will an escape be found from this suffering, from old age and death?’ 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.19.4@nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇaṁ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṁ, nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanaṁ, saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṁ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.19.4@Name and form are conditions for consciousness. Consciousness is a condition for name and form. Name and form are conditions for the six sense fields. The six sense fields are conditions for contact. Contact is a condition for feeling. Feeling is a condition for craving. Craving is a condition for grasping. Grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.19.5@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti’. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.19.5@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.’ 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.21.3@nāmarūpanirodhā viññāṇanirodho, viññāṇanirodhā nāmarūpanirodho, nāmarūpanirodhā saḷāyatananirodho, saḷāyatananirodhā phassanirodho, phassanirodhā vedanānirodho, vedanānirodhā taṇhānirodho, taṇhānirodhā upādānanirodho, upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.21.3@When name and form cease, consciousness ceases. When consciousness ceases, name and form cease. When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease. When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases. When contact ceases, feeling ceases. When feeling ceases, craving ceases. When craving ceases, grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:2.21.4@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti’. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:2.21.4@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’ 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:3.11.4@dukkhaṁ samudayaṁ nirodhaṁ maggaṁ. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:3.11.4@suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path. 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:3.15.4@dukkhaṁ samudayaṁ nirodhaṁ maggaṁ. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:3.15.4@suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path. 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:3.19.4@dukkhaṁ samudayaṁ nirodhaṁ maggaṁ. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:3.19.4@
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:3.33.1@Iti kho, bhikkhave, tathāgatassevesā dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati ‘evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ’ itipi. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:3.33.1@And that is how the Realized One is able to recollect the birth, names, clans, life-span, chief disciples, and gatherings of disciples of the Buddhas of the past who have become completely extinguished, cut off proliferation, cut off the track, finished off the cycle, and transcended suffering. It is both because I have clearly comprehended the principle of the teachings, 
dhamma@dn14@1@dn14:3.33.3@Devatāpi tathāgatassa etamatthaṁ ārocesuṁ, yena tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jātitopi anussarati, nāmatopi anussarati, gottatopi anussarati, āyuppamāṇatopi anussarati, sāvakayugatopi anussarati, sāvakasannipātatopi anussarati ‘evaṁjaccā te bhagavanto ahesuṁ’ itipi. 
dhamma@dn14@3@dn14:3.33.3@and also because the deities told me.” 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:3.1@Iti kho, ānanda, nāmarūpapaccayā viññāṇaṁ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṁ, nāmarūpapaccayā phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṁ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:3.1@So: name and form are conditions for consciousness. Consciousness is a condition for name and form. Name and form are conditions for contact. Contact is a condition for feeling. Feeling is a condition for craving. Craving is a condition for grasping. Grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:3.2@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:3.2@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:22.2@Viññāṇañca hi, ānanda, nāmarūpe patiṭṭhaṁ na labhissatha, api nu kho āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇaṁ dukkhasamudayasambhavo paññāyethā”ti? 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:22.2@If consciousness were not to gain a footing in name and form, would the coming to be of the origin of suffering—of rebirth, old age, and death in the future—be found?” 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:28.5@sukhā vedanā dukkhā vedanā adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:28.5@pleasant, painful, and neutral. 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:28.7@Yasmiṁ, ānanda, samaye sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, neva tasmiṁ samaye dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, na adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti; 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:28.7@Ānanda, at a time when you feel a pleasant feeling, you don’t feel a painful or neutral feeling; 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:28.9@Yasmiṁ, ānanda, samaye dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, neva tasmiṁ samaye sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, na adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti; 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:28.9@At a time when you feel a painful feeling, you don’t feel a pleasant or neutral feeling; 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:28.10@dukkhaṁyeva tasmiṁ samaye vedanaṁ vedeti. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:28.10@you only feel a painful feeling. 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:28.11@Yasmiṁ, ānanda, samaye adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, neva tasmiṁ samaye sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, na dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti; 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:28.11@At a time when you feel a neutral feeling, you don’t feel a pleasant or painful feeling; 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:28.12@adukkhamasukhaṁyeva tasmiṁ samaye vedanaṁ vedeti. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:28.12@you only feel a neutral feeling. 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:29.2@Dukkhāpi kho, ānanda, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:29.2@
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:29.3@Adukkhamasukhāpi kho, ānanda, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:29.3@
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:29.6@Dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamānassa ‘eso me attā’ti hoti. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:29.6@When feeling a painful feeling they think: ‘This is my self.’ 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:29.7@Tassāyeva dukkhāya vedanāya nirodhā ‘byagā me attā’ti hoti. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:29.7@When their painful feeling ceases they think: ‘My self has disappeared.’ 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:29.8@Adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vediyamānassa ‘eso me attā’ti hoti. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:29.8@When feeling a neutral feeling they think: ‘This is my self.’ 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:29.9@Tassāyeva adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya nirodhā ‘byagā me attā’ti hoti. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:29.9@When their neutral feeling ceases they think: ‘My self has disappeared.’ 
dhamma@dn15@1@dn15:29.10@Iti so diṭṭheva dhamme aniccasukhadukkhavokiṇṇaṁ uppādavayadhammaṁ attānaṁ samanupassamāno samanupassati, yo so evamāha: ‘vedanā me attā’ti. 
dhamma@dn15@3@dn15:29.10@So those who say ‘feeling is my self’ regard as self that which is evidently impermanent, mixed with pleasure and pain, and liable to rise and fall. 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:1.11.9@Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā, niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagatā viharissanti sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṁ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni. 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:1.11.9@As long as the mendicants live according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private—the view that is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete end of suffering—they can expect growth, not decline. 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:2.2.4@Dukkhassa, bhikkhave, ariyasaccassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ sandhāvitaṁ saṁsaritaṁ mamañceva tumhākañca. 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:2.2.4@The noble truths of suffering, 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:2.2.5@Dukkhasamudayassa, bhikkhave, ariyasaccassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ sandhāvitaṁ saṁsaritaṁ mamañceva tumhākañca. 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:2.2.5@the origin of suffering, 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:2.2.6@Dukkhanirodhassa, bhikkhave, ariyasaccassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ sandhāvitaṁ saṁsaritaṁ mamañceva tumhākañca. 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:2.2.6@the cessation of suffering, 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:2.2.7@Dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya, bhikkhave, ariyasaccassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ sandhāvitaṁ saṁsaritaṁ mamañceva tumhākañca. 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:2.2.7@and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:2.2.8@Tayidaṁ, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ anubuddhaṁ paṭividdhaṁ, dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ anubuddhaṁ paṭividdhaṁ, dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ anubuddhaṁ paṭividdhaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ anubuddhaṁ paṭividdhaṁ, ucchinnā bhavataṇhā, khīṇā bhavanetti, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti. 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:2.2.8@These noble truths of suffering, origin, cessation, and the path have been understood and comprehended. Craving for continued existence has been cut off; the conduit to rebirth is ended; now there are no more future lives.” 
dhamma@dn16@4@dn16:2.2.8@dukkhanirodhaṁ → dukkhanirodho (bj, sya-all) 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:2.3.9@Ucchinnaṁ mūlaṁ dukkhassa, 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:2.3.9@The root of suffering is cut off, 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:2.7.3@Sudatto, ānanda, upāsako tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmī sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissati. 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:2.7.3@The layman Sudatta had ended three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion. He’s a once-returner; he will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:2.7.14@Sādhikā navuti, ānanda, nātike upāsakā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti. 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:2.7.14@More than ninety laymen in Ñātika have passed away having ended three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion. They’re once-returners, who will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:3.51.20@dukkhassantaṁ karissatī”ti. 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:3.51.20@will make an end to suffering.” 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:4.3.9@Dukkhassantakaro satthā, 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:4.3.9@The teacher made an end of suffering, 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:5.21.1@Idamāyasmato ānandassa vacanaṁ sutvā mallā ca mallaputtā ca mallasuṇisā ca mallapajāpatiyo ca aghāvino dummanā cetodukkhasamappitā appekacce kese pakiriya kandanti, bāhā paggayha kandanti, chinnapātaṁ papatanti, āvaṭṭanti vivaṭṭanti: 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:5.21.1@When they heard what Ānanda had to say, the Mallas, their sons, daughters-in-law, and wives became distraught, saddened, and grief-stricken. And some, with hair disheveled and arms raised, falling down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamented, 
dhamma@dn16@1@dn16:5.21.3@Atha kho mallā ca mallaputtā ca mallasuṇisā ca mallapajāpatiyo ca aghāvino dummanā cetodukkhasamappitā yena upavattanaṁ mallānaṁ sālavanaṁ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamiṁsu. 
dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:5.21.3@Then the Mallas, their sons, daughters-in-law, and wives, distraught, saddened, and grief-stricken went to the Mallian sal grove at Upavattana and approached Ānanda.

dhamma@dn16@3@dn16:6.12.10@When they heard what Ānanda had to say, the Mallas, their sons, daughters-in-law, and wives became distraught, saddened, and grief-stricken. And some, with hair disheveled and arms raised, falling down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamented, 
dhamma@dn17@1@dn17:2.3.4@Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsi. 
dhamma@dn17@3@dn17:2.3.4@With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, he entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@dn17@1@dn17:2.11.6@“sabbeheva, deva, piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo aññathābhāvo, mā kho tvaṁ, deva, sāpekkho kālamakāsi, dukkhā sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā, garahitā ca sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā. 
dhamma@dn17@3@dn17:2.11.6@“Sire, we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved. Don’t pass away with concerns. Such concern is suffering, and it’s criticized. 
dhamma@dn17@1@dn17:2.12.3@‘Sabbeheva, deva, piyehi manāpehi nānābhāvo vinābhāvo aññathābhāvo, mā kho tvaṁ, deva, sāpekkho kālamakāsi, dukkhā sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā, garahitā ca sāpekkhassa kālaṅkiriyā. 
dhamma@dn17@3@dn17:2.12.3@‘Sire, we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved. Don’t pass away with concerns. Such concern is suffering, and it’s criticized. 
dhamma@dn18@1@dn18:1.6@Sādhikā navuti nātikiyā paricārakā abbhatītā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti. 
dhamma@dn18@3@dn18:1.6@More than ninety devotees in Ñātika have passed away having ended three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion. They’re once-returners, who will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

dhamma@dn19@1@dn19:32.5@‘mayaṁ kho bhoto reṇussa sahāyā piyā manāpā appaṭikūlā, yaṁsukho bhavaṁ taṁsukhā mayaṁ, yaṁdukkho bhavaṁ taṁdukkhā mayaṁ. 
dhamma@dn19@3@dn19:32.5@‘Prince Reṇu, we are your friends, dear, beloved, and cherished. We have shared your joys and sorrows. 
dhamma@dn19@1@dn19:33.3@yaṁsukho bhavaṁ taṁsukhā mayaṁ, yaṁdukkho bhavaṁ taṁdukkhā mayaṁ. 
dhamma@dn19@3@dn19:33.3@
dhamma@dn19@1@dn19:62.3@Ye na sabbenasabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājānanti, appekacce tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino honti sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti. 
dhamma@dn19@3@dn19:62.3@Some, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, become once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:1.7@“Ekāyano ayaṁ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā, sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṁ cattāro satipaṭṭhānā. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:1.7@“Mendicants, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:11.3@Dukkhaṁ vā vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:11.3@When they feel a painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’ 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:11.4@Adukkhamasukhaṁ vā vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:11.4@When they feel a neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling.’ 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:11.7@Sāmisaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:11.7@When they feel a painful feeling of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling of the flesh.’ 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:11.8@Nirāmisaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:11.8@When they feel a painful feeling not of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling not of the flesh.’ 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:11.9@Sāmisaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:11.9@When they feel a material neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a material neutral feeling.’ 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:11.10@Nirāmisaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:11.10@When they feel a neutral feeling not of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling not of the flesh.’ 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:17.3@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:17.3@It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.0@4.5.1. Dukkhasaccaniddesa 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.0@4.5.1. The Truth of Suffering 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ? 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.1@And what is the noble truth of suffering? 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.2@Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, maraṇampi dukkhaṁ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, appiyehi sampayogopi dukkho, piyehi vippayogopi dukkho, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.2@Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; association with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering. 
dhamma@dn22@4@dn22:18.2@dukkho → appiyehi …pe… vippayogo dukkhotipāṭho ceva taṁniddeso ca katthaci na dissati, aṭṭhakathāyampi taṁsaṁvaṇṇanā 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.13@Yo kho, bhikkhave, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa soko socanā socitattaṁ antosoko antoparisoko, 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.13@The sorrow, sorrowing, state of sorrow, inner sorrow, inner deep sorrow in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.16@Yo kho, bhikkhave, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa ādevo paridevo ādevanā paridevanā ādevitattaṁ paridevitattaṁ, 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.16@The wail, lament, wailing, lamenting, state of wailing and lamentation in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.18@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ? 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.18@And what is pain? 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.19@Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṁ dukkhaṁ kāyikaṁ asātaṁ kāyasamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ, 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.19@Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.20@idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.20@This is called pain. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.22@Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ cetasikaṁ asātaṁ manosamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ, 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.22@Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mental contact. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.25@Yo kho, bhikkhave, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa āyāso upāyāso āyāsitattaṁ upāyāsitattaṁ, 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.25@The stress, distress, state of stress and distress in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.27@Katamo ca, bhikkhave, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho? 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.27@And what is meant by ‘association with the disliked is suffering’? 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.29@ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.29@this is what is meant by ‘association with the disliked is suffering’. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.30@Katamo ca, bhikkhave, piyehi vippayogo dukkho? 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.30@And what is meant by ‘separation from the liked is suffering’? 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.32@ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, piyehi vippayogo dukkho. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.32@this is what is meant by ‘separation from the liked is suffering’. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.33@Katamañca, bhikkhave, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ? 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.33@And what is meant by ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering’? 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.37@idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.37@This is what is meant by ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’ 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.40@Na kho panetaṁ icchāya pattabbaṁ, idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.40@
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.42@Na kho panetaṁ icchāya pattabbaṁ, idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.42@
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.44@Na kho panetaṁ icchāya pattabbaṁ, idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.44@
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.45@Sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammānaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṁ icchā uppajjati ‘aho vata mayaṁ na sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā assāma, na ca vata no sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsaā āgaccheyyun’ti. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.45@experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, such a wish arises: ‘Oh, if only we were not liable to experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress! If only sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress would not come to us!’ 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.47@idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.47@This is what is meant by ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’ 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.48@Katame ca, bhikkhave, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā? 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.48@And what is meant by ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering’? 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.50@Ime vuccanti, bhikkhave, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.50@This is what is meant by ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering’. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:18.51@Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:18.51@This is called the noble truth of suffering. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:19.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ? 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:19.1@And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering? 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:19.67@Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:19.67@This is called the noble truth of the origin of suffering. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:20.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ? 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:20.1@And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering? 
dhamma@dn22@4@dn22:20.1@dukkhanirodhaṁ → dukkhanirodho (bj, sya-all, km) 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:20.66@Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:20.66@This is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:21.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ? 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:21.1@And what is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering? 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:21.5@Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:21.5@Knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:21.35@Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:21.35@Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:21.37@Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:21.37@This is called the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@dn22@1@dn22:22.24@Ekāyano ayaṁ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya yadidaṁ cattāro satipaṭṭhānāti. 
dhamma@dn22@3@dn22:22.24@‘The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.’

dhamma@dn23@1@dn23:12.6@“Idhāhaṁ, bho kassapa, passāmi samaṇabrāhmaṇe sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme jīvitukāme amaritukāme sukhakāme dukkhapaṭikūle. 
dhamma@dn23@3@dn23:12.6@“Well, I see ascetics and brahmins who are ethical, of good character, who want to live and don’t want to die, who want to be happy and recoil from pain. 
dhamma@dn23@1@dn23:12.12@‘ito no matānaṁ seyyo bhavissatī’ti, tasmā ime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā jīvitukāmā amaritukāmā sukhakāmā dukkhapaṭikūlā attānaṁ na mārenti. 
dhamma@dn23@3@dn23:12.12@things are going to be better for them after death. That’s why they are ethical, of good character, wanting to live and not wanting to die, wanting to be happy and recoiling from pain.’

dhamma@dn23@1@dn23:31.3@So tattha dukkhette dubbhūme avihatakhāṇukaṇṭake bījāni patiṭṭhāpeyya khaṇḍāni pūtīni vātātapahatāni asāradāni asukhasayitāni. 
dhamma@dn23@3@dn23:31.3@And on that barren field, that barren ground, with uncleared stumps he sowed seeds that were broken, spoiled, weather-damaged, infertile, and ill kept. 
dhamma@dn24@1@dn24:1.4.14@kate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye akate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye yassatthāya mayā dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti? 
dhamma@dn24@3@dn24:1.4.14@Whether or not there is a demonstration of psychic power, does my teaching lead someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering?’ 
dhamma@dn24@1@dn24:1.4.15@‘Kate vā, bhante, uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye akate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye yassatthāya bhagavatā dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti. 
dhamma@dn24@3@dn24:1.4.15@‘It does, sir.’ 
dhamma@dn24@1@dn24:1.4.16@‘Iti kira, sunakkhatta, kate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye, akate vā uttari manussadhammā iddhipāṭihāriye, yassatthāya mayā dhammo desito, so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@dn24@3@dn24:1.4.16@‘So it seems that whether or not there is a demonstration of psychic power, my teaching leads someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@dn24@1@dn24:1.5.14@paññatte vā aggaññe, apaññatte vā aggaññe, yassatthāya mayā dhammo desito, so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti? 
dhamma@dn24@3@dn24:1.5.14@Whether or not the origin of the world is described, does my teaching lead someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering?’ 
dhamma@dn24@1@dn24:1.5.15@‘Paññatte vā, bhante, aggaññe, apaññatte vā aggaññe, yassatthāya bhagavatā dhammo desito, so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti. 
dhamma@dn24@3@dn24:1.5.15@‘It does, sir.’ 
dhamma@dn24@1@dn24:1.5.16@‘Iti kira, sunakkhatta, paññatte vā aggaññe, apaññatte vā aggaññe, yassatthāya mayā dhammo desito, so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@dn24@3@dn24:1.5.16@‘So it seems that whether or not the origin of the world is described, my teaching leads someone who practices it to the goal of the complete ending of suffering.

dhamma@dn25@1@dn25:18.13@So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ, tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@dn25@3@dn25:18.13@They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@dn25@1@dn25:23.22@Santi ca kho, nigrodha, akusalā dhammā appahīnā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, yesāhaṁ pahānāya dhammaṁ desemi. 
dhamma@dn25@3@dn25:23.22@Nigrodha, there are things that are unskillful, corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. I teach Dhamma so that those things may be given up. 
dhamma@dn26@1@dn26:5.6@“kiṁ, bhante, kusalaṁ, kiṁ akusalaṁ, kiṁ sāvajjaṁ, kiṁ anavajjaṁ, kiṁ sevitabbaṁ, kiṁ na sevitabbaṁ, kiṁ me karīyamānaṁ dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya assa, kiṁ vā pana me karīyamānaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya assā”ti? 
dhamma@dn26@3@dn26:5.6@“Sirs, what is skillful? What is unskillful? What is blameworthy? What is blameless? What should be cultivated? What should not be cultivated? Doing what leads to my lasting harm and suffering? Doing what leads to my lasting welfare and happiness?” 
dhamma@dn27@1@dn27:15.10@Tadetarahipi manussā kenaci dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhā evamāhaṁsu: 
dhamma@dn27@3@dn27:15.10@And even today when people experience suffering they say: 
dhamma@dn27@1@dn27:29.1@Khattiyopi kho, vāseṭṭha, kāyena dvayakārī, vācāya dvayakārī, manasā dvayakārī, vimissadiṭṭhiko vimissadiṭṭhikammasamādāno vimissadiṭṭhikammasamādānahetu kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī hoti. 
dhamma@dn27@3@dn27:29.1@An aristocrat, 
dhamma@dn27@1@dn27:29.5@samaṇopi kho, vāseṭṭha, kāyena dvayakārī, vācāya dvayakārī, manasā dvayakārī, vimissadiṭṭhiko vimissadiṭṭhikammasamādāno vimissadiṭṭhikammasamādānahetu kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī hoti. 
dhamma@dn27@3@dn27:29.5@or ascetic may do mixed things by way of body, speech, and mind. They have mixed view, and they act out of that mixed view. And because of that, when their body breaks up, after death, they experience both pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@dn28@1@dn28:10.2@Catasso imā, bhante, paṭipadā dukkhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā, 
dhamma@dn28@3@dn28:10.2@Painful practice with slow insight, 
dhamma@dn28@1@dn28:10.3@dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā, 
dhamma@dn28@3@dn28:10.3@painful practice with swift insight, 
dhamma@dn28@1@dn28:10.6@Tatra, bhante, yāyaṁ paṭipadā dukkhā dandhābhiññā, ayaṁ, bhante, paṭipadā ubhayeneva hīnā akkhāyati dukkhattā ca dandhattā ca. 
dhamma@dn28@3@dn28:10.6@Of these, the painful practice with slow insight is said to be inferior both ways: because it’s painful and because it’s slow. 
dhamma@dn28@1@dn28:10.7@Tatra, bhante, yāyaṁ paṭipadā dukkhā khippābhiññā, ayaṁ pana, bhante, paṭipadā dukkhattā hīnā akkhāyati. 
dhamma@dn28@3@dn28:10.7@The painful practice with swift insight is said to be inferior because it’s painful. 
dhamma@dn28@1@dn28:13.6@‘ayaṁ puggalo yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmī bhavissati, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissatī’ti. 
dhamma@dn28@3@dn28:13.6@‘By practicing as instructed this individual will, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, become a once-returner. They will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.’ 
dhamma@dn28@1@dn28:14.5@‘ayaṁ puggalo tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmī bhavissati, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissatī’ti. 
dhamma@dn28@3@dn28:14.5@‘With the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, this individual will become a once-returner. They will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.’ 
dhamma@dn28@1@dn28:15.4@Seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekānipi jātisatāni anekānipi jātisahassāni anekānipi jātisatasahassāni, ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@dn28@3@dn28:15.4@with features and details. 
dhamma@dn28@1@dn28:15.11@Seyyathidaṁ—ekampi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭaṁ dvepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tīṇipi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattāripi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni pañcapi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni dasapi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni, ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@dn28@3@dn28:15.11@with features and details. 
dhamma@dn28@1@dn28:15.19@Seyyathidaṁ—dasapi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni vīsampi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni tiṁsampi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni cattālīsampi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭāni, ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. dhamma@dn28@3@dn28:16.4@‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@dn28@1@dn28:19.2@Na ca, bhante, bhagavā kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogamanuyutto hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na ca attakilamathānuyogamanuyutto dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ. 
dhamma@dn28@3@dn28:19.2@The Buddha doesn’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And he doesn’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless. 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:24.13@Puna caparaṁ, cunda, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:24.13@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption. It is without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:25.8@Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karoti. 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:25.8@Furthermore, a mendicant—with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion—becomes a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:32.4@‘idaṁ dukkhanti kho, āvuso, bhagavatā byākataṁ, ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti kho, āvuso, bhagavatā byākataṁ, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti kho, āvuso, bhagavatā byākataṁ, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti kho, āvuso, bhagavatā byākatan’ti. 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:32.4@‘What has been declared by the Buddha is this: “This is suffering”—“This is the origin of suffering”—“This is the cessation of suffering”—“This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.”’ 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:34.17@‘Sassataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ … 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:34.17@Pleasure and pain are eternal, 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:34.18@asassataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ … 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:34.18@or not eternal, 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:34.19@sassatañca asassatañca sukhadukkhaṁ … 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:34.19@or both eternal and not eternal, 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:34.20@nevasassataṁ nāsassataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ … 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:34.20@or neither eternal nor not eternal. 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:34.21@sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ … 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:34.21@Pleasure and pain are made by oneself, 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:34.22@paraṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ … 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:34.22@or made by another, 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:34.23@sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca sukhadukkhaṁ … 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:34.23@or made by both oneself and another, 
dhamma@dn29@1@dn29:34.24@asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti. 
dhamma@dn29@3@dn29:34.24@or they have arisen by chance, not made by oneself or another. This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’

dhamma@dn30@1@dn30:1.25.3@‘kiṁ, bhante, kusalaṁ, kiṁ akusalaṁ, kiṁ sāvajjaṁ, kiṁ anavajjaṁ, kiṁ sevitabbaṁ, kiṁ na sevitabbaṁ, kiṁ me karīyamānaṁ dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya assa, kiṁ vā pana me karīyamānaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya assā’ti. 
dhamma@dn30@3@dn30:1.25.3@‘Sirs, what is skillful? What is unskillful? What is blameworthy? What is blameless? What should be cultivated? What should not be cultivated? Doing what leads to my lasting harm and suffering? Doing what leads to my lasting welfare and happiness?’ 
dhamma@dn31@1@dn31:9.2@Attāpissa agutto arakkhito hoti, puttadāropissa agutto arakkhito hoti, sāpateyyampissa aguttaṁ arakkhitaṁ hoti, saṅkiyo ca hoti pāpakesu ṭhānesu, abhūtavacanañca tasmiṁ rūhati, bahūnañca dukkhadhammānaṁ purakkhato hoti. 
dhamma@dn31@3@dn31:9.2@Yourself, your partners and children, and your property are all left unguarded. You’re suspected of bad deeds. Untrue rumors spread about you. You’re at the forefront of many things that entail suffering. 
dhamma@dn31@1@dn31:21.2@Upakāro mitto suhado veditabbo, samānasukhadukkho mitto suhado veditabbo, atthakkhāyī mitto suhado veditabbo, anukampako mitto suhado veditabbo. 
dhamma@dn31@3@dn31:21.2@the helper, the friend in good times and bad, the counselor, and the one who’s compassionate. 
dhamma@dn31@1@dn31:23.1@Catūhi kho, gahapatiputta, ṭhānehi samānasukhadukkho mitto suhado veditabbo. 
dhamma@dn31@3@dn31:23.1@You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s the same in good times and bad on four grounds. 
dhamma@dn31@1@dn31:23.3@Imehi kho, gahapatiputta, catūhi ṭhānehi samānasukhadukkho mitto suhado veditabbo. 
dhamma@dn31@3@dn31:23.3@You can recognize a good-hearted friend who’s the same in good times and bad on these four grounds. 
dhamma@dn31@1@dn31:26.2@sukhe dukkhe ca yo sakhā; 
dhamma@dn31@3@dn31:26.2@one the same in both pleasure and pain, 
dhamma@dn31@4@dn31:26.2@sukhe dukkhe → sukhadukkho (sya-all, mr) | ca yo sakhā → yo ca mitto sukhe dukhe (bj); yo ca mitto sukhe dukkhe (si, pts1ed) 
dhamma@dn32@1@dn32:3.17@sabbadukkhāpanūdanaṁ. 
dhamma@dn32@3@dn32:3.17@that dispels all suffering. 
dhamma@dn32@1@dn32:12.30@sabbadukkhāpanūdanaṁ. 
dhamma@dn32@3@dn32:12.30@
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:1.10.55@sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:1.10.55@pleasure, pain, and neutral. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:1.10.56@Tisso dukkhatā—
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:1.10.56@Three forms of suffering: 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:1.10.57@dukkhadukkhatā, saṅkhāradukkhatā, vipariṇāmadukkhatā. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:1.10.57@the suffering inherent in painful feeling, the suffering inherent in conditions, and the suffering inherent in perishing. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:1.11.23@Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:1.11.23@Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:1.11.105@dukkhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṁ. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:1.11.105@knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:1.11.135@dukkhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā, dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā, sukhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā, sukhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:1.11.135@painful practice with slow insight, painful practice with swift insight, pleasant practice with slow insight, and pleasant practice with swift insight. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:1.11.141@atthāvuso, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:1.11.141@There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:1.11.142@Atthāvuso, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:1.11.142@There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:1.11.143@Atthāvuso, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhaṁ āyatiṁ dukkhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:1.11.143@There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:2.1.71@Paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammādukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:2.1.71@They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:2.1.98@sukhindriyaṁ, dukkhindriyaṁ, somanassindriyaṁ, domanassindriyaṁ, upekkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:2.1.98@pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:2.1.140@aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:2.1.140@the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in impermanence, the perception of not-self in suffering, the perception of giving up, and the perception of fading away. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:2.2.48@Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:2.2.48@They live according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and brings one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:2.2.53@Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso, dhamme agāravo viharati appatisso, saṅghe agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāya na paripūrakārī, so saṅghe vivādaṁ janeti. Yo hoti vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṁ. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:2.2.53@They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:2.2.63@Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso, dhamme agāravo viharati appatisso, saṅghe agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāya na paripūrakārī, so saṅghe vivādaṁ janeti. Yo hoti vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṁ. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:2.2.63@
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:2.2.128@aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:2.2.128@the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in impermanence, the perception of not-self in suffering, the perception of giving up, the perception of fading away, and the perception of cessation. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:3.1.141@lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṁsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañca. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:3.1.141@gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:3.3.32@Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu paññavā hoti, udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammādukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:3.3.32@Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:3.3.33@Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu paññavā hoti …pe… sammādukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:3.3.33@
dhamma@dn33@1@dn33:3.3.76@Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@dn33@3@dn33:3.3.76@It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

dhamma@dn34@3@dn34:1.1.9@for making an end of suffering,

dhamma@dn34@3@dn34:1.4.11@pleasant, painful, and neutral. 
dhamma@dn34@1@dn34:1.5.39@dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ. 
dhamma@dn34@3@dn34:1.5.39@suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

dhamma@dn34@1@dn34:1.6.9@Paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@dn34@3@dn34:1.6.9@They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@dn34@1@dn34:1.7.10@Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi sāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, 
dhamma@dn34@3@dn34:1.7.10@Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@dn34@1@dn34:2.1.36@lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṁsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañca. 
dhamma@dn34@3@dn34:2.1.36@gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, pleasure and pain.

dhamma@dn34@3@dn34:2.2.64@the perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness in food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, and fading away.

dhamma@dn34@3@dn34:2.3.31@Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@dn34@1@dn34:2.3.94@Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@dn34@3@dn34:2.3.94@Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@dn34@1@dn34:2.3.109@asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā.
