dhamma@mn1@1@mn1:171.4@‘Nandī dukkhassa mūlan’ti—
dhamma@mn1@3@mn1:171.4@Because he has understood that taking pleasure is the root of suffering, 
dhamma@mn1@1@mn1:194.4@‘Nandī dukkhassa mūlan’ti—
dhamma@mn1@3@mn1:194.4@Because he has understood that taking pleasure is the root of suffering, 
dhamma@mn2@1@mn2:8.10@Diṭṭhisaṁyojanasaṁyutto, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano na parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi; 
dhamma@mn2@3@mn2:8.10@An unlearned ordinary person who is fettered by views is not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@mn2@1@mn2:8.11@‘na parimuccati dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn2@3@mn2:8.11@They’re not freed from suffering, I say. 
dhamma@mn2@1@mn2:11.1@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yoniso manasi karoti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yoniso manasi karoti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yoniso manasi karoti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yoniso manasi karoti. 
dhamma@mn2@3@mn2:11.1@They rationally apply the mind: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@mn2@1@mn2:18.2@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso khamo hoti sītassa uṇhassa, jighacchāya pipāsāya. Ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ, duruttānaṁ durāgatānaṁ vacanapathānaṁ, uppannānaṁ sārīrikānaṁ vedanānaṁ dukkhānaṁ tibbānaṁ kharānaṁ kaṭukānaṁ asātānaṁ amanāpānaṁ pāṇaharānaṁ adhivāsakajātiko hoti. 
dhamma@mn2@3@mn2:18.2@Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst. They endure the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles. They endure rude and unwelcome criticism. And they put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening. 
dhamma@mn2@1@mn2:22.2@ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave: ‘bhikkhu sabbāsavasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati, acchecchi taṇhaṁ, vivattayi saṁyojanaṁ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā’”ti. 
dhamma@mn2@3@mn2:22.2@They’re called a mendicant who lives having restrained all defilements, who has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.” 
dhamma@mn4@1@mn4:22-26.5@Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ. 
dhamma@mn4@3@mn4:22-26.5@With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn4@1@mn4:27.2@seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarāmi. 
dhamma@mn4@3@mn4:27.2@That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. I remembered: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@mn4@1@mn4:31.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ. 
dhamma@mn4@3@mn4:31.2@I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@mn6@1@mn6:12.1@Ākaṅkheyya ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu: ‘tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmī assaṁ sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ kareyyan’ti, sīlesvevassa paripūrakārī …pe… brūhetā suññāgārānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn6@3@mn6:12.1@A mendicant might wish: ‘May I, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, become a once-returner, coming back to this world once only, then making an end of suffering.’ So let them fulfill their precepts … 
dhamma@mn6@1@mn6:17.1@Ākaṅkheyya ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu: ‘anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussareyyaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jāti satasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe—amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapannoti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussareyyan’ti, 
dhamma@mn6@3@mn6:17.1@A mendicant might wish: ‘May I recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. May I remember: “There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.” May I thus recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.’ 
dhamma@mn8@1@mn8:7.1@Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, cunda, vijjati yaṁ idhekacco bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihareyya. 
dhamma@mn8@3@mn8:7.1@It’s possible that some mendicant, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, might enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:8.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ akusalaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ akusalamūlaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ kusalaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ kusalamūlaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya, paṭighānusayaṁ paṭivinodetvā, ‘asmī’ti diṭṭhimānānusayaṁ samūhanitvā, avijjaṁ pahāya vijjaṁ uppādetvā, diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:8.1@A noble disciple understands in this way the unskillful and its root, and the skillful and its root. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendency to greed, got rid of the underlying tendency to repulsion, and eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’. They’ve given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, and make an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:12.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ āhāraṁ pajānāti, evaṁ āhārasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ āhāranirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ āhāranirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya, paṭighānusayaṁ paṭivinodetvā, ‘asmī’ti diṭṭhimānānusayaṁ samūhanitvā, avijjaṁ pahāya vijjaṁ uppādetvā, diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:12.1@A noble disciple understands in this way fuel, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendency to greed, got rid of the underlying tendency to repulsion, and eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’. They’ve given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, and make an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:14.2@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako dukkhañca pajānāti, dukkhasamudayañca pajānāti, dukkhanirodhañca pajānāti, dukkhanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadañca pajānāti—
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:14.2@A noble disciple understands suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:15.1@Katamaṁ panāvuso, dukkhaṁ, katamo dukkhasamudayo, katamo dukkhanirodho, katamā dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā? 
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:15.1@But what is suffering? What is its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation? 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:15.2@Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, maraṇampi dukkhaṁ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, appiyehi sampayogopi dukkho, piyehi vippayogopi dukkho, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā—
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:15.2@Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; association with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:15.3@idaṁ vuccatāvuso, dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:15.3@This is called suffering. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:16.1@Katamo cāvuso, dukkhasamudayo? 
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:16.1@And what is the origin of suffering? 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:16.4@ayaṁ vuccatāvuso, dukkhasamudayo. 
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:16.4@This is called the origin of suffering. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:17.1@Katamo cāvuso, dukkhanirodho? 
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:17.1@And what is the cessation of suffering? 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:17.3@ayaṁ vuccatāvuso, dukkhanirodho. 
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:17.3@This is called the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:18.1@Katamā cāvuso, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā? 
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:18.1@And what is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering? 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:18.4@ayaṁ vuccatāvuso, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā. 
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:18.4@This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:19.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ dukkhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ dukkhasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ dukkhanirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya, paṭighānusayaṁ paṭivinodetvā, ‘asmī’ti diṭṭhimānānusayaṁ samūhanitvā, avijjaṁ pahāya vijjaṁ uppādetvā, diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:19.1@A noble disciple understands in this way suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendency to greed, got rid of the underlying tendency to repulsion, and eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’. They’ve given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, and make an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:23.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ jarāmaraṇaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ jarāmaraṇasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ jarāmaraṇanirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:27.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ jātiṁ pajānāti, evaṁ jātisamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ jātinirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ jātinirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:31.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ bhavaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ bhavasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ bhavanirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ bhavanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:35.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ upādānaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ upādānasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ upādānanirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ upādānanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:39.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ taṇhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ taṇhāsamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ taṇhānirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ taṇhānirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:43.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ vedanaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ vedanāsamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ vedanānirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ vedanānirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:47.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ phassaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ phassasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ phassanirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ phassanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:51.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ saḷāyatanaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ saḷāyatanasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ saḷāyatananirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ saḷāyatananirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:55.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ nāmarūpaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ nāmarūpasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ nāmarūpanirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ nāmarūpanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:59.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ viññāṇaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ viññāṇasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ viññāṇanirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ viññāṇanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya …pe… dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:63.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ saṅkhāre pajānāti, evaṁ saṅkhārasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ saṅkhāranirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya, paṭighānusayaṁ paṭivinodetvā, ‘asmī’ti diṭṭhimānānusayaṁ samūhanitvā, avijjaṁ pahāya vijjaṁ uppādetvā, diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:65.4@Yaṁ kho, āvuso, dukkhe aññāṇaṁ, dukkhasamudaye aññāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhe aññāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya aññāṇaṁ—
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:65.4@Not knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:67.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ avijjaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ avijjāsamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ avijjānirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ avijjānirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya, paṭighānusayaṁ paṭivinodetvā, ‘asmī’ti diṭṭhimānānusayaṁ samūhanitvā, avijjaṁ pahāya vijjaṁ uppādetvā, diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@1@mn9:71.1@Yato kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako evaṁ āsavaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ āsavasamudayaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ āsavanirodhaṁ pajānāti, evaṁ āsavanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ pajānāti, so sabbaso rāgānusayaṁ pahāya, paṭighānusayaṁ paṭivinodetvā, ‘asmī’ti diṭṭhimānānusayaṁ samūhanitvā, avijjaṁ pahāya vijjaṁ uppādetvā, diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hoti—
dhamma@mn9@3@mn9:71.1@A noble disciple understands in this way defilement, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendency to greed, got rid of the underlying tendency to repulsion, and eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’. They’ve given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, and make an end of suffering in this very life. 
dhamma@mn10@1@mn10:2.1@“Ekāyano ayaṁ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā, sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya, dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya, ñāyassa adhigamāya, nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṁ cattāro satipaṭṭhānā. 
dhamma@mn10@3@mn10:2.1@“Mendicants, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment. 
dhamma@mn10@1@mn10:32.3@Dukkhaṁ vā vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn10@3@mn10:32.3@When they feel a painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’ 
dhamma@mn10@4@mn10:32.3@Dukkhaṁ vā → dukkhaṁ (bj, sya-all, pts1ed, mr)
dhamma@mn10@1@mn10:32.4@Adukkhamasukhaṁ vā vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn10@3@mn10:32.4@When they feel a neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling.’ 
dhamma@mn10@1@mn10:32.7@Sāmisaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn10@3@mn10:32.7@When they feel a material painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a material painful feeling.’ 
dhamma@mn10@1@mn10:32.8@Nirāmisaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn10@3@mn10:32.8@When they feel a painful feeling not of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling not of the flesh.’ 
dhamma@mn10@1@mn10:32.9@Sāmisaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘sāmisaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn10@3@mn10:32.9@When they feel a material neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a material neutral feeling.’ 
dhamma@mn10@1@mn10:32.10@Nirāmisaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘nirāmisaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn10@3@mn10:32.10@When they feel a neutral feeling not of the flesh, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling not of the flesh.’ 
dhamma@mn10@1@mn10:44.3@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn10@3@mn10:44.3@It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn10@1@mn10:47.1@‘Ekāyano ayaṁ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya yadidaṁ cattāro satipaṭṭhānā’ti. 
dhamma@mn10@3@mn10:47.1@‘The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.’ 
dhamma@mn11@1@mn11:7.2@te na parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi; 
dhamma@mn11@3@mn11:7.2@They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@mn11@1@mn11:7.3@na parimuccanti dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn11@3@mn11:7.3@They’re not freed from suffering, I say. 
dhamma@mn11@1@mn11:8.2@te parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi; 
dhamma@mn11@3@mn11:8.2@They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@mn11@1@mn11:8.3@parimuccanti dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn11@3@mn11:8.3@They’re freed from suffering, I say. 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:2.5@Yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:2.5@And his teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it’s taught.” 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:3.5@Yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:3.5@
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:3.11@Yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’”ti. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:3.11@
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:4.5@‘yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:4.5@‘His teaching leads those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it’s taught.’ 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:17.1@Puna caparaṁ, sāriputta, tathāgato anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:17.1@Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so he recollects his many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:26.1@‘Yassa kho pana te atthāya dhammo desito, so na niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā’ti. Tatra vata maṁ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṁ sahadhammena paṭicodessatīti nimittametaṁ, sāriputta, na samanupassāmi. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:26.1@I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or Brahmā, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying: ‘The teaching doesn’t lead those who practice it to the complete ending of suffering, the goal for which it is taught.’ 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:37.3@Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannaṁ, ekantadukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:37.3@Then some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in hell, where they experience exclusively painful feelings, sharp and severe. 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:37.8@Tamenaṁ passeyya aparena samayena tassā aṅgārakāsuyā patitaṁ, ekantadukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:37.8@Then some time later they see that they have indeed fallen into that pit of coals, where they experience exclusively painful feelings, sharp and severe. … 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:37.11@Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannaṁ, ekantadukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:37.11@
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:38.3@Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṁ upapannaṁ, dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:38.3@Then some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in the animal realm, where they suffer painful feelings, sharp and severe. 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:38.8@Tamenaṁ passeyya aparena samayena tasmiṁ gūthakūpe patitaṁ, dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:38.8@Then some time later they see that they have indeed fallen into that sewer, where they suffer painful feelings, sharp and severe. … 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:38.11@Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā tiracchānayoniṁ upapannaṁ, dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:38.11@
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:39.3@Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā pettivisayaṁ upapannaṁ, dukkhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:39.3@Then some time later I see that they have indeed been reborn in the ghost realm, where they experience mostly painful feelings. 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:39.8@Tamenaṁ passeyya, aparena samayena tassa rukkhassa chāyāya nisinnaṁ vā nipannaṁ vā dukkhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:39.8@Then some time later they see them sitting or lying under that tree, where they experience mostly painful feelings. … 
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:39.11@Tamenaṁ passāmi aparena samayena dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā pettivisayaṁ upapannaṁ, dukkhabahulā vedanā vedayamānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:39.11@
dhamma@mn12@1@mn12:56.3@Imissāyeva ariyāya paññāya anadhigamā, yāyaṁ ariyā paññā adhigatā ariyā niyyānikā, niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@mn12@3@mn12:56.3@Because I didn’t achieve that noble wisdom that’s noble and emancipating, and which delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:0.2@Mahādukkhakkhandhasutta 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:0.2@The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:8.5@ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu. 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:8.5@This is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures. 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:9.4@Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu. 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:9.4@This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:10.2@But they experience pain and sadness when they try to protect it, thinking: 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:10.7@Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu. 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:10.7@This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures. 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:11.3@Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:11.3@resulting in death and deadly pain.

dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:12.4@This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:13.4@This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures. 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:14.4@Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:14.4@These result in death and deadly pain. 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:14.5@Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu. 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:14.5@This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures. 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:15.3@Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo samparāyiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu. 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:15.3@This is a drawback of sensual pleasures to do with lives to come, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures. 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:20.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṁ passeyya ābādhikaṁ dukkhitaṁ bāḷhagilānaṁ, sake muttakarīse palipannaṁ semānaṁ, aññehi vuṭṭhāpiyamānaṁ, aññehi saṁvesiyamānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:20.1@Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in her own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others. 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:33-35.3@yasmiṁ samaye, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati, neva tasmiṁ samaye attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti; 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:33-35.3@fourth absorption. At that time a mendicant doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both; 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:36.2@Yaṁ, bhikkhave, vedanā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā—ayaṁ vedanānaṁ ādīnavo. 
dhamma@mn13@3@mn13:36.2@That feelings are impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is their drawback. 
dhamma@mn13@1@mn13:38.5@Mahādukkhakkhandhasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ tatiyaṁ.
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:0.2@Cūḷadukkhakkhandhasutta 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:0.2@The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:4.1@‘Appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:4.1@Sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:4.4@Yato ca kho, mahānāma, ariyasāvakassa ‘appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ hoti, so ca aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṁ adhigacchati aññaṁ vā tato santataraṁ; 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:4.4@But when they do achieve that rapture and bliss, or something more peaceful than that, 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:5.2@‘appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ hoti, 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:5.2@‘Sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’ 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:5.5@Yato ca kho me, mahānāma, ‘appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ ahosi, so ca aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṁ ajjhagamaṁ, aññaṁ vā tato santataraṁ; 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:5.5@But when I did achieve that rapture and bliss, or something more peaceful than that,

dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:7.5@This is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in this very life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.

dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:14.3@This is a drawback of sensual pleasures to do with lives to come, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures. 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:15.2@Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā nigaṇṭhā isigilipasse kāḷasilāyaṁ ubbhaṭṭhakā honti āsanapaṭikkhittā, opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti. 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:15.2@Now at that time several Jain ascetics on the slopes of Isigili at the Black Rock were constantly standing, refusing seats. And they felt painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion. 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:16.2@‘kiṁ nu tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, ubbhaṭṭhakā āsanapaṭikkhittā, opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayathā’ti? 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:16.2@‘Reverends, why are you constantly standing, refusing seats, so that you suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?’ 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:17.8@āyatiṁ anavassavā kammakkhayo, kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo, dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo, vedanākkhayā sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatī”ti. 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:17.8@With no future consequence, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.” 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:18.12@ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ, ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjīretabbaṁ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatī’ti? 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:18.12@that so much suffering has already been worn away? Or that so much suffering still remains to be worn away? Or that when so much suffering is worn away all suffering will have been worn away?’ 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:19.5@ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ, ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjīretabbaṁ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatīti. 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:19.5@
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:20.1@‘Na kho, āvuso gotama, sukhena sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ, dukkhena kho sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ; 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:20.1@‘Reverend Gotama, pleasure is not gained through pleasure; pleasure is gained through pain. 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:20.4@“na kho, āvuso gotama, sukhena sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ, dukkhena kho sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ; 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:20.4@
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:20.8@Addhāvuso gotama, amhehi sahasā appaṭisaṅkhā vācā bhāsitā, na kho, āvuso gotama, sukhena sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ, dukkhena kho sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ; 
dhamma@mn14@3@mn14:20.8@‘Clearly we spoke rashly and without reflection. 
dhamma@mn14@1@mn14:21.24@Cūḷadukkhakkhandhasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ catutthaṁ.
dhamma@mn19@1@mn19:17.1@Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ. 
dhamma@mn19@3@mn19:17.1@With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn19@1@mn19:22.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ. 
dhamma@mn19@3@mn19:22.2@I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.' 
dhamma@mn20@1@mn20:4.2@‘itipime vitakkā akusalā, itipime vitakkā sāvajjā, itipime vitakkā dukkhavipākā’ti. 
dhamma@mn20@3@mn20:4.2@‘So these thoughts are unskillful, they’re blameworthy, and they result in suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn20@1@mn20:4.7@‘itipime vitakkā akusalā, itipime vitakkā sāvajjā, itipime vitakkā dukkhavipākā’ti. 
dhamma@mn20@3@mn20:4.7@
dhamma@mn20@1@mn20:8.13@Acchecchi taṇhaṁ, vivattayi saṁyojanaṁ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā”ti. 
dhamma@mn20@3@mn20:8.13@They’ve cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit have made an end of suffering.” 
dhamma@mn20@1@mn20:9.2@Mahācūḷadukkhakkhandhaanumānikasuttaṁ; 
dhamma@mn20@3@mn20:9.2@
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:3.8@Appassādā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:3.8@The Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:3.18@sappasirūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo”ti. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:3.18@a snake’s head, the Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.” 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:3.35@Appassādā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:3.35@
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:3.37@sappasirūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:3.37@
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:6.3@Appassādā kāmā vuttā mayā, bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:6.3@I’ve said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:6.13@sappasirūpamā kāmā vuttā mayā, bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:6.13@a snake’s head, I’ve said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:6.15@Tañhi te, moghapurisa, bhavissati dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:6.15@This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.” 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:8.6@Appassādā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:8.6@The Buddha has said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:8.8@sappasirūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo”ti. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:8.8@a snake’s head, the Buddha has said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.” 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:8.11@Appassādā kāmā vuttā mayā, bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:8.11@
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:8.13@sappasirūpamā kāmā vuttā mayā, bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:8.13@I’ve said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:8.15@Tañhi tassa moghapurisassa bhavissati dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:8.15@This will be for his lasting harm and suffering. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:10.7@Tesaṁ te dhammā duggahitā dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya saṁvattanti. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:10.7@Because they’re wrongly grasped, those teachings lead to their lasting harm and suffering. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:10.14@So tatonidānaṁ maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:10.14@resulting in death or deadly pain. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:10.23@Tesaṁ te dhammā duggahitā dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya saṁvattanti. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:10.23@and those teachings lead to their lasting harm and suffering. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:11.14@Kiñcāpi so, bhikkhave, alagaddo tassa purisassa hatthaṁ vā bāhaṁ vā aññataraṁ vā aṅgapaccaṅgaṁ bhogehi paliveṭheyya, atha kho so neva tatonidānaṁ maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:11.14@And even though that cobra might wrap its coils around that person’s hand or arm or some other limb, that wouldn’t result in death or deadly pain. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:23.1@Taṁ, bhikkhave, attavādupādānaṁ upādiyetha, yaṁsa attavādupādānaṁ upādiyato na uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:23.1@It would make sense to grasp at a doctrine of self that didn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:23.2@Passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, taṁ attavādupādānaṁ yaṁsa attavādupādānaṁ upādiyato na uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti? 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:23.2@But do you see any such doctrine of self?” 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:23.5@Ahampi kho taṁ, bhikkhave, attavādupādānaṁ na samanupassāmi yaṁsa attavādupādānaṁ upādiyato na uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:23.5@I also can’t see any such doctrine of self. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:24.1@Taṁ, bhikkhave, diṭṭhinissayaṁ nissayetha yaṁsa diṭṭhinissayaṁ nissayato na uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:24.1@It would make sense to rely on a view that didn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:24.2@Passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, taṁ diṭṭhinissayaṁ yaṁsa diṭṭhinissayaṁ nissayato na uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti? 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:24.2@But do you see any such view to rely on?” 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:24.5@Ahampi kho taṁ, bhikkhave, diṭṭhinissayaṁ na samanupassāmi yaṁsa diṭṭhinissayaṁ nissayato na uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:24.5@I also can’t see any such view to rely on. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:26.4@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti? 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:26.4@“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?” 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:26.5@“Dukkhaṁ, bhante”. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:26.5@“Suffering, sir.” 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:26.6@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ—
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:26.6@“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:26.15@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti? 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:26.15@“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?” 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:26.16@“Dukkhaṁ, bhante”. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:26.16@“Suffering, sir.” 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:26.17@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ—
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:26.17@“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:37.5@Pubbe cāhaṁ, bhikkhave, etarahi ca dukkhañceva paññāpemi, dukkhassa ca nirodhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:37.5@In the past, as today, what I describe is suffering and the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@mn22@1@mn22:44.2@Evaṁ svākkhāte, bhikkhave, mayā dhamme uttāne vivaṭe pakāsite chinnapilotike yesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ tīṇi saṁyojanāni pahīnāni, rāgadosamohā tanubhūtā, sabbe te sakadāgāmino, sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti. 
dhamma@mn22@3@mn22:44.2@In this teaching there are mendicants who, having given up three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion, are once-returners. All of them come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. … 
dhamma@mn25@1@mn25:15.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn25@3@mn25:15.1@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn26@1@mn26:37.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn26@3@mn26:37.1@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn27@1@mn27:22.1@Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn27@3@mn27:22.1@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn27@1@mn27:25.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn27@3@mn27:25.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn28@1@mn28:2.4@Dukkhe ariyasacce, dukkhasamudaye ariyasacce, dukkhanirodhe ariyasacce, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasacce. 
dhamma@mn28@3@mn28:2.4@The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@mn28@1@mn28:3.1@Katamañcāvuso, dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ? 
dhamma@mn28@3@mn28:3.1@And what is the noble truth of suffering? 
dhamma@mn28@1@mn28:3.2@Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, maraṇampi dukkhaṁ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ; saṅkhittena, pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā. 
dhamma@mn28@3@mn28:3.2@Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering. 
dhamma@mn28@1@mn28:8.2@‘uppannā kho me ayaṁ sotasamphassajā dukkhavedanā. 
dhamma@mn28@3@mn28:8.2@‘This painful feeling born of ear contact has arisen in me. 
dhamma@mn28@1@mn28:23.2@So evaṁ pajānāti, uppannā kho me ayaṁ sotasamphassajā dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn28@3@mn28:23.2@‘This painful feeling born of ear contact has arisen in me. 
dhamma@mn28@1@mn28:28.8@Yo imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu chando ālayo anunayo ajjhosānaṁ so dukkhasamudayo. 
dhamma@mn28@3@mn28:28.8@The desire, clinging, attraction, and attachment for these five grasping aggregates is the origin of suffering. 
dhamma@mn28@1@mn28:28.9@Yo imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṁ, so dukkhanirodho’ti. 
dhamma@mn28@3@mn28:28.9@Giving up and getting rid of desire and greed for these five grasping aggregates is the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn28@1@mn28:38.10@Yo imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu chando ālayo anunayo ajjhosānaṁ so dukkhasamudayo. 
dhamma@mn28@3@mn28:38.10@The desire, clinging, attraction, and attachment for these five grasping aggregates is the origin of suffering. 
dhamma@mn28@1@mn28:38.11@Yo imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṁ so dukkhanirodho’ti. 
dhamma@mn28@3@mn28:38.11@Giving up and getting rid of desire and greed for these five grasping aggregates is the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn29@1@mn29:2.2@‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto, 
dhamma@mn29@3@mn29:2.2@‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. 
dhamma@mn29@1@mn29:2.3@appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti. 
dhamma@mn29@3@mn29:2.3@Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn29@1@mn29:2.8@So tena lābhasakkārasilokena majjati pamajjati pamādaṁ āpajjati, pamatto samāno dukkhaṁ viharati. 
dhamma@mn29@3@mn29:2.8@And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity. And being negligent they live in suffering.

dhamma@mn30@1@mn30:16.1@Puna caparaṁ, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn30@3@mn30:16.1@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn31@1@mn31:15.4@Idha mayaṁ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāma. 
dhamma@mn31@3@mn31:15.4@Whenever we want, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, we enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn34@1@mn34:3.4@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā akusalā imassa lokassa akusalā parassa lokassa, akusalā māradheyyassa akusalā amāradheyyassa, akusalā maccudheyyassa akusalā amaccudheyyassa, tesaṁ ye sotabbaṁ saddahātabbaṁ maññissanti, tesaṁ taṁ bhavissati dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya. 
dhamma@mn34@3@mn34:3.4@In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who are unskilled in this world and the other world, unskilled in Māra’s domain and its opposite, and unskilled in Death’s domain and its opposite. If anyone thinks they are worth listening to and trusting, it will be for their lasting harm and suffering. 
dhamma@mn34@1@mn34:8.2@evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye te bhikkhū tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti, tepi tiriyaṁ mārassa sotaṁ chetvā sotthinā pāraṁ gamissanti. 
dhamma@mn34@3@mn34:8.2@are the mendicants who, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, are once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore. 
dhamma@mn35@1@mn35:20.7@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti? 
dhamma@mn35@3@mn35:20.7@“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?” 
dhamma@mn35@1@mn35:20.8@“Dukkhaṁ, bho gotama”. 
dhamma@mn35@3@mn35:20.8@“Suffering.” 
dhamma@mn35@1@mn35:20.9@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ: 
dhamma@mn35@3@mn35:20.9@“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: 
dhamma@mn35@1@mn35:20.18@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti? 
dhamma@mn35@3@mn35:20.18@“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?” 
dhamma@mn35@1@mn35:20.19@“Dukkhaṁ, bho gotama”. 
dhamma@mn35@3@mn35:20.19@“Suffering.” 
dhamma@mn35@1@mn35:20.20@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ: 
dhamma@mn35@3@mn35:20.20@“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: 
dhamma@mn35@1@mn35:21.2@yo nu kho dukkhaṁ allīno dukkhaṁ upagato dukkhaṁ ajjhosito, dukkhaṁ ‘etaṁ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati, api nu kho so sāmaṁ vā dukkhaṁ parijāneyya, dukkhaṁ vā parikkhepetvā vihareyyā”ti? 
dhamma@mn35@3@mn35:21.2@Consider someone who clings, holds, and attaches to suffering, regarding it thus: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’ Would such a person be able to completely understand suffering themselves, or live having wiped out suffering?” 
dhamma@mn35@1@mn35:21.6@nanu tvaṁ evaṁ sante dukkhaṁ allīno dukkhaṁ upagato dukkhaṁ ajjhosito, dukkhaṁ: 
dhamma@mn35@3@mn35:21.6@This being so, aren’t you someone who clings, holds, and attaches to suffering, regarding it thus: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?” 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:4.2@Phusanti hi te, bho gotama, sārīrikaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:4.2@They suffer painful physical feelings. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:4.3@Bhūtapubbaṁ, bho gotama, sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭhassa sato ūrukkhambhopi nāma bhavissati, hadayampi nāma phalissati, uṇhampi lohitaṁ mukhato uggamissati, ummādampi pāpuṇissati cittakkhepaṁ. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:4.3@This happened to someone once. Their thighs became paralyzed, their heart burst, hot blood gushed from their mouth, and they went mad and lost their mind. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:4.8@Phusanti hi te, bho gotama, cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:4.8@They suffer painful mental feelings. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:4.9@Bhūtapubbaṁ, bho gotama, cetasikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭhassa sato ūrukkhambhopi nāma bhavissati, hadayampi nāma phalissati, uṇhampi lohitaṁ mukhato uggamissati, ummādampi pāpuṇissati cittakkhepaṁ. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:4.9@This happened to someone once. Their thighs became paralyzed, their heart burst, hot blood gushed from their mouth, and they went mad and lost their mind. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:8.5@Sukhāya vedanāya nirodhā uppajjati dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:8.5@And when it ceases, a painful feeling arises. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:8.6@So dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:8.6@When they suffer painful feeling, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:8.7@Tassa kho esā, aggivessana, uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā cittassa. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:8.7@Because their physical endurance is undeveloped, pleasant feelings occupy the mind. And because their mind is undeveloped, painful feelings occupy the mind. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:8.8@Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, evaṁ ubhatopakkhaṁ uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā cittassa, evaṁ kho, aggivessana, abhāvitakāyo ca hoti abhāvitacitto ca. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:8.8@Anyone whose mind is occupied by both pleasant and painful feelings like this is undeveloped both in physical endurance and in mind. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:9.5@Sukhāya vedanāya nirodhā uppajjati dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:9.5@And when it ceases, painful feeling arises. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:9.6@So dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati na kilamati na paridevati na urattāḷiṁ kandati na sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:9.6@When they suffer painful feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:9.7@Tassa kho esā, aggivessana, uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati bhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati bhāvitattā cittassa. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:9.7@Because their physical endurance is developed, pleasant feelings don’t occupy the mind. And because their mind is developed, painful feelings don’t occupy the mind. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:9.8@Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, evaṁ ubhatopakkhaṁ uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati bhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati bhāvitattā cittassa. Evaṁ kho, aggivessana, bhāvitakāyo ca hoti bhāvitacitto cā”ti. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:9.8@Anyone whose mind is not occupied by both pleasant and painful feelings like this is developed both in physical endurance and in mind.” 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:10.5@Yato kho ahaṁ, aggivessana, kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito, taṁ vata me uppannā vā sukhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassati, uppannā vā dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī”ti. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:10.5@Ever since I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness, it has not been possible for any pleasant or painful feeling to occupy my mind.” 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:11.1@“Na hi nūna bhoto gotamassa uppajjati tathārūpā sukhā vedanā yathārūpā uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭheyya; na hi nūna bhoto gotamassa uppajjati tathārūpā dukkhā vedanā yathārūpā uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭheyyā”ti. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:11.1@“Master Gotama mustn’t have experienced the kind of pleasant or painful feelings that would occupy the mind.” 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:17.11@“Evameva kho, aggivessana, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi avūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṁ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho, so ca ajjhattaṁ na suppahīno hoti, na suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:17.11@“In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. They haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:17.12@No cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:17.12@
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:18.11@“Evameva kho, aggivessana, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi vūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṁ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho so ca ajjhattaṁ na suppahīno hoti, na suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. No cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:18.11@“In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. But they haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:19.10@“Evameva kho, aggivessana, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi vūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṁ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho, so ca ajjhattaṁ suppahīno hoti suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, bhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. No cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, bhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:19.10@“In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. And they have internally given up and stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are capable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:20.7@Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:20.7@My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:20.8@Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:20.8@But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:21.7@Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā. Sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:21.7@My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:21.8@Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:21.8@But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:23.8@But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.
