dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:25.7@My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:25.8@Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṁ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:25.8@But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:30.2@‘ye kho keci atītamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayiṁsu, etāvaparamaṁ, nayito bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:30.2@‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:30.3@Yepi hi keci anāgatamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayissanti, etāvaparamaṁ, nayito bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:30.3@
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:30.4@Yepi hi keci etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, etāvaparamaṁ, nayito bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:30.4@
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:35-37.5@Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:35-37.5@With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:42.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:42.2@I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:47.1@“Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā appahīnā, tamahaṁ ‘sammūḷho’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:47.1@“Anyone who has not given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death is deluded, I say. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:47.3@Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā pahīnā, tamahaṁ ‘asammūḷho’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:47.3@Anyone who has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death—is not deluded, I say. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:47.5@Tathāgatassa kho, aggivessana, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:47.5@The Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future. 
dhamma@mn36@1@mn36:47.7@evameva kho, aggivessana, tathāgatassa ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā”ti. 
dhamma@mn36@3@mn36:47.7@in the same way, the Realized One has given up the defilements so they are unable to arise in the future.” 
dhamma@mn37@1@mn37:3.6@sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, so tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati. 
dhamma@mn37@3@mn37:3.6@they meditate observing impermanence, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in those feelings. 
dhamma@mn37@1@mn37:13.6@So sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhijānāti, sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhiññāya sabbaṁ dhammaṁ parijānāti, sabbaṁ dhammaṁ pariññāya yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā. 
dhamma@mn37@3@mn37:13.6@they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Having completely understood all things, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—
dhamma@mn37@1@mn37:15.10@So sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhijānāti, sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhiññāya sabbaṁ dhammaṁ parijānāti, sabbaṁ dhammaṁ pariññāya yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā. 
dhamma@mn37@3@mn37:15.10@
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:5.15@Tañhi te, moghapurisa, bhavissati dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:5.15@This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.” 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:7.9@Tañhi tassa moghapurisassa bhavissati dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:7.9@This will be for his lasting harm and suffering. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:17.11@jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:17.11@Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:17.12@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:17.12@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:19.14@jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:19.14@Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:19.15@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:19.15@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:20.11@jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:20.11@When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:20.12@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:20.12@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:22.14@jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:22.14@When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:22.15@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:22.15@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:30.3@So evaṁ anurodhavirodhaṁ samāpanno yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, so taṁ vedanaṁ abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:30.3@Being so full of favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:30.5@Yā vedanāsu nandī tadupādānaṁ, tassupādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:30.5@Relishing feelings is grasping. Their grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:30.6@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:30.6@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:30.13@So evaṁ anurodhavirodhaṁ samāpanno yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, so taṁ vedanaṁ abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:30.13@Being so full of favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:30.15@Yā vedanāsu nandī tadupādānaṁ, tassupādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:30.15@Relishing feelings is grasping. Their grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:30.16@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:30.16@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:40.3@So evaṁ anurodhavirodhavippahīno yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti, sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, so taṁ vedanaṁ nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:40.3@Having given up favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to it. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:40.5@Tassa nandīnirodhā upādānanirodho, upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:40.5@When their relishing ceases, grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:40.6@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:40.6@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:41.7@So evaṁ anurodhavirodhavippahīno yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti, sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, so taṁ vedanaṁ nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:41.7@Having given up favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to it. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:41.9@Tassa nandīnirodhā upādānanirodho, upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:41.9@When their relishing ceases, grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. 
dhamma@mn38@1@mn38:41.10@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti. 
dhamma@mn38@3@mn38:41.10@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases. 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:14.8@Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso ābādhiko assa dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, bhattañcassa nacchādeyya, na cassa kāye balamattā. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:14.8@Suppose a person was sick, suffering, and gravely ill. They’d lose their appetite and get physically weak. 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:14.11@‘ahaṁ kho pubbe ābādhiko ahosiṁ dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, bhattañca me nacchādesi, na ca me āsi kāye balamattā, somhi etarahi tamhā ābādhā mutto, bhattañca me chādeti, atthi ca me kāye balamattā’ti. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:14.11@
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:18.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:18.1@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:21.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:21.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:21.11@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti …pe… 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:21.11@In the same way, a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:23.2@Samitāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:23.2@They have assuaged the bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:24.2@Bāhitāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:24.2@They have banished the bad, unskillful qualities. 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:25.2@Nhātāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:25.2@They have bathed off the bad, unskillful qualities. 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:26.2@Viditāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:26.2@They have known the bad, unskillful qualities. 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:27.2@Nissutāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:27.2@They have scoured off the bad, unskillful qualities. 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:28.2@Ārakāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:28.2@They have nobbled their foes, the bad, unskillful qualities. 
dhamma@mn39@1@mn39:29.2@Ārakāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@mn39@3@mn39:29.2@They are impeccably remote from the bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@mn43@1@mn43:2.5@‘Idaṁ dukkhan’ti nappajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti nappajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti nappajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti nappajānāti. 
dhamma@mn43@3@mn43:2.5@They don’t understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn43@1@mn43:3.5@‘Idaṁ dukkhan’ti pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn43@3@mn43:3.5@They understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn43@1@mn43:4.5@Sukhantipi vijānāti, dukkhantipi vijānāti, adukkhamasukhantipi vijānāti. 
dhamma@mn43@3@mn43:4.5@It cognizes ‘pleasure’ and ‘pain’ and ‘neutral’. 
dhamma@mn43@1@mn43:7.5@Sukhampi vedeti, dukkhampi vedeti, adukkhamasukhampi vedeti. 
dhamma@mn43@3@mn43:7.5@It feels pleasure, pain, and neutral. 
dhamma@mn43@1@mn43:26.1@“Kati panāvuso, paccayā adukkhamasukhāya cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā”ti? 
dhamma@mn43@3@mn43:26.1@“How many conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart?” 
dhamma@mn43@1@mn43:26.2@“Cattāro kho, āvuso, paccayā adukkhamasukhāya cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā. 
dhamma@mn43@3@mn43:26.2@“Four conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart. 
dhamma@mn43@1@mn43:26.3@Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn43@3@mn43:26.3@Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn43@1@mn43:26.4@Ime kho, āvuso, cattāro paccayā adukkhamasukhāya cetovimuttiyā samāpattiyā”ti. 
dhamma@mn43@3@mn43:26.4@These four conditions are necessary to attain the neutral release of the heart.” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:22.3@sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā”ti. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:22.3@pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling.” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:23.1@“Katamā panāyye, sukhā vedanā, katamā dukkhā vedanā, katamā adukkhamasukhā vedanā”ti? 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:23.1@“What are these three feelings?” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:23.4@Yaṁ kho, āvuso visākha, kāyikaṁ vā cetasikaṁ vā dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ—
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:23.4@Anything felt physically or mentally as painful or unpleasant. 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:23.5@ayaṁ dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:23.5@This is painful feeling. 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:23.7@ayaṁ adukkhamasukhā vedanā”ti. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:23.7@This is neutral feeling.” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:24.1@“Sukhā panāyye, vedanā kiṁsukhā kiṁdukkhā, dukkhā vedanā kiṁsukhā kiṁdukkhā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā kiṁsukhā kiṁdukkhā”ti? 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:24.1@“What is pleasant and what is painful regarding each of the three feelings?” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:24.2@“Sukhā kho, āvuso visākha, vedanā ṭhitisukhā vipariṇāmadukkhā; 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:24.2@“Pleasant feeling is pleasant when it remains and painful when it perishes. 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:24.3@dukkhā vedanā ṭhitidukkhā vipariṇāmasukhā; 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:24.3@Painful feeling is painful when it remains and pleasant when it perishes. 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:24.4@adukkhamasukhā vedanā ñāṇasukhā aññāṇadukkhā”ti. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:24.4@Neutral feeling is pleasant in the presence of knowledge, and painful in the presence of ignorance.” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:25.1@“Sukhāya panāyye, vedanāya kiṁ anusayo anuseti, dukkhāya vedanāya kiṁ anusayo anuseti, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya kiṁ anusayo anusetī”ti? 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:25.1@“What underlying tendencies underlie each of the three feelings?” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:25.2@“Sukhāya kho, āvuso visākha, vedanāya rāgānusayo anuseti, dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo anuseti, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo anusetī”ti. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:25.2@“The underlying tendency for greed underlies pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency for repulsion underlies painful feeling. The underlying tendency for ignorance underlies neutral feeling.” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:26.1@“Sabbāya nu kho, ayye, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayo anuseti, sabbāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo anuseti, sabbāya adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo anusetī”ti? 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:26.1@“Do these underlying tendencies always underlie these feelings?” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:26.2@“Na kho, āvuso visākha, sabbāya sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayo anuseti, na sabbāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo anuseti, na sabbāya adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo anusetī”ti. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:26.2@“No, they do not.” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:27.1@“Sukhāya panāyye, vedanāya kiṁ pahātabbaṁ, dukkhāya vedanāya kiṁ pahātabbaṁ, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya kiṁ pahātabban”ti? 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:27.1@“What should be given up in regard to each of these three feelings?” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:27.2@“Sukhāya kho, āvuso visākha, vedanāya rāgānusayo pahātabbo, dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo pahātabbo, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo pahātabbo”ti. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:27.2@“The underlying tendency to greed should be given up when it comes to pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency to repulsion should be given up when it comes to painful feeling. The underlying tendency to ignorance should be given up when it comes to neutral feeling.” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:28.1@“Sabbāya nu kho, ayye, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayo pahātabbo, sabbāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo pahātabbo, sabbāya adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo pahātabbo”ti? 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:28.1@“Should these underlying tendencies be given up regarding all instances of these feelings?” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:28.2@“Na kho, āvuso visākha, sabbāya sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayo pahātabbo, na sabbāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo pahātabbo, na sabbāya adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo pahātabbo. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:28.2@“No, not in all instances. 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:28.9@Idhāvuso visākha, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā, dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:28.9@Take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:29.2@“Sukhāya kho, āvuso visākha, vedanāya dukkhā vedanā paṭibhāgo”ti. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:29.2@“Painful feeling.” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:29.3@“Dukkhāya pannāyye, vedanāya kiṁ paṭibhāgo”ti? 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:29.3@“What is the counterpart of painful feeling?” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:29.4@“Dukkhāya kho, āvuso visākha, vedanāya sukhā vedanā paṭibhāgo”ti. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:29.4@“Pleasant feeling.” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:29.5@“Adukkhamasukhāya panāyye, vedanāya kiṁ paṭibhāgo”ti? 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:29.5@“What is the counterpart of neutral feeling?” 
dhamma@mn44@1@mn44:29.6@“Adukkhamasukhāya kho, āvuso visākha, vedanāya avijjā paṭibhāgo”ti. 
dhamma@mn44@3@mn44:29.6@“Ignorance.” 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:2.3@Atthi, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhaṁ āyatiṁ dukkhavipākaṁ; 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:2.3@There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain. 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:2.4@atthi, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ; 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:2.4@There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain. 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:2.5@atthi, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ; 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:2.5@There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure. 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:3.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhaṁ āyatiṁ dukkhavipākaṁ? 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:3.1@And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain? 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:3.10@Te tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti. 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:3.10@And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings. 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:3.12@‘idaṁ kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kāmesu anāgatabhayaṁ sampassamānā kāmānaṁ pahānamāhaṁsu, kāmānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapenti, ime hi mayaṁ kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayāmā’ti. 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:3.12@‘This is that future danger that those ascetics and brahmins saw. For it is because of sensual pleasures that I’m feeling painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings.’ 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:4.21@Yañcāhaṁ māluvābījahetu dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayāmī’ti. 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:4.21@It’s because of that camel’s foot creeper seed that I’m feeling painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings.’ 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:4.30@Te tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti. 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:4.30@
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:4.33@Ime hi mayaṁ kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayāmā’ti. 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:4.33@
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:4.34@Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhaṁ āyatiṁ dukkhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:4.34@This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain. 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:5.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ? 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:5.1@And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain? 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:5.16@Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:5.16@This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain. 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:6.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ? 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:6.1@And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure? 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:6.2@Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pakatiyā tibbarāgajātiko hoti, so abhikkhaṇaṁ rāgajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:6.2@It’s when someone is ordinarily full of acute greed, hate, and delusion. They often feel the pain and sadness that greed, hate, and delusion bring. 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:6.3@pakatiyā tibbadosajātiko hoti, so abhikkhaṇaṁ dosajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:6.3@
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:6.4@pakatiyā tibbamohajātiko hoti, so abhikkhaṇaṁ mohajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:6.4@
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:6.5@So sahāpi dukkhena, sahāpi domanassena, assumukhopi rudamāno paripuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carati. 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:6.5@They lead the full and pure spiritual life in pain and sadness, weeping, with tearful faces. 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:6.7@Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:6.7@This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure. 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:7.2@Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pakatiyā na tibbarāgajātiko hoti, so na abhikkhaṇaṁ rāgajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:7.2@It’s when someone is not ordinarily full of acute greed, hate, and delusion. They rarely feel the pain and sadness that greed, hate, and delusion bring. 
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:7.3@pakatiyā na tibbadosajātiko hoti, so na abhikkhaṇaṁ dosajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn45@3@mn45:7.3@
dhamma@mn45@1@mn45:7.4@pakatiyā na tibbamohajātiko hoti, so na abhikkhaṇaṁ mohajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.

dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:5.3@Atthi, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:5.3@There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:5.4@atthi, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhaṁ āyatiṁ dukkhavipākaṁ; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:5.4@There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:5.5@atthi, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:5.5@There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:6.1@Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ, taṁ avidvā avijjāgato yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti: 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:6.1@When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, an ignoramus, without knowing this, doesn’t truly understand: 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:6.2@‘idaṁ kho dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākan’ti. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:6.2@‘This is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.’

dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:7.1@When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pain, an ignoramus …

dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:10.1@When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, a wise person, knowing this, truly understands:

dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:11.1@When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pain, a wise person …

dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:12.1@When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pleasure, a wise person … 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:12.2@‘idaṁ kho dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākan’ti. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:12.2@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ? 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.1@And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain? 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.2@Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pāṇātipātī hoti, pāṇātipātapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.2@It’s when someone in pain and sadness kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view. Because of these things they experience pain and sadness. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.3@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena adinnādāyī hoti, adinnādānapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.3@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.4@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena kāmesu micchācārī hoti, kāmesu micchācārapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.4@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.5@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena musāvādī hoti, musāvādapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.5@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.6@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pisuṇavāco hoti, pisuṇavācāpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.6@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.7@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pharusavāco hoti, pharusavācāpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.7@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.8@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena samphappalāpī hoti, samphappalāpapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.8@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.9@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena abhijjhālu hoti, abhijjhāpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.9@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.10@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena byāpannacitto hoti, byāpādapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.10@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.11@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena micchādiṭṭhi hoti, micchādiṭṭhipaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.11@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:14.13@Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:14.13@This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:15.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhaṁ āyatiṁ dukkhavipākaṁ? 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:15.1@And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain? 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:15.13@Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhaṁ āyatiṁ dukkhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:15.13@This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ? 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.1@And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure? 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.2@Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, pāṇātipātā veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.2@It’s when someone in pain and sadness doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view. Because of these things they experience pain and sadness. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.3@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.3@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.4@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.4@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.5@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.5@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.6@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.6@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.7@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.7@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.8@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā veramaṇīpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.8@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.9@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena anabhijjhālu hoti, anabhijjhāpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.9@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.10@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena abyāpannacitto hoti, abyāpādapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti; 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.10@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.11@sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena sammādiṭṭhi hoti, sammādiṭṭhipaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.11@
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:16.13@Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:16.13@This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:18.2@Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:18.2@Then a man would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:18.6@Tassa te pivato ceva nacchādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana maraṇaṁ vā nigacchasi maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan’ti. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:18.6@If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be unappetizing, and it will result in death or deadly pain.’ 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:18.8@Tassa taṁ pivato ceva nacchādeyya vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:18.8@The color, aroma, and flavor would be unappetizing, and it would result in death or deadly pain. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:18.9@Tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ vadāmi, yamidaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:18.9@This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, I say. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:19.3@Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:19.3@Then a man would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:19.8@Tassa te pivatohi kho chādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana maraṇaṁ vā nigacchasi maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan’ti. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:19.8@If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be appetizing, but it will result in death or deadly pain.’ 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:19.10@Tassa taṁ pivatohi kho chādeyya vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:19.10@The color, aroma, and flavor would be appetizing, but it would result in death or deadly pain. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:19.11@Tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ vadāmi, yamidaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhaṁ āyatiṁ dukkhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:19.11@This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pain, I say. 
dhamma@mn46@1@mn46:20.8@Tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ vadāmi, yamidaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ. 
dhamma@mn46@3@mn46:20.8@This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pleasure, I say. 
dhamma@mn48@1@mn48:5.6@Tañhi tumhākaṁ, moghapurisā, bhavissati dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti. 
dhamma@mn48@3@mn48:5.6@This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.” 
dhamma@mn48@1@mn48:6.14@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca. 
dhamma@mn48@3@mn48:6.14@Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@mn48@1@mn48:7.1@Imesaṁ kho, bhikkhave, channaṁ sāraṇīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ etaṁ aggaṁ etaṁ saṅgāhikaṁ etaṁ saṅghāṭanikaṁ—yadidaṁ yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@mn48@3@mn48:7.1@Of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. It holds and binds everything together. 
dhamma@mn48@1@mn48:7.3@evameva kho, bhikkhave, imesaṁ channaṁ sāraṇīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ etaṁ aggaṁ etaṁ saṅgāhikaṁ etaṁ saṅghāṭanikaṁ yadidaṁ yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@mn48@3@mn48:7.3@In the same way, of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. It holds and binds everything together. 
dhamma@mn48@1@mn48:8.1@Kathañca, bhikkhave, yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya? 
dhamma@mn48@3@mn48:8.1@And how does the view that is noble and emancipating lead one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering? 
dhamma@mn49@1@mn49:30.14@Tathāgatassa, pāpima, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā—
dhamma@mn49@3@mn49:30.14@Because the Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@mn49@1@mn49:30.17@evameva kho, pāpima, tathāgatassa ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā—
dhamma@mn49@3@mn49:30.17@the Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@mn50@1@mn50:3.7@Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti. 
dhamma@mn50@3@mn50:3.7@Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”

dhamma@mn51@1@mn51:4.3@Yāva supaññattā cime, bhante, bhagavatā cattāro satipaṭṭhānā sattānaṁ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṁ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya. 
dhamma@mn51@3@mn51:4.3@How well described by the Buddha are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation! They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment. 
dhamma@mn51@1@mn51:6.2@“Yvāyaṁ, bhante, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānaṁ sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti—
dhamma@mn51@3@mn51:6.2@“Sir, the person who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain. 
dhamma@mn51@1@mn51:6.4@Yopāyaṁ, bhante, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so paraṁ sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti—
dhamma@mn51@3@mn51:6.4@The person who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain. 
dhamma@mn51@1@mn51:6.6@Yopāyaṁ, bhante, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti—
dhamma@mn51@3@mn51:6.6@The person who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain. 
dhamma@mn51@1@mn51:6.9@so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ neva ātāpeti na paritāpeti—
dhamma@mn51@3@mn51:6.9@
dhamma@mn51@1@mn51:23.1@sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn51@3@mn51:23.1@Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn51@1@mn51:24.2@So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@mn51@3@mn51:24.2@They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@mn51@1@mn51:26.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. ‘Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn51@3@mn51:26.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@mn53@1@mn53:17.1@Paññavā hoti, udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato, ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@mn53@3@mn53:17.1@They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@mn53@1@mn53:18.5@sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn53@3@mn53:18.5@fourth absorption. 
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:15.10@‘aṭṭhikaṅkalūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti. 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:15.10@‘With the simile of a skeleton the Buddha said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’ 
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:16.4@sace so gijjho vā kaṅko vā kulalo vā taṁ maṁsapesiṁ na khippameva paṭinissajjeyya, so tatonidānaṁ maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan”ti? 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:16.4@If that vulture, crow, or hawk doesn’t quickly let go of that scrap of meat, wouldn’t that result in death or deadly suffering for them?” 
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:16.7@‘maṁsapesūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti. 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:16.7@
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:17.3@sace so puriso taṁ ādittaṁ tiṇukkaṁ na khippameva paṭinissajjeyya tassa sā ādittā tiṇukkā hatthaṁ vā daheyya bāhuṁ vā daheyya aññataraṁ vā aññataraṁ vā aṅgapaccaṅgaṁ daheyya, so tatonidānaṁ maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan”ti? 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:17.3@If that person doesn’t quickly let go of that blazing grass torch, wouldn’t they burn their hands or arm or other limb, resulting in death or deadly suffering for them?” 
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:17.6@‘tiṇukkūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti. 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:17.6@
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:18.2@Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhapaṭikkūlo. 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:18.2@Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain. 
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:18.8@“Viditañhi, bhante, tassa purisassa imañcāhaṁ aṅgārakāsuṁ papatissāmi, tatonidānaṁ maraṇaṁ vā nigacchissāmi maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan”ti. 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:18.8@For that person knows: ‘If I fall in that pit of glowing coals, that’d result in my death or deadly pain.’” … 
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:18.10@‘aṅgārakāsūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti. 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:18.10@
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:19.4@‘supinakūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti …pe… 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:19.4@
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:20.11@‘yācitakūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti …pe… 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:20.11@
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:21.18@amuko yo so puriso paṭhamaṁ rukkhaṁ ārūḷho sace so na khippameva oroheyya tassa so rukkho papatanto hatthaṁ vā bhañjeyya pādaṁ vā bhañjeyya aññataraṁ vā aññataraṁ vā aṅgapaccaṅgaṁ bhañjeyya, so tatonidānaṁ maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan”ti? 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:21.18@If the first person, who climbed the tree, doesn’t quickly come down, when that tree fell wouldn’t they break their hand or arm or other limb, resulting in death or deadly suffering for them?” 
dhamma@mn54@1@mn54:21.21@‘rukkhaphalūpamā kāmā vuttā bhagavatā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti. 
dhamma@mn54@3@mn54:21.21@‘With the simile of the fruit tree the Buddha said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’ 
dhamma@mn55@1@mn55:12.4@Yampi so pāṇo galappaveṭhakena ānīyamāno dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti, iminā dutiyena ṭhānena bahuṁ apuññaṁ pasavati. 
dhamma@mn55@3@mn55:12.4@When that living creature experiences pain and sadness as it’s led along by a collar, this is the second reason. 
dhamma@mn55@1@mn55:12.7@Yampi so pāṇo ārabhiyamāno dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti, iminā catutthena ṭhānena bahuṁ apuññaṁ pasavati. 
dhamma@mn55@3@mn55:12.7@When that living creature experiences pain and sadness as it’s being slaughtered, this is the fourth reason. 
dhamma@mn56@1@mn56:11.2@idhassa nigaṇṭho ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno sītodakapaṭikkhitto uṇhodakapaṭisevī. 
dhamma@mn56@3@mn56:11.2@Take a Jain ascetic who is sick, suffering, gravely ill. They reject cold water and use only hot water. 
dhamma@mn56@1@mn56:18.4@dukkhaṁ, samudayaṁ, nirodhaṁ, maggaṁ. 
dhamma@mn56@3@mn56:18.4@suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path. 
dhamma@mn57@1@mn57:8.5@So sabyābajjhehi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno sabyābajjhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti ekantadukkhaṁ, seyyathāpi sattā nerayikā. 
dhamma@mn57@3@mn57:8.5@Touched by hurtful contacts, they experience hurtful feelings that are exclusively painful—like the beings in hell. 
dhamma@mn57@1@mn57:10.5@So sabyābajjhehipi abyābajjhehipi phassehi phuṭṭho samāno sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi vedanaṁ vedeti vokiṇṇasukhadukkhaṁ, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā. 
dhamma@mn57@3@mn57:10.5@Touched by both hurtful and pleasing contacts, they experience both hurtful and pleasing feelings that are a mixture of pleasure and pain—like humans, some gods, and some beings in the underworld. 
dhamma@mn59@1@mn59:1.6@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@mn59@3@mn59:1.6@pleasant, painful, and neutral. 
dhamma@mn59@1@mn59:1.11@sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn59@3@mn59:1.11@pleasant and painful. 
dhamma@mn59@1@mn59:1.12@Yāyaṁ, bhante, adukkhamasukhā vedanā santasmiṁ esā paṇīte sukhe vuttā bhagavatā”ti. 
dhamma@mn59@3@mn59:1.12@The Buddha said that neutral feeling is included as a peaceful and subtle kind of pleasure.” 
dhamma@mn59@1@mn59:2.4@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@mn59@3@mn59:2.4@
dhamma@mn59@1@mn59:2.9@sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn59@3@mn59:2.9@
dhamma@mn59@1@mn59:2.10@Yāyaṁ, bhante, adukkhamasukhā vedanā santasmiṁ esā paṇīte sukhe vuttā bhagavatā”ti. 
dhamma@mn59@3@mn59:2.10@
dhamma@mn59@1@mn59:3.4@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@mn59@3@mn59:3.4@
dhamma@mn59@1@mn59:3.9@sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn59@3@mn59:3.9@
dhamma@mn59@1@mn59:3.10@Yāyaṁ, bhante, adukkhamasukhā vedanā santasmiṁ esā paṇīte sukhe vuttā bhagavatā”ti. 
dhamma@mn59@3@mn59:3.10@
dhamma@mn60@1@mn60:21.7@sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedentī’ti. 
dhamma@mn60@3@mn60:21.7@All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.’ 
dhamma@mn60@1@mn60:22.8@na sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedentī’ti. 
dhamma@mn60@3@mn60:22.8@It is not the case that all sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy, or that, molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.’ 
dhamma@mn60@1@mn60:23.6@Natthi balaṁ, natthi vīriyaṁ, natthi purisathāmo, natthi purisaparakkamo; sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedentī’ti 
dhamma@mn60@3@mn60:23.6@
dhamma@mn60@1@mn60:26.6@Atthi balaṁ, atthi vīriyaṁ, atthi purisathāmo, atthi purisaparakkamo; na sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedentī’ti 
dhamma@mn60@3@mn60:26.6@
dhamma@mn60@1@mn60:55.6@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti …pe… 
dhamma@mn60@3@mn60:55.6@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:9.3@akusalaṁ idaṁ kāyakammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti? 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:9.3@Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’ 
dhamma@mn61@4@mn61:9.3@dukkhudrayaṁ → dukkhudayaṁ (mr) 
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:9.6@akusalaṁ idaṁ kāyakammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti, evarūpaṁ te, rāhula, kāyena kammaṁ sasakkaṁ na karaṇīyaṁ. 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:9.6@It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ To the best of your ability, Rāhula, you should not do such a deed. 
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:10.3@akusalaṁ idaṁ kāyakammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti? 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:10.3@Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’ 
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:10.6@akusalaṁ idaṁ kāyakammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti, paṭisaṁhareyyāsi tvaṁ, rāhula, evarūpaṁ kāyakammaṁ. 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:10.6@It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should desist from such a deed. 
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:11.3@akusalaṁ idaṁ kāyakammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti? 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:11.3@Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’ 
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:11.6@akusalaṁ idaṁ kāyakammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti, evarūpaṁ te, rāhula, kāyakammaṁ satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu desetabbaṁ, vivaritabbaṁ, uttānīkātabbaṁ; 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:11.6@It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should confess, reveal, and clarify such a deed to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion. 
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:12.3@akusalaṁ idaṁ vacīkammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti? 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:12.3@
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:12.6@akusalaṁ idaṁ vacīkammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti, evarūpaṁ te, rāhula, vācāya kammaṁ sasakkaṁ na karaṇīyaṁ. 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:12.6@
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:13.3@akusalaṁ idaṁ vacīkammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti? 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:13.3@
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:13.6@akusalaṁ idaṁ vacīkammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti, paṭisaṁhareyyāsi tvaṁ, rāhula, evarūpaṁ vacīkammaṁ. 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:13.6@
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:14.3@akusalaṁ idaṁ vacīkammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti? 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:14.3@
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:14.6@akusalaṁ idaṁ vacīkammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti, evarūpaṁ te, rāhula, vacīkammaṁ satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu desetabbaṁ, vivaritabbaṁ, uttānīkattabbaṁ; 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:14.6@It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should confess, reveal, and clarify such a deed to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion. 
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:15.3@akusalaṁ idaṁ manokammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti? 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:15.3@
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:15.6@akusalaṁ idaṁ manokammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti, evarūpaṁ te, rāhula, manasā kammaṁ sasakkaṁ na karaṇīyaṁ. 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:15.6@
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:16.3@akusalaṁ idaṁ manokammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti? 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:16.3@
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:16.6@akusalaṁ idaṁ manokammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti, paṭisaṁhareyyāsi tvaṁ, rāhula, evarūpaṁ manokammaṁ. 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:16.6@
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:17.3@akusalaṁ idaṁ manokammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti? 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:17.3@
dhamma@mn61@1@mn61:17.6@akusalaṁ idaṁ manokammaṁ dukkhudrayaṁ dukkhavipākan’ti, evarūpaṁ pana te, rāhula, manokammaṁ aṭṭīyitabbaṁ harāyitabbaṁ jigucchitabbaṁ; 
dhamma@mn61@3@mn61:17.6@It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should be horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that deed. 
dhamma@mn63@1@mn63:6.3@‘Sassato loko’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘asassato loko’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti, atthi jarā, atthi maraṇaṁ, santi sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā; 
dhamma@mn63@3@mn63:6.3@When there is the view that the cosmos is eternal or that the cosmos is not eternal, there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@mn63@1@mn63:6.7@‘Antavā loko’ti vā, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhiyā sati, ‘anantavā loko’ti vā diṭṭhiyā sati attheva jāti, atthi jarā, atthi maraṇaṁ, santi sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā; 
dhamma@mn63@3@mn63:6.7@
dhamma@mn63@1@mn63:9.2@‘Idaṁ dukkhan’ti, mālukyaputta, mayā byākataṁ; 
dhamma@mn63@3@mn63:9.2@I have declared the following: ‘this is suffering,’ 
dhamma@mn63@1@mn63:9.3@‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti—
dhamma@mn63@3@mn63:9.3@‘this is the origin of suffering,’ 
dhamma@mn63@1@mn63:9.5@‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti—
dhamma@mn63@3@mn63:9.5@‘this is the cessation of suffering,’ 
dhamma@mn63@1@mn63:9.7@‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti—
dhamma@mn63@3@mn63:9.7@‘this is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn64@1@mn64:9.3@So yadeva tattha hoti rūpagataṁ vedanāgataṁ saññāgataṁ saṅkhāragataṁ viññāṇagataṁ te dhamme aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassati. 
dhamma@mn64@3@mn64:9.3@They contemplate the phenomena there—included in form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness—as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self. 
dhamma@mn65@1@mn65:17.7@Puna caparaṁ, bhaddāli, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn65@3@mn65:17.7@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn65@1@mn65:20.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti; 
dhamma@mn65@3@mn65:20.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@mn66@1@mn66:4.1@“bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā dukkhadhammānaṁ apahattā, bahūnaṁ vata no bhagavā sukhadhammānaṁ upahattā; 
dhamma@mn66@3@mn66:4.1@“The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!

dhamma@mn66@3@mn66:17.1@Take another person who, understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, 
dhamma@mn67@1@mn67:16.3@‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto; 
dhamma@mn67@3@mn67:16.3@‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. 
dhamma@mn67@1@mn67:16.4@appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti. 
dhamma@mn67@3@mn67:16.4@Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’

dhamma@mn68@1@mn68:5.5@Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto; 
dhamma@mn68@3@mn68:5.5@Rather, didn’t you go forth thinking: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. 
dhamma@mn68@1@mn68:5.6@appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti—
dhamma@mn68@3@mn68:5.6@Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering’?” 
dhamma@mn68@1@mn68:7.2@‘ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, appahīnā te tathāgatassa; 
dhamma@mn68@3@mn68:7.2@‘The Realized One has not given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@mn68@1@mn68:7.5@‘ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, appahīnā te tathāgatassa; 
dhamma@mn68@3@mn68:7.5@
dhamma@mn68@1@mn68:7.8@‘ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, pahīnā te tathāgatassa; 
dhamma@mn68@3@mn68:7.8@‘The Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@mn68@1@mn68:7.11@Tathāgatassa, anuruddhā, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, pahīnā te ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā. 
dhamma@mn68@3@mn68:7.11@The Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future. 
dhamma@mn68@1@mn68:7.13@evameva kho, anuruddhā, tathāgatassa ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, pahīnā te ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā; 
dhamma@mn68@3@mn68:7.13@in the same way, the Realized One has given up the defilements so they are unable to arise in the future. 
dhamma@mn68@1@mn68:12.4@tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmī sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissatī’ti. 
dhamma@mn68@3@mn68:12.4@with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, he’s a once-returner. He’ll come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.’

dhamma@mn70@1@mn70:6.18@“Kiṁ nu me tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṁ dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānātha yaṁ kiñcāyaṁ purisapuggalo paṭisaṁvedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tassa akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī”ti? 
dhamma@mn70@3@mn70:6.18@“Mendicants, have you ever known me to teach the Dhamma like this: no matter what this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—their unskillful qualities decline and their skillful qualities grow?” 
dhamma@mn70@1@mn70:7.1@“Nanu me tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṁ dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānātha idhekaccassa yaṁ evarūpaṁ sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, idha panekaccassa evarūpaṁ sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, idhekaccassa evarūpaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, idha panekaccassa evarūpaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, idhekaccassa evarūpaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, idha panekaccassa evarūpaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī”ti? 
dhamma@mn70@3@mn70:7.1@“Haven’t you known me to teach the Dhamma like this: ‘When someone feels this kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. When someone feels this kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. When someone feels this kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow’?” 
dhamma@mn70@1@mn70:8.15@‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evāhaṁ ajānanto ‘evarūpaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ pajahathā’ti vadeyyaṁ; 
dhamma@mn70@3@mn70:8.15@‘When someone feels this kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ 
dhamma@mn70@1@mn70:9.2@‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, tasmāhaṁ ‘evarūpaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ pajahathā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn70@3@mn70:9.2@‘When someone feels this kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should give up this kind of painful feeling.’ 
dhamma@mn70@1@mn70:9.4@‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, evāhaṁ ajānanto ‘evarūpaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ upasampajja viharathā’ti vadeyyaṁ; 
dhamma@mn70@3@mn70:9.4@‘When someone feels that kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’ 
dhamma@mn70@1@mn70:9.8@‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhantī’ti, tasmāhaṁ ‘evarūpaṁ dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ upasampajja viharathā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn70@3@mn70:9.8@‘When someone feels that kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’ Since this is so, that’s why I say: ‘You should enter and remain in that kind of painful feeling.’ 
dhamma@mn70@1@mn70:10.2@‘idhekaccassa evarūpaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti kusalā dhammā parihāyantī’ti, evāhaṁ ajānanto ‘evarūpaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ pajahathā’ti vadeyyaṁ; 
dhamma@mn70@3@mn70:10.2@‘When someone feels this kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.’

dhamma@mn70@3@mn70:10.8@‘When someone feels that kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.’

dhamma@mn71@1@mn71:11.2@“atthi nu kho, bho gotama, koci gihī gihisaṁyojanaṁ appahāya kāyassa bhedā dukkhassantakaro”ti? 
dhamma@mn71@3@mn71:11.2@“Master Gotama, are there any laypeople who, without giving up the fetter of lay life, make an end of suffering when the body breaks up?” 
dhamma@mn71@1@mn71:11.3@“Natthi kho, vaccha, koci gihī gihisaṁyojanaṁ appahāya kāyassa bhedā dukkhassantakaro”ti. 
dhamma@mn71@3@mn71:11.3@“No, Vaccha.” 
dhamma@mn71@1@mn71:13.1@“Atthi nu kho, bho gotama, koci ājīvako kāyassa bhedā dukkhassantakaro”ti? 
dhamma@mn71@3@mn71:13.1@“Master Gotama, are there any Ājīvaka ascetics who make an end of suffering when the body breaks up?” 
dhamma@mn71@1@mn71:13.2@“Natthi kho, vaccha, koci ājīvako kāyassa bhedā dukkhassantakaro”ti. 
dhamma@mn71@3@mn71:13.2@“No, Vaccha.” 
dhamma@mn72@1@mn72:14.1@“‘Sassato loko’ti kho, vaccha, diṭṭhigatametaṁ diṭṭhigahanaṁ diṭṭhikantāro diṭṭhivisūkaṁ diṭṭhivipphanditaṁ diṭṭhisaṁyojanaṁ sadukkhaṁ savighātaṁ saupāyāsaṁ sapariḷāhaṁ, na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati. 
dhamma@mn72@3@mn72:14.1@“Each of these ten convictions is the thicket of views, the desert of views, the trick of views, the evasiveness of views, the fetter of views. They’re beset with anguish, distress, and fever. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. 
dhamma@mn72@1@mn72:14.10@‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti kho, vaccha, diṭṭhigatametaṁ diṭṭhigahanaṁ diṭṭhikantāro diṭṭhivisūkaṁ diṭṭhivipphanditaṁ diṭṭhisaṁyojanaṁ sadukkhaṁ savighātaṁ saupāyāsaṁ sapariḷāhaṁ, na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati. 
dhamma@mn72@3@mn72:14.10@
dhamma@mn73@1@mn73:22.2@‘anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussareyyaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi; anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe—amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapannoti; iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussareyyan’ti, 
dhamma@mn73@3@mn73:22.2@‘May I recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. May I remember: “There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.” May I recollect my many past lives, with features and details.’ 
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:9.1@Ayaṁ kho panaggivessana, kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṁsanadhammo, aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassitabbo. 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:9.1@Aggivessana, this body is physical. It’s made up of the four primary elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction. You should see it as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as misery, as an affliction, as alien, as falling apart, as empty, as not-self. 
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:9.2@Tassimaṁ kāyaṁ aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassato yo kāyasmiṁ kāyachando kāyasneho kāyanvayatā sā pahīyati. 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:9.2@Doing so, you’ll give up desire, affection, and subservience to the body. 
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:10.2@sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:10.2@pleasant, painful, and neutral. 
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:10.3@Yasmiṁ, aggivessana, samaye sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, neva tasmiṁ samaye dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, na adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti; 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:10.3@At a time when you feel a pleasant feeling, you don’t feel a painful or neutral feeling; 
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:10.5@Yasmiṁ, aggivessana, samaye dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, neva tasmiṁ samaye sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, na adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti; 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:10.5@At a time when you feel a painful feeling, you don’t feel a pleasant or neutral feeling; 
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:10.6@dukkhaṁyeva tasmiṁ samaye vedanaṁ vedeti. 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:10.6@you only feel a painful feeling. 
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:10.7@Yasmiṁ, aggivessana, samaye adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, neva tasmiṁ samaye sukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, na dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedeti; 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:10.7@At a time when you feel a neutral feeling, you don’t feel a pleasant or painful feeling; 
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:10.8@adukkhamasukhaṁyeva tasmiṁ samaye vedanaṁ vedeti. 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:10.8@you only feel a neutral feeling. 
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:11.2@dukkhāpi kho, aggivessana, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā; 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:11.2@
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:11.3@adukkhamasukhāpi kho, aggivessana, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā. 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:11.3@
dhamma@mn74@1@mn74:12.1@Evaṁ passaṁ, aggivessana, sutavā ariyasāvako sukhāyapi vedanāya nibbindati, dukkhāyapi vedanāya nibbindati, adukkhamasukhāyapi vedanāya nibbindati; 
dhamma@mn74@3@mn74:12.1@Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings. 
dhamma@mn75@1@mn75:15.10@Asu hi, bho gotama, aggi dukkhasamphasso ceva mahābhitāpo ca mahāpariḷāho cā”ti. 
dhamma@mn75@3@mn75:15.10@Because that fire is really painful to touch, fiercely burning and scorching.” 
dhamma@mn75@1@mn75:15.12@idāneva nu kho so aggi dukkhasamphasso ceva mahābhitāpo ca mahāpariḷāho ca udāhu pubbepi so aggi dukkhasamphasso ceva mahābhitāpo ca mahāpariḷāho cā”ti? 
dhamma@mn75@3@mn75:15.12@Is it only now that the fire is really painful to touch, fiercely burning and scorching, or was it painful previously as well?” 
dhamma@mn75@1@mn75:15.13@“Idāni ceva, bho gotama, so aggi dukkhasamphasso ceva mahābhitāpo ca mahāpariḷāho ca, pubbepi so aggi dukkhasamphasso ceva mahābhitāpo ca mahāpariḷāho ca. 
dhamma@mn75@3@mn75:15.13@“That fire is painful now and it was also painful previously. 
dhamma@mn75@1@mn75:15.14@Asu ca, bho gotama, kuṭṭhī puriso arugatto pakkagatto kimīhi khajjamāno nakhehi vaṇamukhāni vippatacchamāno upahatindriyo dukkhasamphasseyeva aggismiṁ sukhamiti viparītasaññaṁ paccalatthā”ti. 
dhamma@mn75@3@mn75:15.14@That person was affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs. Being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, their sense faculties were impaired. So even though the fire was actually painful to touch, they had a distorted perception that it was pleasant.” 
dhamma@mn75@1@mn75:16.1@“Evameva kho, māgaṇḍiya, atītampi addhānaṁ kāmā dukkhasamphassā ceva mahābhitāpā ca mahāpariḷāhā ca, anāgatampi addhānaṁ kāmā dukkhasamphassā ceva mahābhitāpā ca mahāpariḷāhā ca, etarahipi paccuppannaṁ addhānaṁ kāmā dukkhasamphassā ceva mahābhitāpā ca mahāpariḷāhā ca. 
dhamma@mn75@3@mn75:16.1@“In the same way, sensual pleasures of the past, future, and present are painful to touch, fiercely burning and scorching. 
dhamma@mn75@1@mn75:16.2@Ime ca, māgaṇḍiya, sattā kāmesu avītarāgā kāmataṇhāhi khajjamānā kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamānā upahatindriyā dukkhasamphassesuyeva kāmesu sukhamiti viparītasaññaṁ paccalatthuṁ. 
dhamma@mn75@3@mn75:16.2@These sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures—being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures—have impaired sense faculties. So even though sensual pleasures are actually painful to touch, they have a distorted perception that they are pleasant. 
dhamma@mn75@1@mn75:24.8@Tassa me upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti; 
dhamma@mn75@3@mn75:24.8@My grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. 
dhamma@mn75@1@mn75:24.9@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hotī’”ti. 
dhamma@mn75@3@mn75:24.9@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.’” 
dhamma@mn75@1@mn75:25.9@Tassa me upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti; 
dhamma@mn75@3@mn75:25.9@When my grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. 
dhamma@mn75@1@mn75:25.10@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī”ti. 
dhamma@mn75@3@mn75:25.10@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.” 
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:13.7@sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedentī’ti. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:13.7@All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.’ 
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:14.5@Natthi balaṁ, natthi vīriyaṁ, natthi purisathāmo, natthi purisaparakkamo, sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedentī’ti. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:14.5@
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:16.3@te na iñjanti na vipariṇamanti na aññamaññaṁ byābādhenti nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:16.3@They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other. 
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:16.5@Pathavīkāyo āpokāyo tejokāyo vāyokāyo sukhe dukkhe jīve sattame—
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:16.5@The substances of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh. 
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:16.7@Te na iñjanti na vipariṇamanti na aññamaññaṁ byābādhenti. Nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:16.7@They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other. 
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:16.11@Cuddasa kho panimāni yonipamukhasatasahassāni saṭṭhi ca satāni cha ca satāni pañca ca kammuno satāni pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni, kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca, dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā, dvaṭṭhantarakappā, chaḷābhijātiyo, aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo, ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasate, ekūnapaññāsa paribbājakasate, ekūnapaññāsa nāgāvāsasate, vīse indriyasate, tiṁse nirayasate, chattiṁsa rajodhātuyo, satta saññīgabbhā, satta asaññīgabbhā, satta nigaṇṭhigabbhā, satta devā, satta mānusā, satta pesācā, satta sarā, satta pavuṭā, satta papātā, satta papātasatāni, satta supinā, satta supinasatāni, cullāsīti mahākappino satasahassāni, yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:16.11@There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600. There are 500 deeds, and five, and three. There are deeds and half-deeds. There are 62 paths, 62 sub-eons, six classes of rebirth, and eight stages in a person’s life. There are 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,900 wanderers, and 4,900 naked ascetics. There are 2,000 faculties, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dust. There are seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, and seven knotless embryos. There are seven gods, seven humans, and seven goblins. There are seven lakes, seven rivers, 700 rivers, seven cliffs, and 700 cliffs. There are seven dreams and 700 dreams. There are 8.4 million great eons through which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering. 
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:16.13@Hevaṁ natthi doṇamite sukhadukkhe pariyantakate saṁsāre, natthi hāyanavaḍḍhane, natthi ukkaṁsāvakaṁse. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:16.13@Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse. 
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:16.15@evameva bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissantī’ti. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:16.15@In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:17.5@Nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:17.5@
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:17.7@Pathavīkāyo āpokāyo tejokāyo vāyokāyo sukhe dukkhe jīve sattame—
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:17.7@

dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:17.10@
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:17.14@Cuddasa kho panimāni yonipamukhasatasahassāni saṭṭhi ca satāni cha ca satāni pañca ca kammuno satāni pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni, kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca, dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā, dvaṭṭhantarakappā, chaḷābhijātiyo, aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo, ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasate, ekūnapaññāsa paribbājakasate, ekūnapaññāsa nāgāvāsasate, vīse indriyasate, tiṁse nirayasate, chattiṁsa rajodhātuyo, satta saññīgabbhā, satta asaññīgabbhā, satta nigaṇṭhigabbhā, satta devā, satta mānusā, satta pesācā, satta sarā, satta pavuṭā, satta papātā, satta papātasatāni, satta supinā, satta supinasatāni, cullāsīti mahākappino satasahassāni, yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:17.14@
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:17.15@Tattha natthi imināhaṁ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā aparipakkaṁ vā kammaṁ paripācessāmi, paripakkaṁ vā kammaṁ phussa phussa byantiṁ karissāmīti, hevaṁ natthi doṇamite sukhadukkhe pariyantakate saṁsāre, natthi hāyanavaḍḍhane, natthi ukkaṁsāvakaṁse. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:17.15@
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:17.17@evameva bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissantī’ti. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:17.17@
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:17.19@Ubhopi mayaṁ ettha samasamā sāmaññaṁ pattā, yo cāhaṁ na vadāmi ‘ubho sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissāmā’ti. 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:17.19@have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that after transmigrating both of us will make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@mn76@1@mn76:49.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti; 
dhamma@mn76@3@mn76:49.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@mn77@1@mn77:14.1@Puna caparaṁ, udāyi, mama sāvakā yena dukkhena dukkhotiṇṇā dukkhaparetā te maṁ upasaṅkamitvā dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ pucchanti, tesāhaṁ dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ puṭṭho byākaromi, tesāhaṁ cittaṁ ārādhemi pañhassa veyyākaraṇena; 
dhamma@mn77@3@mn77:14.1@Furthermore, my disciples come to me and ask how the noble truth of suffering applies to the suffering in which they are swamped and mired. And I provide them with a satisfying answer to their question. 
dhamma@mn77@1@mn77:14.2@te maṁ dukkhasamudayaṁ … 
dhamma@mn77@3@mn77:14.2@They ask how the noble truths of the origin of suffering, 
dhamma@mn77@1@mn77:14.3@dukkhanirodhaṁ … 
dhamma@mn77@3@mn77:14.3@the cessation of suffering, 
dhamma@mn77@1@mn77:14.4@dukkhanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ ariyasaccaṁ pucchanti, tesāhaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ ariyasaccaṁ puṭṭho byākaromi, tesāhaṁ cittaṁ ārādhemi pañhassa veyyākaraṇena. 
dhamma@mn77@3@mn77:14.4@and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering apply to the suffering  in which they are swamped and mired. And I provide them with satisfying answers to their questions. 
dhamma@mn77@1@mn77:14.5@Yampudāyi, mama sāvakā yena dukkhena dukkhotiṇṇā dukkhaparetā te maṁ upasaṅkamitvā dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ pucchanti, tesāhaṁ dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ puṭṭho byākaromi, tesāhaṁ cittaṁ ārādhemi pañhassa veyyākaraṇena. 
dhamma@mn77@3@mn77:14.5@Since this is so, 
dhamma@mn77@1@mn77:14.6@Te maṁ dukkhasamudayaṁ …

dhamma@mn77@1@mn77:14.8@dukkhanirodhagāminiṁ paṭipadaṁ ariyasaccaṁ pucchanti.
