dhamma@mn77@1@mn77:28.1@Puna caparaṁ, udāyi, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn77@3@mn77:28.1@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption. It is without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn77@1@mn77:34.1@Puna caparaṁ, udāyi, akkhātā mayā sāvakānaṁ paṭipadā, yathāpaṭipannā me sāvakā anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussaranti, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi, anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@mn77@3@mn77:34.1@Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to recollect the many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@mn79@1@mn79:22.2@yasmiṁ samaye pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, ekantasukhī vā tasmiṁ samaye attā hoti sukhadukkhī vā”ti? 
dhamma@mn79@3@mn79:22.2@On an occasion when someone refrains from killing living creatures, is their self perfectly happy at that time, or does it have both pleasure and pain?” 
dhamma@mn79@1@mn79:22.3@“Sukhadukkhī, bhante”. 
dhamma@mn79@3@mn79:22.3@“It has both pleasure and pain.” 
dhamma@mn79@1@mn79:22.5@yasmiṁ samaye adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, ekantasukhī vā tasmiṁ samaye attā hoti sukhadukkhī vā”ti? 
dhamma@mn79@3@mn79:22.5@On an occasion when someone refrains from stealing … 
dhamma@mn79@1@mn79:22.6@“Sukhadukkhī, bhante”. 
dhamma@mn79@3@mn79:22.6@

dhamma@mn79@3@mn79:22.12@On an occasion when someone undertakes and follows some kind of mortification, is their self perfectly happy at that time, or does it have both pleasure and pain?” 
dhamma@mn79@1@mn79:22.13@“Sukhadukkhī, bhante”.

dhamma@mn79@1@mn79:22.15@api nu kho vokiṇṇasukhadukkhaṁ paṭipadaṁ āgamma ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyā hotī”ti? 
dhamma@mn79@3@mn79:22.15@Is a perfectly happy world realized by relying on a practice of mixed pleasure and pain?”

dhamma@mn81@1@mn81:18.9@Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro dukkhe nikkaṅkho, dukkhasamudaye nikkaṅkho, dukkhanirodhe nikkaṅkho, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya nikkaṅkho. 
dhamma@mn81@3@mn81:18.9@He is free of doubt regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

dhamma@mn82@1@mn82:10.14@“tvaṁ khosi, samma raṭṭhapāla, mātāpitūnaṁ ekaputtako piyo manāpo sukhedhito sukhaparibhato, na tvaṁ, samma raṭṭhapāla, kassaci dukkhassa jānāsi, maraṇenapi te mātāpitaro akāmakā vinā bhavissanti.

dhamma@mn82@3@mn82:22.7@Because this will bring you nothing but sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.” 
dhamma@mn82@1@mn82:31.2@Idha, bho raṭṭhapāla, ekacco ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. 
dhamma@mn82@3@mn82:31.2@It’s when someone is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

dhamma@mn82@3@mn82:31.4@‘I’m now sick, suffering, gravely ill.

dhamma@mn85@3@mn85:9.5@‘Pleasure is not gained through pleasure; pleasure is gained through pain.’”

dhamma@mn85@1@mn85:20.7@Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, rājakumāra, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho, teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato. 
dhamma@mn85@3@mn85:20.7@My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

dhamma@mn85@1@mn85:30.2@‘ye kho keci atītamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayiṁsu, etāvaparamaṁ nayito bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn85@3@mn85:30.2@‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this. 
dhamma@mn85@1@mn85:30.3@Yepi hi keci anāgatamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayissanti, etāvaparamaṁ nayito bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn85@3@mn85:30.3@
dhamma@mn85@1@mn85:30.4@Yepi hi keci etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, etāvaparamaṁ nayito bhiyyo. 
dhamma@mn85@3@mn85:30.4@
dhamma@mn85@1@mn85:40.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ …pe… ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ; 
dhamma@mn85@3@mn85:40.2@I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@mn85@1@mn85:58.8@paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammādukkhakkhayagāminiyā. 
dhamma@mn85@3@mn85:58.8@They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

dhamma@mn87@1@mn87:8.1@Tadamināpetaṁ, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā piyajātikā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā piyappabhavikā.

dhamma@mn87@1@mn87:24.5@vajiriyā te kumāriyā vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti? 
dhamma@mn87@3@mn87:24.5@If she were to decay and perish, would sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise in you?” 
dhamma@mn87@1@mn87:24.6@“Vajiriyā me, mallike, kumāriyā vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṁ, kiṁ pana me na uppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti? 
dhamma@mn87@3@mn87:24.6@“If she were to decay and perish, my life would fall apart. How could sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress not arise in me?” 
dhamma@mn87@1@mn87:24.8@‘piyajātikā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā piyappabhavikā’ti. 
dhamma@mn87@3@mn87:24.8@‘Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.’ 
dhamma@mn87@1@mn87:25.4@“Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, mahārāja, vāsabhāya te khattiyāya vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti? 
dhamma@mn87@3@mn87:25.4@

dhamma@mn87@3@mn87:28.6@If these realms were to decay and perish, would sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise in you?”

dhamma@mn88@1@mn88:10.8@“Yo kho, mahārāja, kāyasamācāro dukkhavipāko”. 
dhamma@mn88@3@mn88:10.8@“Behavior that results in suffering.” 
dhamma@mn88@1@mn88:10.9@“Katamo pana, bhante, kāyasamācāro dukkhavipāko”? 
dhamma@mn88@3@mn88:10.9@“But what kind of bodily behavior results in suffering?” 
dhamma@mn88@1@mn88:12.2@“Yo kho, mahārāja, manosamācāro dukkhavipāko”.

dhamma@mn90@1@mn90:10.13@paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammādukkhakkhayagāminiyā—
dhamma@mn90@3@mn90:10.13@They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@mn91@1@mn91:36.5@dukkhaṁ, samudayaṁ, nirodhaṁ, maggaṁ. 
dhamma@mn91@3@mn91:36.5@suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path. 
dhamma@mn94@1@mn94:6.2@“Yvāyaṁ, bho udena, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānaṁ sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti; 
dhamma@mn94@3@mn94:6.2@“Sir, the person who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain. 
dhamma@mn94@1@mn94:6.4@Yopāyaṁ, bho udena, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so paraṁ sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti; 
dhamma@mn94@3@mn94:6.4@The person who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain. 
dhamma@mn94@1@mn94:6.6@Yopāyaṁ, bho udena, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ ātāpeti paritāpeti; 
dhamma@mn94@3@mn94:6.6@The person who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain. 
dhamma@mn94@1@mn94:6.8@Yo ca kho ayaṁ, bho udena, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṁvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati, so attānañca parañca sukhakāmaṁ dukkhapaṭikkūlaṁ neva ātāpeti na paritāpeti; 
dhamma@mn94@3@mn94:6.8@The person who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—living without wishes, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine—does not torment themselves or others, both of whom want to be happy and recoil from pain. 
dhamma@mn94@1@mn94:25.1@Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn94@3@mn94:25.1@Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn94@1@mn94:26.2@So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi, anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto; so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto; so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@mn94@3@mn94:26.2@They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@mn94@1@mn94:28.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti; 
dhamma@mn94@3@mn94:28.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@mn95@1@mn95:17.6@passāmīti, paraṁ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṁ paresaṁ assa dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyāti? 
dhamma@mn95@3@mn95:17.6@or that they might encourage others to do what is for their lasting harm and suffering?’

dhamma@mn97@1@mn97:27.1@Atha kho dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo aparena samayena ābādhiko ahosi dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. 
dhamma@mn97@3@mn97:27.1@Some time later Dhanañjāni became sick, suffering, gravely ill.

dhamma@mn97@1@mn97:28.2@“kacci te, dhanañjāni, khamanīyaṁ, kacci yāpanīyaṁ? Kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti? Paṭikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti? 
dhamma@mn97@3@mn97:28.2@“I hope you’re keeping well, Dhanañjāni; I hope you’re getting by. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.” 
dhamma@mn97@1@mn97:29.1@“Na me, bho sāriputta, khamanīyaṁ na yāpanīyaṁ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti. Abhikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo. 
dhamma@mn97@3@mn97:29.1@“I’m not keeping well, Master Sāriputta, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.

dhamma@mn100@1@mn100:14.11@“Evameva kho, bhāradvāja, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi avūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṁ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho so ca ajjhattaṁ na suppahīno hoti na suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. No cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. 
dhamma@mn100@3@mn100:14.11@“In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. They haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening. 
dhamma@mn100@1@mn100:15.10@yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti. “Evameva kho, bhāradvāja, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi vūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṁ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho so ca ajjhattaṁ na suppahīno hoti na suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. dhamma@mn100@3@mn100:15.10@That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.” “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. dhamma@mn100@1@mn100:17.7@Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, bhāradvāja, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā; sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho, teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.

dhamma@mn100@3@mn100:27.2@‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this.

dhamma@mn100@1@mn100:39.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ; 
dhamma@mn100@3@mn100:39.2@I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:2.5@‘yaṁ kiñcāyaṁ purisapuggalo paṭisaṁvedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, sabbaṁ taṁ pubbekatahetu. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:2.5@‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:2.7@āyatiṁ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatī’ti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:2.7@With no future consequence, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.’

dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:12.3@Yasmiṁ vo samaye tibbo upakkamo hoti tibbaṁ padhānaṁ, tibbā tasmiṁ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:12.3@At a time of intense exertion and striving do you suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion? 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:12.4@yasmiṁ pana vo samaye na tibbo upakkamo hoti na tibbaṁ padhānaṁ, na tibbā tasmiṁ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyethā’ti? 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:12.4@Whereas at a time without intense exertion and striving do you not suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?’ 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:12.5@‘Yasmiṁ no, āvuso gotama, samaye tibbo upakkamo hoti tibbaṁ padhānaṁ, tibbā tasmiṁ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyāma; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:12.5@‘Reverend Gotama, at a time of intense exertion we suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:12.6@yasmiṁ pana no samaye na tibbo upakkamo hoti na tibbaṁ padhānaṁ, na tibbā tasmiṁ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyāmā’ti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:12.6@not without intense exertion.’

dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:13.1@‘So it seems that only at a time of intense exertion do you suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion,

dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:13.2@not without intense exertion.

dhamma@mn101@4@mn101:14.1@tasmiṁ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha → tiṭṭheyyeva tasmiṁ samaye … vedanā (sya-all, km, pts1ed) 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:14.2@yasmiṁ pana vo samaye na tibbo upakkamo hoti na tibbaṁ padhānaṁ, tibbā tasmiṁ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:14.2@and if without intense exertion you did experience such feelings, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:14.4@“yaṁ kiñcāyaṁ purisapuggalo paṭisaṁvedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, sabbaṁ taṁ pubbekatahetu. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:14.4@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:14.6@āyatiṁ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatī”ti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:14.6@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:15.1@Yasmā ca kho, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, yasmiṁ vo samaye tibbo upakkamo hoti tibbaṁ padhānaṁ, tibbā tasmiṁ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:15.1@But since this is not the case, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:15.2@yasmiṁ pana vo samaye na tibbo upakkamo hoti na tibbaṁ padhānaṁ, na tibbā tasmiṁ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:15.2@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:15.3@te tumhe sāmaṁyeva opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānā avijjā aññāṇā sammohā vipaccetha: 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:15.3@aren’t you experiencing painful, sharp feelings due only to your own exertion, which out of ignorance, unknowing, and confusion you misconstrue to imply: 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:15.4@“yaṁ kiñcāyaṁ purisapuggalo paṭisaṁvedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, sabbaṁ taṁ pubbekatahetu. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:15.4@“Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. …”?’ 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:15.6@āyatiṁ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatī”’ti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:15.6@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:17.1@‘Taṁ kiṁ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṁ kammaṁ sukhavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā dukkhavedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti? 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:17.1@‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced as pleasure, can exertion make it be experienced as pain?’ 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:17.3@‘Yaṁ panidaṁ kammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā sukhavedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti? 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:17.3@‘But if a deed is to be experienced as pain, can exertion make it be experienced as pleasure?’ 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:21.1@‘Iti kira, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṁ kammaṁ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā samparāyavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yaṁ panidaṁ kammaṁ samparāyavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ sukhavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā dukkhavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā sukhavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ paripakkavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā aparipakkavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ aparipakkavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā paripakkavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ bahuvedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā appavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ appavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā bahuvedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ savedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā avedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ avedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā savedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:21.1@‘So it seems that exertion cannot change the way deeds are experienced in any of these ways. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.3@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.3@If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.4@addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pubbe dukkaṭakammakārino yaṁ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.4@clearly the Jains have done bad deeds in the past, since they now experience such intense pain. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.5@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.5@If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of God Almighty’s creation, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.6@addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pāpakena issarena nimmitā yaṁ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.6@clearly the Jains were created by a bad God, since they now experience such intense pain. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.7@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.7@If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of circumstance and nature, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.8@addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pāpasaṅgatikā yaṁ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.8@clearly the Jains arise from bad circumstances, since they now experience such intense pain. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.9@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.9@If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the class of rebirth, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.10@addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pāpābhijātikā yaṁ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.10@clearly the Jains have been reborn in a bad class, since they now experience such intense pain. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.11@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.11@If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of exertion in the present, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.12@addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā evarūpā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamā yaṁ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.12@clearly the Jains exert themselves badly in the present, since they now experience such intense pain. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.13@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.13@The Jains deserve criticism whether or not sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.14@no ce sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.14@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.15@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.15@or God Almighty’s creation, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.16@no ce sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.16@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.17@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.17@or circumstance and nature, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.18@no ce sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.18@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.19@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.19@or class of rebirth, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.20@no ce sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.20@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.21@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.21@or exertion in the present. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:22.22@no ce sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:22.22@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:23.2@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva anaddhabhūtaṁ attānaṁ dukkhena addhabhāveti, dhammikañca sukhaṁ na pariccajati, tasmiñca sukhe anadhimucchito hoti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:23.2@It’s when a mendicant doesn’t bring suffering upon themselves; and they don’t give up legitimate pleasure, but they’re not besotted with that pleasure. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:23.4@‘imassa kho me dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, imassa pana me dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hotī’ti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:23.4@‘When I actively strive I become dispassionate towards this source of suffering. But when I develop equanimity I become dispassionate towards this other source of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:23.5@So yassa hi khvāssa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, saṅkhāraṁ tattha padahati. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:23.5@So they either actively strive or develop equanimity as appropriate. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:23.6@Yassa panassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hoti, upekkhaṁ tattha bhāveti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:23.6@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:23.7@Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti—
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:23.7@Through active striving they become dispassionate towards that specific source of suffering, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:23.8@evampissa taṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ hoti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:23.8@and so that suffering is worn away. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:23.9@Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hoti—
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:23.9@Through developing equanimity they become dispassionate towards that other source of suffering, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:23.10@evampissa taṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ hoti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:23.10@and so that suffering is worn away. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:24.4@api nu tassa purisassa amuṁ itthiṁ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti? 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:24.4@Would that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for him?” 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:24.8@Tasmā taṁ itthiṁ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:24.8@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:25.3@Tassa me amuṁ itthiṁ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:25.3@When I saw her standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing, it gave rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for me. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:25.8@api nu tassa purisassa amuṁ itthiṁ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti? 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:25.8@Would that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for him?” 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:25.12@Tasmā taṁ itthiṁ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ na uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:25.12@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:26.1@“Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva anaddhabhūtaṁ attānaṁ dukkhena addhabhāveti, dhammikañca sukhaṁ na pariccajati, tasmiñca sukhe anadhimucchito hoti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:26.1@“In the same way, a mendicant doesn’t bring suffering upon themselves; and they don’t give up legitimate pleasure, but they’re not besotted with that pleasure. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:26.3@‘imassa kho me dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, imassa pana me dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hotī’ti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:26.3@‘When I actively strive I become dispassionate towards this source of suffering. But when I develop equanimity I become dispassionate towards this other source of suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:26.4@So yassa hi khvāssa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, saṅkhāraṁ tattha padahati; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:26.4@So they either actively strive or develop equanimity as appropriate. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:26.5@yassa panassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hoti, upekkhaṁ tattha bhāveti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:26.5@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:26.6@Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti—
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:26.6@Through active striving they become dispassionate towards that specific source of suffering, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:26.7@evampissa taṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ hoti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:26.7@and so that suffering is worn away. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:26.8@Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hoti—
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:26.8@Through developing equanimity they become dispassionate towards that other source of suffering, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:26.9@evampissa taṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ hoti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:26.9@and so that suffering is worn away. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:27.3@dukkhāya pana me attānaṁ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:27.3@But when I strive painfully, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:27.4@Yannūnāhaṁ dukkhāya attānaṁ padaheyyan’ti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:27.4@Why don’t I strive painfully?’ 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:27.5@So dukkhāya attānaṁ padahati. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:27.5@So that’s what they do, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:27.6@Tassa dukkhāya attānaṁ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:27.6@and as they do so unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:27.7@So na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṁ padahati. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:27.7@After some time, they no longer strive painfully. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:27.9@Yassa hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu atthāya dukkhāya attānaṁ padaheyya svāssa attho abhinipphanno hoti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:27.9@Because they have accomplished the goal for which they strived painfully. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:27.10@Tasmā na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṁ padahati. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:27.10@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:29.7@dukkhāya pana me attānaṁ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:29.7@But when I strive painfully, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:29.8@Yannūnāhaṁ dukkhāya attānaṁ padaheyyan’ti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:29.8@Why don’t I strive painfully?’ … 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:29.9@So dukkhāya attānaṁ padahati. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:29.9@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:29.10@Tassa dukkhāya attānaṁ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:29.10@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:29.11@So na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṁ padahati. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:29.11@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:29.13@Yassa hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu atthāya dukkhāya attānaṁ padaheyya svāssa attho abhinipphanno hoti. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:29.13@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:29.14@Tasmā na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṁ padahati. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:29.14@After some time, they no longer strive painfully. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:41.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:41.1@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:42.2@So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:42.2@They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:44.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:44.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:46.5@If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of God Almighty’s creation, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:46.7@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:46.7@If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of circumstance and nature, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:46.9@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:46.9@If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the class of rebirth, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:46.11@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:46.11@If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of exertion in the present, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:46.13@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, pāsaṁso tathāgato; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:46.13@The Realized One deserves praise whether or not sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:46.14@no ce sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, pāsaṁso tathāgato. 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:46.14@
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:46.15@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, pāsaṁso tathāgato; 
dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:46.15@or God Almighty’s creation, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:46.16@no ce sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, pāsaṁso tathāgato.

dhamma@mn101@3@mn101:46.17@or circumstance and nature, 
dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:46.18@no ce sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, pāsaṁso tathāgato.

dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:46.19@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, pāsaṁso tathāgato;

dhamma@mn101@1@mn101:46.21@Sace, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, pāsaṁso tathāgato;

dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:14.15@ittheke abhivadanti, ‘ekantadukkhī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:14.15@‘The self and the cosmos experience nothing but suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:14.16@ittheke abhivadanti, ‘sukhadukkhī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:14.16@‘The self and the cosmos experience both happiness and suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:14.17@ittheke abhivadanti, ‘adukkhamasukhī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’ti—
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:14.17@‘The self and the cosmos experience neither happiness nor suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:16.14@ekantadukkhī attā ca loko ca … 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:16.14@or experience nothing but suffering, 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:16.15@sukhadukkhī attā ca loko ca … 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:16.15@or experience both happiness and suffering, 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:16.16@adukkhamasukhī attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññanti, tesaṁ vata aññatreva saddhāya aññatra ruciyā aññatra anussavā aññatra ākāraparivitakkā aññatra diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā paccattaṁyeva ñāṇaṁ bhavissati parisuddhaṁ pariyodātanti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati. 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:16.16@or experience neither happiness nor suffering. It’s simply not possible for them to have purified and clear personal knowledge of this, apart from faith, endorsement, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration. 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:21.1@Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā pubbantānudiṭṭhīnañca paṭinissaggā, aparantānudiṭṭhīnañca paṭinissaggā, sabbaso kāmasaṁyojanānaṁ anadhiṭṭhānā, pavivekāya pītiyā samatikkamā, nirāmisassa sukhassa samatikkamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ upasampajja viharati: 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:21.1@Now, some ascetics and brahmins, letting go of theories about the past and the future, shedding the fetters of sensuality, going beyond the rapture of seclusion and pleasure not of the flesh, enter and remain in neutral feeling. 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:21.2@‘etaṁ santaṁ etaṁ paṇītaṁ yadidaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ upasampajja viharāmī’ti. 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:21.2@‘This is peaceful, this is sublime, that is, entering and remaining in neutral feeling.’ 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:21.3@Tassa sā adukkhamasukhā vedanā nirujjhati. 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:21.3@Then that neutral feeling ceases. 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:21.4@Adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya nirodhā uppajjati nirāmisaṁ sukhaṁ, nirāmisassa sukhassa nirodhā uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:21.4@When neutral feeling ceases, pleasure not of the flesh arises; and when pleasure not of the flesh ceases, neutral feelings arises. 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:22.2@evameva kho, bhikkhave, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya nirodhā uppajjati nirāmisaṁ sukhaṁ, nirāmisassa sukhassa nirodhā uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:22.2@
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:22.4@Ayaṁ kho bhavaṁ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā pubbantānudiṭṭhīnañca paṭinissaggā, aparantānudiṭṭhīnañca paṭinissaggā, sabbaso kāmasaṁyojanānaṁ anadhiṭṭhānā, pavivekāya pītiyā samatikkamā, nirāmisassa sukhassa samatikkamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ upasampajja viharati: 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:22.4@This good ascetic or brahmin, letting go of theories about the past and the future, shedding the fetters of sensuality, going beyond the rapture of seclusion and pleasure not of the flesh, enters and remains in neutral feeling. 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:22.5@‘etaṁ santaṁ etaṁ paṇītaṁ yadidaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ upasampajja viharāmī’ti. 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:22.5@‘This is peaceful, this is sublime, that is, entering and remaining in neutral feeling.’ 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:22.6@Tassa sā adukkhamasukhā vedanā nirujjhati. 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:22.6@Then that neutral feeling ceases. 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:22.7@Adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya nirodhā uppajjati nirāmisaṁ sukhaṁ, nirāmisassa sukhassa nirodhā uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:22.7@When neutral feeling ceases, pleasure not of the flesh arises; and when pleasure not of the flesh ceases, neutral feelings arises. 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:23.1@Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā pubbantānudiṭṭhīnañca paṭinissaggā, aparantānudiṭṭhīnañca paṭinissaggā, sabbaso kāmasaṁyojanānaṁ anadhiṭṭhānā, pavivekāya pītiyā samatikkamā, nirāmisassa sukhassa samatikkamā, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya samatikkamā: 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:23.1@Now, some ascetics and brahmins, letting go of theories about the past and the future, shedding the fetters of sensuality, go beyond the rapture of seclusion, pleasure not of the flesh, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:24.2@Ayaṁ kho bhavaṁ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā pubbantānudiṭṭhīnañca paṭinissaggā, aparantānudiṭṭhīnañca paṭinissaggā, sabbaso kāmasaṁyojanānaṁ anadhiṭṭhānā, pavivekāya pītiyā samatikkamā, nirāmisassa sukhassa samatikkamā, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya samatikkamā: 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:24.2@This good ascetic or brahmin, letting go of theories about the past and the future, shedding the fetters of sensuality, goes beyond the rapture of seclusion, pleasure not of the flesh, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@mn102@1@mn102:24.5@Atha ca panāyaṁ bhavaṁ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā pubbantānudiṭṭhiṁ vā upādiyamāno upādiyati, aparantānudiṭṭhiṁ vā upādiyamāno upādiyati, kāmasaṁyojanaṁ vā upādiyamāno upādiyati, pavivekaṁ vā pītiṁ upādiyamāno upādiyati, nirāmisaṁ vā sukhaṁ upādiyamāno upādiyati, adukkhamasukhaṁ vā vedanaṁ upādiyamāno upādiyati. 
dhamma@mn102@3@mn102:24.5@Nevertheless, they still grasp at theories about the past or the future, or the fetters of sensuality, or the rapture of seclusion, or pleasure not of the flesh, or neutral feeling. 
dhamma@mn104@1@mn104:4.11@svāssa vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānan’”ti. 
dhamma@mn104@3@mn104:4.11@For such a dispute would be for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.’” 
dhamma@mn104@1@mn104:5.7@Svāssa vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānan”ti. 
dhamma@mn104@3@mn104:5.7@Such a dispute would be for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.” 
dhamma@mn104@1@mn104:5.9@Magge vā hi, ānanda, paṭipadāya vā saṅghe vivādo uppajjamāno uppajjeyya; svāssa vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn104@3@mn104:5.9@But should a dispute arise in the Saṅgha concerning the path or the practice, that would be for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans. 
dhamma@mn104@1@mn104:6.5@Yo so, ānanda, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso, dhamme … saṅghe agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāya na paripūrakārī hoti, so saṅghe vivādaṁ janeti; yo hoti vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya, bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn104@3@mn104:6.5@They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans. 
dhamma@mn104@1@mn104:7-11.7@Yo so, ānanda, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso, dhamme … saṅghe … sikkhāya na paripūrakārī hoti so saṅghe vivādaṁ janeti; yo hoti vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya, bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṁ. 
dhamma@mn104@3@mn104:7-11.7@They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans. 
dhamma@mn104@1@mn104:21.13@Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu—yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā—diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca. 
dhamma@mn104@3@mn104:21.13@Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:18.7@So rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:18.7@resulting in death or deadly pain. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:20.9@So puthuttaṁ gatena vaṇena maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:20.9@resulting in death or deadly pain. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:21.7@So rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:21.7@resulting in death or deadly pain. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:22.2@maraṇamattañhetaṁ, sunakkhatta, dukkhaṁ yaṁ aññataraṁ saṅkiliṭṭhaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:22.2@And it is deadly pain to commit one of the corrupt offenses. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:23.6@So na rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena neva maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya na maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:23.6@so no death or deadly pain would result. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:25.9@So ruḷhena vaṇena sañchavinā neva maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya na maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:25.9@and no death or deadly pain would result. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:26.6@So na rāgānuddhaṁsitena cittena neva maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya na maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:26.6@so no death or deadly pain would result. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:28.1@So vata, sunakkhatta, bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu saṁvutakārī ‘upadhi dukkhassa mūlan’ti—
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:28.1@Truly, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:29.3@Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhapaṭikūlo. 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:29.3@Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:29.6@‘imāhaṁ pivitvā maraṇaṁ vā nigacchāmi maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan’”ti? 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:29.6@it would result in death or deadly suffering?” 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:29.8@“Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, so vata bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu saṁvutakārī ‘upadhi dukkhassa mūlan’ti—
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:29.8@“In the same way, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:30.2@Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhapaṭikūlo. 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:30.2@Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain. 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:30.5@‘imināhaṁ daṭṭho maraṇaṁ vā nigacchāmi maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan’”ti? 
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:30.5@it would result in death or deadly suffering?” 
dhamma@mn105@1@mn105:30.7@“Evameva kho, sunakkhatta, so vata bhikkhu chasu phassāyatanesu saṁvutakārī ‘upadhi dukkhassa mūlan’ti—
dhamma@mn105@3@mn105:30.7@“In the same way, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact. 
dhamma@mn108@1@mn108:21.1@Anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattārīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@mn108@3@mn108:21.1@They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details. 
dhamma@mn109@1@mn109:12.7@Yaṁ rūpaṁ aniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, ayaṁ rūpe ādīnavo. 
dhamma@mn109@3@mn109:12.7@That form is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback. 
dhamma@mn109@1@mn109:12.13@Yaṁ viññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, ayaṁ viññāṇe ādīnavo. 
dhamma@mn109@3@mn109:12.13@That consciousness is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback. 
dhamma@mn109@1@mn109:15.4@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti? 
dhamma@mn109@3@mn109:15.4@“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?” 
dhamma@mn109@1@mn109:15.5@“Dukkhaṁ, bhante”. 
dhamma@mn109@3@mn109:15.5@“Suffering, sir.” 
dhamma@mn109@1@mn109:15.6@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ: 
dhamma@mn109@3@mn109:15.6@“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: 
dhamma@mn109@1@mn109:16.7@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti? 
dhamma@mn109@3@mn109:16.7@“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?” 
dhamma@mn109@1@mn109:16.8@“Dukkhaṁ, bhante”. 
dhamma@mn109@3@mn109:16.8@“Suffering, sir.” 
dhamma@mn109@1@mn109:16.9@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ: 
dhamma@mn109@3@mn109:16.9@“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: 
dhamma@mn111@1@mn111:9.1@Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, sāriputto sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn111@3@mn111:9.1@Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, he entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn111@1@mn111:10.1@Ye ca catutthe jhāne dhammā—upekkhā adukkhamasukhā vedanā passaddhattā cetaso anābhogo satipārisuddhi cittekaggatā ca, phasso vedanā saññā cetanā cittaṁ chando adhimokkho vīriyaṁ sati upekkhā manasikāro—tyāssa dhammā anupadavavatthitā honti. 
dhamma@mn111@3@mn111:10.1@And he distinguished the phenomena in the fourth absorption one by one: equanimity and neutral feeling and mental unconcern due to tranquility and pure mindfulness and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and application of mind. 
dhamma@mn112@1@mn112:19.2@So idaṁ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ; 
dhamma@mn112@3@mn112:19.2@I truly understood: “This is suffering” … “This is the origin of suffering” … “This is the cessation of suffering” … “This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering”. 
dhamma@mn115@1@mn115:6.4@sukhadhātu, dukkhadhātu, somanassadhātu, domanassadhātu, upekkhādhātu, avijjādhātu. 
dhamma@mn115@3@mn115:6.4@the elements of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, equanimity, and ignorance. 
dhamma@mn115@1@mn115:11.15@jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā sambhavanti. 
dhamma@mn115@3@mn115:11.15@Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be. 
dhamma@mn115@1@mn115:11.16@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@mn115@3@mn115:11.16@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@mn115@1@mn115:11.27@jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā nirujjhanti. 
dhamma@mn115@3@mn115:11.27@When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. 
dhamma@mn115@1@mn115:11.28@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti’. 
dhamma@mn115@3@mn115:11.28@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’ 
dhamma@mn116@1@mn116:6.11@Passi jahi upadhidukkhamūlaṁ, 
dhamma@mn116@3@mn116:6.11@Passin gave up attachment, suffering’s root, 
dhamma@mn116@1@mn116:6.30@Usabhacchidā jāliniṁ dukkhamūlaṁ; 
dhamma@mn116@3@mn116:6.30@Usabha cut the net, the root of suffering, 
dhamma@mn118@1@mn118:11.1@Santi, bhikkhave, bhikkhū imasmiṁ bhikkhusaṅghe tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṁ tanuttā sakadāgāmino sakideva imaṁ lokaṁ āgantvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti—
dhamma@mn118@3@mn118:11.1@In this Saṅgha there are mendicants who, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, are once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. 
dhamma@mn119@1@mn119:35.1@Khamo hoti sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ duruttānaṁ durāgatānaṁ vacanapathānaṁ, uppannānaṁ sārīrikānaṁ vedanānaṁ dukkhānaṁ tibbānaṁ kharānaṁ kaṭukānaṁ asātānaṁ amanāpānaṁ pāṇaharānaṁ adhivāsakajātiko hoti. 
dhamma@mn119@3@mn119:35.1@They endure cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening. 
dhamma@mn122@1@mn122:5.1@Nāhaṁ, ānanda, ekaṁ rūpampi samanupassāmi yattha rattassa yathābhiratassa rūpassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā na uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā. 
dhamma@mn122@3@mn122:5.1@Ānanda, I do not see even a single sight which, with its decay and perishing, would not give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in someone who has desire and lust for it. 
dhamma@mn122@1@mn122:13.4@Ye ca kho ime, ānanda, vitakkā ariyā niyyānikā niyyanti takkarassa sammādukkhakkhayāya, seyyathidaṁ—nekkhammavitakko abyāpādavitakko avihiṁsāvitakko iti: ‘evarūpe vitakke vitakkessāmī’ti. 
dhamma@mn122@3@mn122:13.4@‘But I will think the kind of thought that is noble and emancipating, and brings one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. That is, thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.’ 
dhamma@mn122@1@mn122:22.6@Ācariyūpaddavena avadhiṁsu naṁ pāpakā akusalā dhammā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@mn122@3@mn122:22.6@They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@mn122@1@mn122:23.7@Antevāsūpaddavena avadhiṁsu naṁ pāpakā akusalā dhammā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@mn122@3@mn122:23.7@They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@mn122@1@mn122:24.11@Brahmacārūpaddavena avadhiṁsu naṁ pāpakā akusalā dhammā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@mn122@3@mn122:24.11@They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@mn122@1@mn122:24.13@Tatrānanda, yo cevāyaṁ ācariyūpaddavo, yo ca antevāsūpaddavo ayaṁ tehi brahmacārūpaddavo dukkhavipākataro ceva kaṭukavipākataro ca, api ca vinipātāya saṁvattati. 
dhamma@mn122@3@mn122:24.13@And in this context, Ānanda, as compared to the peril of the teacher or the student, the peril of the spiritual practitioner has more painful, bitter results, and even leads to the underworld. 
dhamma@mn123@1@mn123:2.3@yatra hi nāma tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jānissati: 
dhamma@mn123@3@mn123:2.3@For he is able to know the Buddhas of the past who have become completely extinguished, cut off proliferation, cut off the track, finished off the cycle, and transcended suffering. 
dhamma@mn123@1@mn123:2.13@‘acchariyaṁ, āvuso, abbhutaṁ, āvuso, tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā, yatra hi nāma tathāgato atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivatte jānissati—
dhamma@mn123@3@mn123:2.13@
dhamma@mn125@1@mn125:29.2@So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti; 
dhamma@mn125@3@mn125:29.2@They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. 
dhamma@mn125@1@mn125:30.1@So hoti bhikkhu khamo sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ duruttānaṁ durāgatānaṁ vacanapathānaṁ, uppannānaṁ sārīrikānaṁ vedanānaṁ dukkhānaṁ tibbānaṁ kharānaṁ kaṭukānaṁ asātānaṁ amanāpānaṁ pāṇaharānaṁ adhivāsakajātiko hoti 
dhamma@mn125@3@mn125:30.1@Such a mendicant endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and puts up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening. 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:3.1@Sa kho so, bhikkhave, bālo tividhaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:3.1@A fool experiences three kinds of suffering and sadness in the present life. 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:3.8@Idaṁ, bhikkhave, bālo paṭhamaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:3.8@This is the first kind of suffering and sadness that a fool experiences in the present life. 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:4.9@Idampi, bhikkhave, bālo dutiyaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:4.9@This is the second kind of suffering and sadness that a fool experiences in the present life. 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:5.9@Idampi, bhikkhave, bālo tatiyaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:5.9@This is the third kind of suffering and sadness that a fool experiences in the present life. 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:7.4@Yāvañcidaṁ, bhikkhave, upamāpi na sukarā yāva dukkhā nirayā”ti. 
dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:7.4@So much so that it’s not easy to give a simile for how painful hell is.” 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:8.20@api nu so puriso tīhi sattisatehi haññamāno tatonidānaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvediyethā”ti? 
dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:8.20@Would that man experience pain and distress from being struck with three hundred spears?” 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:8.21@“Ekissāpi, bhante, sattiyā haññamāno so puriso tatonidānaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvediyetha, ko pana vādo tīhi sattisatehī”ti? 
dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:8.21@“Sir, that man would experience pain and distress from being struck with one spear, let alone three hundred spears!” 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:9.5@“Evameva kho, bhikkhave, yaṁ so puriso tīhi sattisatehi haññamāno tatonidānaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti taṁ nirayakassa dukkhassa upanidhāya saṅkhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti. 
dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:9.5@“In the same way, compared to the suffering in hell, the pain and distress experienced by that man due to being struck with three hundred spears doesn’t count, it’s not worth a fraction, there’s no comparison. 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:10.3@So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedeti, na ca tāva kālaṁ karoti yāva na taṁ pāpakammaṁ byantīhoti. 
dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:10.3@And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated. 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:11.2@So tattha dukkhā tibbā …pe… byantīhoti.

dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:15.4@And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:17.2@So much so that it’s not easy to completely describe the suffering in hell. 
dhamma@mn129@1@mn129:23.2@yāvañcidaṁ, bhikkhave, na sukaraṁ akkhānena pāpuṇituṁ yāva dukkhā tiracchānayoni. 
dhamma@mn129@3@mn129:23.2@So much so that it’s not easy to completely describe the suffering in the animal realm. 
dhamma@mn130@1@mn130:6.6@‘ambho purisa, na tvaṁ addasa manussesu itthiṁ vā purisaṁ vā ābādhikaṁ dukkhitaṁ bāḷhagilānaṁ sake muttakarīse palipannaṁ semānaṁ aññehi vuṭṭhāpiyamānaṁ aññehi saṁvesiyamānan’ti? 
dhamma@mn130@3@mn130:6.6@‘Mister, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in their own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others?’

dhamma@mn135@1@mn135:17.5@kiṁ me karīyamānaṁ dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya hoti, kiṁ vā pana me karīyamānaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya hotī’ti? 
dhamma@mn135@3@mn135:17.5@What kind of action will lead to my lasting harm and suffering? Or what kind of action will lead to my lasting welfare and happiness?’ 
dhamma@mn135@1@mn135:17.13@kiṁ me karīyamānaṁ dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya hoti, kiṁ vā pana me karīyamānaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya hotī’ti?

dhamma@mn135@3@mn135:18.5@What kind of action will lead to my lasting harm and suffering? Or what kind of action will lead to my lasting welfare and happiness?’
