dhamma@mn136@1@mn136:2.14@“Sañcetanikaṁ, āvuso potaliputta, kammaṁ katvā kāyena vācāya manasā dukkhaṁ so vediyatī”ti. 
dhamma@mn136@3@mn136:2.14@“After doing an intentional deed by way of body, speech, or mind, reverend, one feels suffering.” 
dhamma@mn136@1@mn136:6.3@yaṁ kiñci vedayitaṁ taṁ dukkhasmin”ti. 
dhamma@mn136@3@mn136:6.3@‘Suffering includes whatever is felt.’” 
dhamma@mn136@1@mn136:6.11@sañcetanikaṁ, āvuso potaliputta, kammaṁ katvā kāyena vācāya manasā dukkhavedanīyaṁ dukkhaṁ so vedayati; 
dhamma@mn136@3@mn136:6.11@After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as painful by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels pain. 
dhamma@mn136@1@mn136:6.12@sañcetanikaṁ, āvuso potaliputta, kammaṁ katvā kāyena vācāya manasā adukkhamasukhavedanīyaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ so vedayatī’ti. 
dhamma@mn136@3@mn136:6.12@After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as neutral by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels neutral.’ 
dhamma@mn136@1@mn136:17.2@pubbe vāssa taṁ kataṁ hoti pāpakammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ, pacchā vāssa taṁ kataṁ hoti pāpakammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ, maraṇakāle vāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi samattā samādinnā. 
dhamma@mn136@3@mn136:17.2@They must have done a bad deed to be experienced as painful either previously or later, or else at the time of death they undertook wrong view. 
dhamma@mn136@1@mn136:20.2@pubbe vāssa taṁ kataṁ hoti pāpakammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ, pacchā vāssa taṁ kataṁ hoti pāpakammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ, maraṇakāle vāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi samattā samādinnā. 
dhamma@mn136@3@mn136:20.2@They must have done a bad deed to be experienced as painful either previously or later, or else at the time of death they undertook wrong view. 
dhamma@mn137@1@mn137:11.2@Rūpānaṁ tveva aniccataṁ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṁ, ‘pubbe ceva rūpā etarahi ca sabbe te rūpā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passato uppajjati somanassaṁ. 
dhamma@mn137@3@mn137:11.2@When you’ve understood the impermanence of sights—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—happiness arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those sights are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. 
dhamma@mn137@1@mn137:11.8@dhammānaṁ tveva aniccataṁ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṁ, ‘pubbe ceva dhammā etarahi ca sabbe te dhammā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passato uppajjati somanassaṁ. 
dhamma@mn137@3@mn137:11.8@ideas—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—happiness arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those ideas are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. 
dhamma@mn137@1@mn137:13.2@Rūpānaṁ tveva aniccataṁ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṁ, ‘pubbe ceva rūpā etarahi ca sabbe te rūpā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya disvā anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti: 
dhamma@mn137@3@mn137:13.2@When you’ve understood the impermanence of sights—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those sights are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Upon seeing this, you give rise to yearning for the supreme liberations: 
dhamma@mn137@1@mn137:13.9@dhammānaṁ tveva aniccataṁ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṁ, ‘pubbe ceva dhammā etarahi ca sabbe te dhammā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya disvā anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti: 
dhamma@mn137@3@mn137:13.9@ideas—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those ideas are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Upon seeing this, you give rise to yearning for the supreme liberations: 
dhamma@mn137@1@mn137:15.2@Rūpānaṁ tveva aniccataṁ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṁ, ‘pubbe ceva rūpā etarahi ca sabbe te rūpā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passato uppajjati upekkhā. 
dhamma@mn137@3@mn137:15.2@When you’ve understood the impermanence of sights—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—equanimity arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those sights are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. 
dhamma@mn137@1@mn137:15.9@dhammānaṁ tveva aniccataṁ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṁ, ‘pubbe ceva dhammā etarahi ca sabbe te dhammā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passato uppajjati upekkhā. 
dhamma@mn137@3@mn137:15.9@ideas—their perishing, fading away, and cessation—equanimity arises as you truly understand through right understanding that both formerly and now all those ideas are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. 
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:3.2@Bahiddhā, bhikkhave, viññāṇe avikkhitte avisaṭe sati ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhite anupādāya aparitassato āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hotī”ti. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:3.2@When this is the case and they are no longer anxious, there is for them no coming to be of the origin of suffering—of rebirth, old age, and death in the future.” 
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:5.4@Bahiddhā, bhikkhave, viññāṇe avikkhitte avisaṭe sati ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhite anupādāya aparitassato āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hotī’ti. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:5.4@
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:6.5@Bahiddhā, bhikkhave, viññāṇe avikkhitte avisaṭe sati ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhite anupādāya aparitassato āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hotī’ti. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:6.5@
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:6.9@Bahiddhā, bhikkhave, viññāṇe avikkhitte avisaṭe sati ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhite anupādāya aparitassato āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hotī”ti. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:6.9@
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:9.5@‘tathā tathā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu upaparikkheyya, yathā yathā upaparikkhato bahiddhā cassa viññāṇaṁ avikkhittaṁ avisaṭaṁ ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhitaṁ anupādāya na paritasseyya, bahiddhā, bhikkhave, viññāṇe avikkhitte avisaṭe sati ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhite anupādāya aparitassato āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hotī’ti. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:9.5@‘A mendicant should examine in any such a way that their consciousness is neither scattered and diffused externally nor stuck internally, and they are not anxious because of grasping. When this is the case and they are no longer anxious, there is for them no coming to be of the origin of suffering—of rebirth, old age, and death in the future.’ 
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:15.1@Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:15.1@Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:15.2@Tassa adukkhamasukhānusāri viññāṇaṁ hoti adukkhamasukhassādagadhitaṁ adukkhamasukhassādavinibandhaṁ adukkhamasukhassādasaṁyojanasaṁyuttaṁ ajjhattaṁ cittaṁ asaṇṭhitanti vuccati. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:15.2@Their consciousness follows after that neutral feeling, tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in that neutral feeling. So their mind is said to be stuck internally. 
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:19.1@Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:19.1@Furthermore, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption … 
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:19.2@Tassa na adukkhamasukhānusāri viññāṇaṁ hoti na adukkhamasukhassādagadhitaṁ na adukkhamasukhassādavinibandhaṁ na adukkhamasukhassādasaṁyojanasaṁyuttaṁ ajjhattaṁ cittaṁ asaṇṭhitanti vuccati. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:19.2@Their consciousness doesn’t follow after that neutral feeling, and is not tied, attached, and fettered to gratification in that neutral feeling. So their mind is said to be not stuck internally. 
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:22.3@Bahiddhā, bhikkhave, viññāṇe avikkhitte avisaṭe sati ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhite anupādāya aparitassato āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hotī’ti. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:22.3@When this is the case and they are no longer anxious, there is for them no coming to be of the origin of suffering—of rebirth, old age, and death in the future.’ 
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:23.4@Bahiddhā, bhikkhave, viññāṇe avikkhitte avisaṭe sati ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhite anupādāya aparitassato āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hotī’ti. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:23.4@
dhamma@mn138@1@mn138:23.8@Bahiddhā, bhikkhave, viññāṇe avikkhitte avisaṭe sati ajjhattaṁ asaṇṭhite anupādāya aparitassato āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇadukkhasamudayasambhavo na hotīti. 
dhamma@mn138@3@mn138:23.8@
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:3.1@“Na kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na ca attakilamathānuyogamanuyuñjeyya dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ. 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:3.1@“Don’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:4.1@‘Na kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na ca attakilamathānuyogamanuyuñjeyya dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitan’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:4.1@‘Don’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:4.3@Yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogo hīno gammo pothujjaniko anariyo anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; micchāpaṭipadā. 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:4.3@Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Indulging in such happiness is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:4.4@Yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṁ ananuyogo hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; sammāpaṭipadā. 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:4.4@Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:4.5@Yo attakilamathānuyogo dukkho anariyo anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; micchāpaṭipadā. 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:4.5@Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:4.6@Yo attakilamathānuyogaṁ ananuyogo dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; sammāpaṭipadā. 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:4.6@Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:4.7@‘Na kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na ca attakilamathānuyogaṁ anuyuñjeyya dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitan’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:4.7@‘Don’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:7.2@‘Ye kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṁ anuyuttā hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:7.2@In speaking like this, some are rebuked: ‘Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. All those who indulge in such happiness are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:7.4@‘Ye kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṁ ananuyuttā hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:7.4@In speaking like this, some are flattered: ‘Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. All those who have broken off such indulgence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:7.6@‘Ye attakilamathānuyogaṁ anuyuttā dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:7.6@In speaking like this, some are rebuked: ‘Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. All those who indulge in it are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:7.8@‘Ye attakilamathānuyogaṁ ananuyuttā dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:7.8@In speaking like this, some are flattered: ‘Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. All those who have broken off such indulgence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:7.10@‘Yesaṁ kesañci bhavasaṁyojanaṁ appahīnaṁ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:7.10@In speaking like this, some are rebuked: ‘All those who have not given up the fetters of rebirth are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:7.12@‘Yesaṁ kesañci bhavasaṁyojanaṁ pahīnaṁ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:7.12@In speaking like this, some are flattered: ‘All those who have given up the fetters of rebirth are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:8.2@‘Ye kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṁ anuyuttā hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:8.2@You don’t say: ‘Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. All those who indulge in such happiness are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:8.4@‘Anuyogo ca kho sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:8.4@‘The indulgence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:8.7@‘Ye kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṁ ananuyuttā hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:8.7@You don’t say: ‘Pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. All those who have broken off such indulgence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:8.9@‘Ananuyogo ca kho adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:8.9@‘Breaking off the indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:8.12@‘Ye attakilamathānuyogaṁ anuyuttā dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:8.12@You don’t say: ‘Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. All those who indulge in it are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:8.14@‘Anuyogo ca kho sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:8.14@‘The indulgence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:8.17@‘Ye attakilamathānuyogaṁ ananuyuttā dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:8.17@You don’t say: ‘Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. All those who have broken off such indulgence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:8.19@‘Ananuyogo ca kho adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:8.19@‘Breaking off the indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:8.22@‘Yesaṁ kesañci bhavasaṁyojanaṁ appahīnaṁ, sabbe te sadukkhā saupaghātā saupāyāsā sapariḷāhā micchāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:8.22@You don’t say: ‘All those who have not given up the fetters of rebirth are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:8.26@‘Yesaṁ kesañci bhavasaṁyojanaṁ pahīnaṁ, sabbe te adukkhā anupaghātā anupāyāsā apariḷāhā sammāpaṭipannā’ti—
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:8.26@You don’t say: ‘All those who have given up the fetters of rebirth are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’ 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.1@Tatra, bhikkhave, yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogo hīno gammo pothujjaniko anariyo anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.1@Now, mendicants, pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Indulging in such happiness is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.4@Tatra, bhikkhave, yo kāmapaṭisandhisukhino somanassānuyogaṁ ananuyogo hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.4@Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.7@Tatra, bhikkhave, yo attakilamathānuyogo dukkho anariyo anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.7@Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.10@Tatra, bhikkhave, yo attakilamathānuyogaṁ ananuyogo dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.10@Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.13@Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṁ majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.13@The middle way of practice by which the Realized One was awakened gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment. It is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.16@Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṁ ussādanā ca apasādanā ca no ca dhammadesanā, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.16@Flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.19@Tatra, bhikkhave, yāyaṁ nevussādanā ca na apasādanā ca dhammadesanā ca, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.19@Neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.22@Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṁ kāmasukhaṁ mīḷhasukhaṁ pothujjanasukhaṁ anariyasukhaṁ, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.22@Sensual pleasure—a filthy, common, ignoble pleasure—is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.25@Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṁ nekkhammasukhaṁ pavivekasukhaṁ upasamasukhaṁ sambodhisukhaṁ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.25@The pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.28@Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṁ rahovādo abhūto ataccho anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.28@Saying untrue, false, and pointless things behind someone’s back is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.31@Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṁ rahovādo bhūto taccho anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.31@Saying true and correct, but pointless things behind someone’s back is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.34@Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṁ rahovādo bhūto taccho atthasaṁhito, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.34@Saying true, correct, and beneficial things behind someone’s back is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.37@Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṁ sammukhā khīṇavādo abhūto ataccho anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.37@Saying untrue, false, and pointless things in someone’s presence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.40@Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṁ sammukhā khīṇavādo bhūto taccho anatthasaṁhito, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.40@Saying true and correct, but pointless things in someone’s presence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.43@Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṁ sammukhā khīṇavādo bhūto taccho atthasaṁhito, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.43@Saying true, correct, and beneficial things in someone’s presence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.46@Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṁ taramānassa bhāsitaṁ, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.46@Speaking hurriedly is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.49@Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṁ ataramānassa bhāsitaṁ, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.49@Speaking unhurriedly is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.52@Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṁ janapadaniruttiyā ca abhiniveso samaññāya ca atisāro, sadukkho eso dhammo saupaghāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.52@Insisting on local terminology and overriding common usage is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way. 
dhamma@mn139@1@mn139:13.55@Tatra, bhikkhave, yvāyaṁ janapadaniruttiyā ca anabhiniveso samaññāya ca anatisāro, adukkho eso dhammo anupaghāto anupāyāso apariḷāho; 
dhamma@mn139@3@mn139:13.55@Not insisting on local terminology and not overriding common usage is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way. 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.3@‘Sukhan’tipi vijānāti, ‘dukkhan’tipi vijānāti, ‘adukkhamasukhan’tipi vijānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.3@It knows ‘pleasure’ and ‘pain’ and ‘neutral’. 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.7@Dukkhavedaniyaṁ, bhikkhu, phassaṁ paṭicca uppajjati dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.7@Painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful. 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.8@So dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.8@When they feel a painful feeling, they know: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’ 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.9@‘Tasseva dukkhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṁ tajjaṁ vedayitaṁ dukkhavedaniyaṁ phassaṁ paṭicca uppannā dukkhā vedanā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.9@They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, the corresponding painful feeling ceases and stops.’ 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.10@Adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṁ, bhikkhu, phassaṁ paṭicca uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.10@Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral. 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.11@So adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.11@When they feel a neutral feeling, they know: ‘I feel a neutral feeling.’ 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.12@‘Tasseva adukkhamasukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṁ tajjaṁ vedayitaṁ adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṁ phassaṁ paṭicca uppannā adukkhamasukhā vedanā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.12@They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.’ 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.17@Dukkhavedaniyaṁ, bhikkhu, phassaṁ paṭicca uppajjati dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.17@
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.18@So dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘dukkhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.18@
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.19@‘Tasseva dukkhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṁ tajjaṁ vedayitaṁ dukkhavedaniyaṁ phassaṁ paṭicca uppannā dukkhā vedanā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.19@
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.20@Adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṁ, bhikkhu, phassaṁ paṭicca uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.20@
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.21@So adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayamāno ‘adukkhamasukhaṁ vedanaṁ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.21@
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:19.22@‘Tasseva adukkhamasukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā yaṁ tajjaṁ vedayitaṁ adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṁ phassaṁ paṭicca uppannā adukkhamasukhā vedanā sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:19.22@They know: ‘With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.’ 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:23.2@Dukkhañce vedanaṁ vedeti, ‘sā aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:23.2@If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it. 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:23.3@Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṁ vedeti, ‘sā aniccā’ti pajānāti, ‘anajjhositā’ti pajānāti, ‘anabhinanditā’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:23.3@If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it. 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:24.2@dukkhañce vedanaṁ vedeti, visaṁyutto naṁ vedeti; 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:24.2@If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached. 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:24.3@adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṁ vedeti, visaṁyutto naṁ vedeti. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:24.3@If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached. 
dhamma@mn140@1@mn140:25.3@sabbadukkhakkhaye ñāṇaṁ. 
dhamma@mn140@3@mn140:25.3@the knowledge of the ending of suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:3.1@Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhasamudayassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhanirodhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:3.1@The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:9.1@Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhasamudayassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhanirodhassa ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa ācikkhanā desanā paññāpanā paṭṭhapanā vivaraṇā vibhajanā uttānīkammaṁ. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:9.1@The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:10.1@Katamañcāvuso, dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ? 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:10.1@And what is the noble truth of suffering? 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:10.2@Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, maraṇampi dukkhaṁ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ; saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:10.2@Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:14.2@Yo kho, āvuso, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa soko socanā socitattaṁ antosoko antoparisoko, 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:14.2@The sorrow, sorrowing, state of sorrow, inner sorrow, inner deep sorrow in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:15.2@Yo kho, āvuso, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa ādevo paridevo ādevanā paridevanā ādevitattaṁ paridevitattaṁ, 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:15.2@The wail, lament, wailing, lamenting, state of wailing and lamentation in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:16.1@Katamañcāvuso, dukkhaṁ? 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:16.1@And what is pain? 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:16.2@Yaṁ kho, āvuso, kāyikaṁ dukkhaṁ kāyikaṁ asātaṁ kāyasamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ, 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:16.2@Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:16.3@idaṁ vuccatāvuso: ‘dukkhaṁ’. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:16.3@This is called pain. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:17.2@Yaṁ kho, āvuso, cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ cetasikaṁ asātaṁ manosamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ, 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:17.2@Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:18.2@Yo kho, āvuso, aññataraññatarena byasanena samannāgatassa aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa āyāso upāyāso āyāsitattaṁ upāyāsitattaṁ, 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:18.2@The stress, distress, state of stress and distress in someone who has undergone misfortune, who has experienced suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:19.1@Katamañcāvuso, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ? 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:19.1@And what is ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering’? 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:19.5@Idampi: ‘yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ’. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:19.5@This is: ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:19.9@sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammānaṁ, āvuso, sattānaṁ evaṁ icchā uppajjati: 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:19.9@experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, such a wish arises: 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:19.10@‘aho vata mayaṁ na sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā assāma; na ca vata no sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā āgaccheyyun’ti. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:19.10@‘Oh, if only we were not liable to experience sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress! If only sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress would not come to us!’ 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:19.12@Idampi: ‘yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ’. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:19.12@This is: ‘not getting what you wish for is suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:20.1@Katame cāvuso, saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā? 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:20.1@And what is ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering’? 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:20.3@Ime vuccantāvuso: ‘saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā’. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:20.3@This is called ‘in brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.’ 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:20.4@Idaṁ vuccatāvuso: ‘dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ’. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:20.4@This is called the noble truth of suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:21.1@Katamañcāvuso, dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ? 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:21.1@And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering? 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:21.4@idaṁ vuccatāvuso: ‘dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ’. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:21.4@This is called the noble truth of the origin of suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:22.1@Katamañcāvuso, dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ? 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:22.1@And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering? 
dhamma@mn141@4@mn141:22.1@dukkhanirodhaṁ → dukkhanirodho (bj, sya-all, km)
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:22.3@idaṁ vuccatāvuso: ‘dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ’. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:22.3@This is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:23.1@Katamañcāvuso, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ? 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:23.1@And what is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering? 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:24.2@Yaṁ kho, āvuso, dukkhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṁ, 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:24.2@Knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@mn141@1@mn141:31.7@Idaṁ vuccatāvuso: ‘dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ’. 
dhamma@mn141@3@mn141:31.7@This is called the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@mn142@1@mn142:3.9@Bhagavantaṁ, bhante, āgamma mahāpajāpati gotamī dukkhe nikkaṅkhā, dukkhasamudaye nikkaṅkhā, dukkhanirodhe nikkaṅkhā, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya nikkaṅkhā. 
dhamma@mn142@3@mn142:3.9@It’s owing to the Buddha that she is free of doubt regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. 
dhamma@mn142@1@mn142:4.8@Yaṁ hānanda, puggalo puggalaṁ āgamma dukkhe nikkaṅkho hoti, dukkhasamudaye nikkaṅkho hoti, dukkhanirodhe nikkaṅkho hoti, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya nikkaṅkho hoti, imassānanda, puggalassa iminā puggalena na suppatikāraṁ vadāmi, yadidaṁ—
dhamma@mn142@3@mn142:4.8@When someone has enabled you to be free of doubt regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation, it’s not easy to repay them 
dhamma@mn143@1@mn143:2.1@Tena kho pana samayena anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. 
dhamma@mn143@3@mn143:2.1@Now at that time the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, suffering, gravely ill. 
dhamma@mn143@1@mn143:2.4@‘anāthapiṇḍiko, bhante, gahapati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. 
dhamma@mn143@3@mn143:2.4@‘Sir, the householder Anāthapiṇḍika is sick, suffering, gravely ill. 
dhamma@mn143@1@mn143:2.7@‘anāthapiṇḍiko, bhante, gahapati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. 
dhamma@mn143@3@mn143:2.7@‘Sir, the householder Anāthapiṇḍika is sick, suffering, gravely ill. 
dhamma@mn143@1@mn143:2.12@“anāthapiṇḍiko, bhante, gahapati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. 
dhamma@mn143@3@mn143:2.12@
dhamma@mn143@1@mn143:2.15@“anāthapiṇḍiko, bhante, gahapati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. 
dhamma@mn143@3@mn143:2.15@
dhamma@mn143@1@mn143:3.2@“kacci te, gahapati, khamanīyaṁ, kacci yāpanīyaṁ? Kacci te dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti? 
dhamma@mn143@3@mn143:3.2@“I hope you’re keeping well, householder; I hope you’re getting by. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.” 
dhamma@mn143@1@mn143:4.1@“Na me, bhante sāriputta, khamanīyaṁ na yāpanīyaṁ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo. 
dhamma@mn143@3@mn143:4.1@“I’m not keeping well, Honorable Sāriputta, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading, its growing, not its fading, is evident. 
dhamma@mn143@1@mn143:4.3@Na me, bhante sāriputta, khamanīyaṁ na yāpanīyaṁ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo. 
dhamma@mn143@3@mn143:4.3@

dhamma@mn143@3@mn143:4.7@
dhamma@mn143@1@mn143:4.9@Na me, bhante sāriputta, khamanīyaṁ na yāpanīyaṁ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti. 
dhamma@mn143@3@mn143:4.9@I’m not keeping well, Honorable Sāriputta, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading, its growing, not its fading, is evident.” 
dhamma@mn144@1@mn144:3.1@Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā channo ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. 
dhamma@mn144@3@mn144:3.1@Now at that time Venerable Channa was sick, suffering, gravely ill. 
dhamma@mn144@1@mn144:4.3@“kacci te, āvuso channa, khamanīyaṁ, kacci yāpanīyaṁ? Kacci te dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti? 
dhamma@mn144@3@mn144:4.3@“I hope you’re keeping well, Reverend Channa; I hope you’re getting by. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.” 
dhamma@mn144@1@mn144:5.1@“Na me, āvuso sāriputta, khamanīyaṁ na yāpanīyaṁ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo. 
dhamma@mn144@3@mn144:5.1@“Reverend Sāriputta, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading. 
dhamma@mn144@1@mn144:5.3@Na me, āvuso sāriputta, khamanīyaṁ na yāpanīyaṁ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṁ paññāyati no paṭikkamo.

dhamma@mn144@3@mn144:5.7@
dhamma@mn144@1@mn144:5.9@Na me, āvuso sāriputta, khamanīyaṁ na yāpanīyaṁ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo. 
dhamma@mn144@3@mn144:5.9@I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading. 
dhamma@mn144@1@mn144:11.9@Esevanto dukkhassā’”ti. 
dhamma@mn144@3@mn144:11.9@Just this is the end of suffering.’” 
dhamma@mn145@1@mn145:3.4@‘Nandīsamudayā dukkhasamudayo, puṇṇā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn145@3@mn145:3.4@Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say. 
dhamma@mn145@1@mn145:3.12@‘Nandīsamudayā dukkhasamudayo, puṇṇā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn145@3@mn145:3.12@Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say. 
dhamma@mn145@1@mn145:4.4@‘Nandīnirodhā dukkhanirodho, puṇṇā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn145@3@mn145:4.4@When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say. 
dhamma@mn145@1@mn145:4.12@‘Nandīnirodhā dukkhanirodho, puṇṇā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@mn145@3@mn145:4.12@When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say. 
dhamma@mn146@1@mn146:6.4@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti? 
dhamma@mn146@3@mn146:6.4@“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?” 
dhamma@mn146@1@mn146:6.5@“Dukkhaṁ, bhante”. 
dhamma@mn146@3@mn146:6.5@“Suffering, sir.” 
dhamma@mn146@1@mn146:6.6@“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ: 
dhamma@mn146@3@mn146:6.6@“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:28.1@Cakkhuñca, bhikkhave, paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṁ, tiṇṇaṁ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:28.1@Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for the arising of what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral. 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:28.4@Dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:28.4@When you experience a painful feeling, if you sorrow and wail and lament, beating your breast and falling into confusion, 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:28.6@Adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno tassā vedanāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:28.6@When you experience a neutral feeling, if you don’t truly understand that feeling’s origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape, 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:28.8@So vata, bhikkhave, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayaṁ appahāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayaṁ appaṭivinodetvā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayaṁ asamūhanitvā avijjaṁ appahāya vijjaṁ anuppādetvā diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro bhavissatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:28.8@Mendicants, without giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, without dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, without eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, without giving up ignorance and without giving rise to knowledge, it’s quite impossible to make an end of suffering in the present life. 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:29-33.5@manañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṁ, tiṇṇaṁ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:29-33.5@Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for the arising of what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral. 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:29-33.8@Dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:29-33.8@When you experience a painful feeling, if you sorrow and wail and lament, beating your breast and falling into confusion, 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:29-33.10@Adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno tassā vedanāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:29-33.10@When you experience a neutral feeling, if you don’t truly understand that feeling’s origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape, 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:29-33.12@So vata, bhikkhave, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayaṁ appahāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayaṁ appaṭivinodetvā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayaṁ asamūhanitvā avijjaṁ appahāya vijjaṁ anuppādetvā diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro bhavissatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:29-33.12@Mendicants, without giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, without dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, without eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, without giving up ignorance and without giving rise to knowledge, it’s quite impossible to make an end of suffering in the present life. 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:34.1@Cakkhuñca, bhikkhave, paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṁ, tiṇṇaṁ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:34.1@Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for the arising of what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral. 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:34.4@Dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati na kilamati na paridevati na urattāḷiṁ kandati na sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:34.4@When you experience a painful feeling, if you don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating your breast and falling into confusion, 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:34.6@Adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno tassā vedanāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:34.6@When you experience a neutral feeling, if you truly understand that feeling’s origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape, 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:34.8@So vata, bhikkhave, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayaṁ pahāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayaṁ paṭivinodetvā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayaṁ samūhanitvā avijjaṁ pahāya vijjaṁ uppādetvā diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro bhavissatīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:34.8@Mendicants, after giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, after dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, after eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, after giving up ignorance and giving rise to knowledge, it’s quite possible to make an end of suffering in the present life. 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:39.1@“Manañca, bhikkhave, paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṁ tiṇṇaṁ saṅgati phasso, phassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:39.1@Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral. 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:39.4@Dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati na kilamati na paridevati na urattāḷiṁ kandati na sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:39.4@When you experience a painful feeling, if you don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating your breast and falling into confusion,

dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:39.6@When you experience a neutral feeling, if you truly understand that feeling’s origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape, 
dhamma@mn148@1@mn148:39.8@So vata, bhikkhave, sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayaṁ pahāya dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayaṁ paṭivinodetvā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayaṁ samūhanitvā avijjaṁ pahāya vijjaṁ uppādetvā diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro bhavissatīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati. 
dhamma@mn148@3@mn148:39.8@Mendicants, after giving up the underlying tendency to greed for pleasant feeling, after dispelling the underlying tendency to repulsion towards painful feeling, after eradicating ignorance in the case of neutral feeling, after giving up ignorance and giving rise to knowledge, it’s quite possible to make an end of suffering in the present life. 
dhamma@mn149@1@mn149:3.1@“Cakkhuṁ, bhikkhave, ajānaṁ apassaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, rūpe ajānaṁ apassaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, cakkhuviññāṇaṁ ajānaṁ apassaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, cakkhusamphassaṁ ajānaṁ apassaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, yamidaṁ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi ajānaṁ apassaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, cakkhusmiṁ sārajjati, rūpesu sārajjati, cakkhuviññāṇe sārajjati, cakkhusamphasse sārajjati, yamidaṁ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tasmimpi sārajjati. 
dhamma@mn149@3@mn149:3.1@“Mendicants, when you don’t truly know and see the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises conditioned by eye contact, you’re aroused by these things. 
dhamma@mn149@1@mn149:3.7@So kāyadukkhampi cetodukkhampi paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@mn149@3@mn149:3.7@And they experience physical and mental suffering. 
dhamma@mn149@4@mn149:3.7@kāyadukkhampi → kāyikadukkhampi (sya-all, km); kāyikaṁ dukkhampi (mr) 
dhamma@mn149@1@mn149:4-7.5@manaṁ, bhikkhave, ajānaṁ apassaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, dhamme, bhikkhave, ajānaṁ apassaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, manoviññāṇaṁ, bhikkhave, ajānaṁ apassaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, manosamphassaṁ, bhikkhave, ajānaṁ apassaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, yamidaṁ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi ajānaṁ apassaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, manasmiṁ sārajjati, dhammesu sārajjati, manoviññāṇe sārajjati, manosamphasse sārajjati, yamidaṁ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tasmimpi sārajjati. 
dhamma@mn149@3@mn149:4-7.5@mind, ideas, mind consciousness, mind contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises conditioned by mind contact, you’re aroused by these things. 
dhamma@mn149@1@mn149:8.6@So kāyadukkhampi cetodukkhampi paṭisaṁvedeti. 
dhamma@mn149@3@mn149:8.6@And they experience physical and mental suffering. 
dhamma@mn149@1@mn149:9.1@Cakkhuñca kho, bhikkhave, jānaṁ passaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, rūpe jānaṁ passaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, cakkhuviññāṇaṁ jānaṁ passaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, cakkhusamphassaṁ jānaṁ passaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, yamidaṁ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi jānaṁ passaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, cakkhusmiṁ na sārajjati, rūpesu na sārajjati, cakkhuviññāṇe na sārajjati, cakkhusamphasse na sārajjati, yamidaṁ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tasmimpi na sārajjati. 
dhamma@mn149@3@mn149:9.1@When you do truly know and see the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises conditioned by eye contact, you’re not aroused by these things. 
dhamma@mn149@1@mn149:12-18.5@manaṁ, bhikkhave, jānaṁ passaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, dhamme jānaṁ passaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, manoviññāṇaṁ jānaṁ passaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, manosamphassaṁ jānaṁ passaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, yamidaṁ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi jānaṁ passaṁ yathābhūtaṁ, manasmiṁ na sārajjati, dhammesu na sārajjati, manoviññāṇe na sārajjati, manosamphasse na sārajjati, yamidaṁ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tasmimpi na sārajjati. 
dhamma@mn149@3@mn149:12-18.5@mind, ideas, mind consciousness, mind contact, and what is felt as pleasant, painful, or neutral that arises conditioned by mind contact, you are not aroused by these things. … 
vinaya@pli-tv-bi-pm@1@pli-tv-bi-pm:28.4@“māyye kupitā anattamanā evaṁ avaca ‘buddhaṁ paccācikkhāmi, dhammaṁ paccācikkhāmi, saṅghaṁ paccācikkhāmi, sikkhaṁ paccācikkhāmi, kinnumāva samaṇiyo yā samaṇiyo sakyadhītaro, santaññāpi samaṇiyo lajjiniyo kukkuccikā sikkhākāmā, tāsāhaṁ santike brahmacariyaṁ carissāmī’ti, abhiramāyye, svākkhāto dhammo, cara brahmacariyaṁ sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti, 
vinaya@pli-tv-bi-pm@3@pli-tv-bi-pm:28.4@‘Venerable, don’t say such things in anger, I renounce the Buddha, I renounce the Teaching, I renounce the Sangha, I renounce the training! The Sakyan daughters are not the only monastics. There are other monastics who have a sense of conscience, who are afraid of wrongdoing and fond of the training. I’ll practice the spiritual life with them.’ Take delight, Venerable; the Teaching is well proclaimed. Practice the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering.’ 
vinaya@pli-tv-bi-pm@1@pli-tv-bi-pm:103.1@Yā pana bhikkhunī dukkhitaṁ sahajīviniṁ neva upaṭṭhaheyya, na upaṭṭhāpanāya ussukkaṁ kareyya, pācittiyaṁ. 
vinaya@pli-tv-bi-pm@3@pli-tv-bi-pm:103.1@If a nun neither nurses a suffering disciple, nor makes any effort to have someone else nurse her, she commits an offense entailing confession. 
vinaya@pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34@1@pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34:1.2@Tena kho pana samayena thullanandā bhikkhunī dukkhitaṁ sahajīviniṁ neva upaṭṭheti na upaṭṭhāpanāya ussukkaṁ karoti. 
vinaya@pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34@3@pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34:1.2@At that time a disciple of the nun Thullanandā was suffering, but Thullanandā neither nursed her nor made any effort to have someone else nurse her. 
vinaya@pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34@1@pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34:1.4@“kathañhi nāma ayyā thullanandā dukkhitaṁ sahajīviniṁ neva upaṭṭhessati na upaṭṭhāpanāya ussukkaṁ karissatī”ti …pe… 
vinaya@pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34@3@pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34:1.4@“How could Venerable Thullanandā not nurse a suffering disciple, nor make any effort to have someone else nurse her?” …

vinaya@pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34@3@pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34:1.5@“Is it true, monks, that the nun Thullanandā didn’t do this?”

dhamma@sn12.10@1@sn12.10:1.4@Kudāssu nāma imassa dukkhassa nissaraṇaṁ paññāyissati jarāmaraṇassā’ti? 
dhamma@sn12.10@3@sn12.10:1.4@Oh, when will an escape be found from this suffering, from old age and death?’ 
dhamma@sn12.10@1@sn12.10:4.3@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@sn12.10@3@sn12.10:4.3@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@sn12.10@1@sn12.10:7.3@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti. 
dhamma@sn12.10@3@sn12.10:7.3@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases. 
dhamma@sn12.11@1@sn12.11:3.3@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@sn12.11@3@sn12.11:3.3@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@sn12.11@1@sn12.11:3.6@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.11@3@sn12.11:3.6@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
dhamma@sn12.12@1@sn12.12:6.12@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@sn12.12@3@sn12.12:6.12@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@sn12.12@1@sn12.12:7.7@jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti. 
dhamma@sn12.12@3@sn12.12:7.7@When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. 
dhamma@sn12.12@1@sn12.12:7.8@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.12@3@sn12.12:7.8@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
dhamma@sn12.15@1@sn12.15:2.6@‘Dukkhameva uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, dukkhaṁ nirujjhamānaṁ nirujjhatī’ti na kaṅkhati na vicikicchati aparapaccayā ñāṇamevassa ettha hoti. 
dhamma@sn12.15@3@sn12.15:2.6@you’ll have no doubt or uncertainty that what arises is just suffering arising, and what ceases is just suffering ceasing. Your knowledge about this is independent of others. 
dhamma@sn12.15@1@sn12.15:3.6@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@sn12.15@3@sn12.15:3.6@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@sn12.15@1@sn12.15:3.9@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī’”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.15@3@sn12.15:3.9@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’”
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.1@“Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, ‘sayaṅkataṁ dukkhan’ti? 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.1@“Well, Master Gotama, is suffering made by oneself?” 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.3@‘Kiṁ pana, bho gotama, paraṅkataṁ dukkhan’ti? 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.3@“Then is suffering made by another?” 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.5@‘Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca dukkhan’ti? 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.5@“Well, is suffering made by both oneself and another?” 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.7@‘Kiṁ pana, bho gotama, asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhan’ti? 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.7@“Then does suffering arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?” 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.9@‘Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, natthi dukkhan’ti? 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.9@“Well, is there no such thing as suffering?” 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.10@‘Na kho, kassapa, natthi dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.10@“It’s not that there’s no such thing as suffering. 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.11@Atthi kho, kassapa, dukkhan’ti. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.11@Suffering is real.” 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.12@‘Tena hi bhavaṁ gotamo dukkhaṁ na jānāti, na passatī’ti. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.12@“Then Master Gotama doesn’t know nor see suffering.” 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.13@‘Na khvāhaṁ, kassapa, dukkhaṁ na jānāmi, na passāmi. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.13@“It’s not that I don’t know or see suffering. 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.14@Jānāmi khvāhaṁ, kassapa, dukkhaṁ; 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.14@I do know suffering, 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:3.15@passāmi khvāhaṁ, kassapa, dukkhan’”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:3.15@I do see suffering.” 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:4.1@“Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, ‘sayaṅkataṁ dukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṁ, kassapā’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:4.1@“Master Gotama, when asked these questions, you say ‘not so’. 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:4.2@‘Kiṁ pana, bho gotama, paraṅkataṁ dukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṁ, kassapā’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:4.2@
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:4.3@‘Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca dukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṁ, kassapā’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:4.3@
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:4.4@‘Kiṁ pana, bho gotama, asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṁ, kassapā’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:4.4@
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:4.5@‘Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, natthi dukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘na kho, kassapa, natthi dukkhaṁ, atthi kho, kassapa, dukkhan’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:4.5@Yet you say that there is such a thing as suffering. 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:4.6@‘Tena hi bhavaṁ gotamo dukkhaṁ na jānāti na passatī’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘na khvāhaṁ, kassapa, dukkhaṁ na jānāmi na passāmi. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:4.6@
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:4.7@Jānāmi khvāhaṁ, kassapa, dukkhaṁ; 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:4.7@And you say that you do know suffering, 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:4.8@passāmi khvāhaṁ, kassapa, dukkhan’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:4.8@and you do see suffering. 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:4.9@Ācikkhatu ca me, bhante, bhagavā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:4.9@Sir, explain suffering to me! 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:4.10@Desetu ca me, bhante, bhagavā dukkhan”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:4.10@Teach me about suffering!” 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:5.1@“‘So karoti so paṭisaṁvedayatī’ti kho, kassapa, ādito sato ‘sayaṅkataṁ dukkhan’ti iti vadaṁ sassataṁ etaṁ pareti. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:5.1@“Suppose that the person who does the deed experiences the result. Then for one who has existed since the beginning, suffering is made by oneself. This statement leans toward eternalism. 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:5.2@‘Añño karoti añño paṭisaṁvedayatī’ti kho, kassapa, vedanābhitunnassa sato ‘paraṅkataṁ dukkhan’ti iti vadaṁ ucchedaṁ etaṁ pareti. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:5.2@Suppose that one person does the deed and another experiences the result. Then for one stricken by feeling, suffering is made by another. This statement leans toward annihilationism. 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:5.6@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:5.6@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@sn12.17@1@sn12.17:5.9@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī’”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.17@3@sn12.17:5.9@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’” 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.1@“Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhanti? 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.1@“Well, Master Gotama, are pleasure and pain made by oneself?” 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.3@Kiṁ pana, bho gotama, paraṅkataṁ sukhadukkhanti? 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.3@“Then are pleasure and pain made by another?” 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.5@Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca sukhadukkhanti? 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.5@“Well, are pleasure and pain made by both oneself and another?” 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.7@Kiṁ pana, bho gotama, asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ sukhadukkhanti? 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.7@“Then do pleasure and pain arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?” 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.9@Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, natthi sukhadukkhanti? 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.9@“Well, is there no such thing as pleasure and pain?” 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.10@Na kho, timbaruka, natthi sukhadukkhaṁ; 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.10@“It’s not that there’s no such thing as pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.11@atthi kho, timbaruka, sukhadukkhanti. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.11@Pleasure and pain are real.” 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.12@Tena hi bhavaṁ gotamo sukhadukkhaṁ na jānāti, na passatīti? 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.12@“Then Master Gotama doesn’t know nor see pleasure and pain.” 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.13@Na khvāhaṁ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhaṁ na jānāmi, na passāmi. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.13@“It’s not that I don’t know or see pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.14@Jānāmi khvāhaṁ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhaṁ; 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.14@I do know pleasure and pain, 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:2.15@passāmi khvāhaṁ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhan”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:2.15@I do see pleasure and pain.” 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.1@“‘Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṁ, timbarukā’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.1@“Master Gotama, when asked these questions, you say ‘not so’. 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.2@‘Kiṁ pana, bho gotama, paraṅkataṁ sukhadukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṁ, timbarukā’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.2@
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.3@‘Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca sukhadukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṁ, timbarukā’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.3@
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.4@‘Kiṁ pana, bho gotama, asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ sukhadukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṁ, timbarukā’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.4@
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.5@‘Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, natthi sukhadukkhan’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘na kho, timbaruka, natthi sukhadukkhaṁ; 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.5@Yet you say that there is such a thing as pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.6@atthi kho, timbaruka, sukhadukkhan’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.6@
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.7@‘Tena hi bhavaṁ gotamo sukhadukkhaṁ na jānāti, na passatī’ti iti puṭṭho samāno ‘na khvāhaṁ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhaṁ na jānāmi, na passāmi. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.7@
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.8@Jānāmi khvāhaṁ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhaṁ; 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.8@And you say that you do know pleasure and pain, 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.9@passāmi khvāhaṁ, timbaruka, sukhadukkhan’ti vadesi. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.9@and you do see pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.10@Ācikkhatu ca me bhavaṁ gotamo sukhadukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.10@Sir, explain pleasure and pain to me! 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:3.11@Desetu ca me bhavaṁ gotamo sukhadukkhan”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:3.11@Teach me about pleasure and pain!” 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:4.1@“‘Sā vedanā, so vedayatī’ti kho, timbaruka, ādito sato ‘sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhan’ti evampāhaṁ na vadāmi. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:4.1@“Suppose that the feeling and the one who feels it are the same thing. Then for one who has existed since the beginning, pleasure and pain is made by oneself. I don’t say this. 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:4.2@‘Aññā vedanā, añño vedayatī’ti kho, timbaruka, vedanābhitunnassa sato ‘paraṅkataṁ sukhadukkhan’ti evampāhaṁ na vadāmi. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:4.2@Suppose that the feeling is one thing and the one who feels it is another. Then for one stricken by feeling, pleasure and pain is made by another. I don’t say this. 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:4.6@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:4.6@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@sn12.18@1@sn12.18:4.9@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī’”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.18@3@sn12.18:4.9@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’” 
dhamma@sn12.19@1@sn12.19:1.3@Iti ayañceva kāyo bahiddhā ca nāmarūpaṁ, itthetaṁ dvayaṁ, dvayaṁ paṭicca phasso saḷevāyatanāni, yehi phuṭṭho bālo sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedayati etesaṁ vā aññatarena. 
dhamma@sn12.19@3@sn12.19:1.3@So there is the duality of this body and external name and form. Contact depends on this duality. When contacted through one or other of the six sense fields, the fool experiences pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@sn12.19@1@sn12.19:2.2@Iti ayañceva kāyo bahiddhā ca nāmarūpaṁ, itthetaṁ dvayaṁ, dvayaṁ paṭicca phasso saḷevāyatanāni, yehi phuṭṭho paṇḍito sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedayati etesaṁ vā aññatarena. 
dhamma@sn12.19@3@sn12.19:2.2@So there is the duality of this body and external name and form. Contact depends on this duality. When contacted through one or other of the six sense fields, the astute person experiences pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@sn12.19@1@sn12.19:5.3@Na, bhikkhave, bālo acari brahmacariyaṁ sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@sn12.19@3@sn12.19:5.3@The fool has not completed the spiritual journey for the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@sn12.19@1@sn12.19:5.5@so kāyūpago samāno na parimuccati jātiyā jarāmaraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi. 
dhamma@sn12.19@3@sn12.19:5.5@When reborn in another body, they’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@sn12.19@1@sn12.19:5.6@Na parimuccati dukkhasmāti vadāmi. 
dhamma@sn12.19@3@sn12.19:5.6@They’re not freed from suffering, I say. 
dhamma@sn12.19@1@sn12.19:6.3@Acari, bhikkhave, paṇḍito brahmacariyaṁ sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@sn12.19@3@sn12.19:6.3@The astute person has completed the spiritual journey for the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@sn12.19@1@sn12.19:6.5@So akāyūpago samāno parimuccati jātiyā jarāmaraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi. 
dhamma@sn12.19@3@sn12.19:6.5@Not being reborn in another body, they’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. 
dhamma@sn12.19@1@sn12.19:6.6@Parimuccati dukkhasmāti vadāmi. 
dhamma@sn12.19@3@sn12.19:6.6@They’re freed from suffering, I say. 
dhamma@sn12.21@1@sn12.21:1.12@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@sn12.21@3@sn12.21:1.12@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@sn12.21@1@sn12.21:1.15@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.21@3@sn12.21:1.15@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
dhamma@sn12.22@1@sn12.22:1.12@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti. 
dhamma@sn12.22@3@sn12.22:1.12@That is how this entire mass of suffering originates. 
dhamma@sn12.22@1@sn12.22:1.15@evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti’. 
dhamma@sn12.22@3@sn12.22:1.15@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases. 
dhamma@sn12.22@1@sn12.22:3.1@Dukkhaṁ, bhikkhave, kusīto viharati vokiṇṇo pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehi, mahantañca sadatthaṁ parihāpeti. 
dhamma@sn12.22@3@sn12.22:3.1@A lazy person lives in suffering, mixed up with bad, unskillful qualities, and ruins a great deal of their own good. 
dhamma@sn12.23@1@sn12.23:4.2@‘Dukkhan’tissa vacanīyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn12.23@3@sn12.23:4.2@You should say: ‘Suffering.’ 
dhamma@sn12.23@1@sn12.23:4.3@Dukkhampāhaṁ, bhikkhave, saupanisaṁ vadāmi, no anupanisaṁ. 
dhamma@sn12.23@3@sn12.23:4.3@I say that suffering has a vital condition. 
dhamma@sn12.23@1@sn12.23:4.4@Kā ca, bhikkhave, dukkhassa upanisā? 
dhamma@sn12.23@3@sn12.23:4.4@And what is it? 
dhamma@sn12.23@1@sn12.23:6.11@jātūpanisaṁ dukkhaṁ, 
dhamma@sn12.23@3@sn12.23:6.11@Rebirth is a vital condition for suffering. 
dhamma@sn12.23@1@sn12.23:6.12@dukkhūpanisā saddhā, 
dhamma@sn12.23@3@sn12.23:6.12@Suffering is a vital condition for faith. 
dhamma@sn12.23@1@sn12.23:8.1@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, avijjūpanisā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārūpanisaṁ viññāṇaṁ, viññāṇūpanisaṁ nāmarūpaṁ, nāmarūpūpanisaṁ saḷāyatanaṁ, saḷāyatanūpaniso phasso, phassūpanisā vedanā, vedanūpanisā taṇhā, taṇhūpanisaṁ upādānaṁ, upādānūpaniso bhavo, bhavūpanisā jāti, jātūpanisaṁ dukkhaṁ, dukkhūpanisā saddhā, saddhūpanisaṁ pāmojjaṁ, pāmojjūpanisā pīti, pītūpanisā passaddhi, passaddhūpanisaṁ sukhaṁ, sukhūpaniso samādhi, samādhūpanisaṁ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṁ, yathābhūtañāṇadassanūpanisā nibbidā, nibbidūpaniso virāgo, virāgūpanisā vimutti, vimuttūpanisaṁ khaye ñāṇan”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.23@3@sn12.23:8.1@In the same way, ignorance is a vital condition for choices. … Freedom is a vital condition for the knowledge of ending.”
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:3.1@“Santāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:3.1@“Reverend Sāriputta, there are ascetics and brahmins who teach the efficacy of deeds. Some of them declare that suffering is made by oneself. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:3.2@Santi panāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā paraṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:3.2@Some of them declare that suffering is made by another. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:3.3@Santāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca dukkhaṁ paññapenti. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:3.3@Some of them declare that suffering is made by both oneself and another. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:3.4@Santi panāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:3.4@Some of them declare that suffering arises by chance, not made by oneself or another. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:4.1@“Paṭiccasamuppannaṁ kho, āvuso, dukkhaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:4.1@“Reverends, the Buddha said that suffering is dependently originated. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:5.1@Tatrāvuso, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:5.1@Consider the ascetics and brahmins who teach the efficacy of deeds. In the case of those who declare that suffering is made by oneself, that’s conditioned by contact. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:5.2@Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā paraṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:5.2@In the case of those who declare that suffering is made by another, that’s also conditioned by contact. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:5.3@Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:5.3@In the case of those who declare that suffering is made by oneself and another, that’s also conditioned by contact. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:5.4@Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti tadapi phassapaccayā. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:5.4@In the case of those who declare that suffering arises by chance, not made by oneself or another, that’s also conditioned by contact. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:6.1@Tatrāvuso, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:6.1@Consider the ascetics and brahmins who teach the efficacy of deeds. In the case of those who declare that suffering is made by oneself, it’s impossible that they will experience that without contact. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:6.2@Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā paraṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:6.2@In the case of those who declare that suffering is made by another, it’s impossible that they will experience that without contact. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:6.3@Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:6.3@In the case of those who declare that suffering is made by oneself and another, it’s impossible that they will experience that without contact. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:6.4@Yepi te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti, te vata aññatra phassā paṭisaṁvedissantīti netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī”ti. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:6.4@In the case of those who declare that suffering arises by chance, not made by oneself or another, it’s impossible that they will experience that without contact.” 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:8.2@Paṭiccasamuppannaṁ kho, ānanda, dukkhaṁ vuttaṁ mayā.

dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:10.4@In the case of those who declare that suffering arises by chance, not made by oneself or another, it’s impossible that they will experience that without contact. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:13.1@‘Santāvuso gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:13.1@(The wanderers asked the Buddha the very same questions, and he gave the same answers.) 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:13.2@Santi panāvuso gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā paraṅkataṁ dukkhaṁ paññapenti.

dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:16.4@
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:21.15@jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:21.15@When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease. 
dhamma@sn12.24@1@sn12.24:21.16@Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotī’ti. 
dhamma@sn12.24@3@sn12.24:21.16@That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’ 
dhamma@sn12.25@1@sn12.25:2.1@“Santāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti. 
dhamma@sn12.25@3@sn12.25:2.1@“Reverend Sāriputta, there are ascetics and brahmins who teach the efficacy of deeds. Some of them declare that pleasure and pain are made by oneself. 
dhamma@sn12.25@1@sn12.25:2.2@Santi panāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā paraṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti. 
dhamma@sn12.25@3@sn12.25:2.2@Some of them declare that pleasure and pain are made by another. 
dhamma@sn12.25@1@sn12.25:2.3@Santāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti. 
dhamma@sn12.25@3@sn12.25:2.3@Some of them declare that pleasure and pain are made by both oneself and another. 
dhamma@sn12.25@1@sn12.25:2.4@Santi panāvuso sāriputta, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā asayaṅkāraṁ aparaṅkāraṁ adhiccasamuppannaṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti. 
dhamma@sn12.25@3@sn12.25:2.4@Some of them declare that pleasure and pain arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.

dhamma@sn12.25@3@sn12.25:3.1@“Reverend, the Buddha said that pleasure and pain are dependently originated. 
dhamma@sn12.25@1@sn12.25:4.1@Tatrāvuso, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā kammavādā sayaṅkataṁ sukhadukkhaṁ paññapenti, tadapi phassapaccayā.

dhamma@sn12.25@3@sn12.25:4.4@In the case of those who declare that pleasure and pain arise by chance, not made by oneself or another, that’s also conditioned by contact.

dhamma@sn12.25@3@sn12.25:5.4@In the case of those who declare that pleasure and pain arise by chance, not made by oneself or another, it’s impossible that they will experience that without contact.”
