dhamma@sn35.223@1@sn35.223:0.3@Ajjhattāyatanadukkhasutta 
dhamma@sn35.223@3@sn35.223:0.3@The Interior as Suffering 
dhamma@sn35.223@1@sn35.223:1.1@“Cakkhu, bhikkhave, dukkhaṁ …pe… jivhā dukkhā …pe… mano dukkho. 
dhamma@sn35.223@3@sn35.223:1.1@“Mendicants, the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are suffering. 
dhamma@sn35.226@1@sn35.226:0.3@Bāhirāyatanadukkhasutta 
dhamma@sn35.226@3@sn35.226:0.3@The Exterior as Suffering 
dhamma@sn35.226@1@sn35.226:1.1@“Rūpā, bhikkhave, dukkhā. Saddā … gandhā … rasā … phoṭṭhabbā … dhammā dukkhā. 
dhamma@sn35.226@3@sn35.226:1.1@“Mendicants, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas are suffering. 
dhamma@sn35.229@1@sn35.229:4.2@Pahāsi dukkhaṁ apunabbhavāya; 
dhamma@sn35.229@3@sn35.229:4.2@They’ve given up suffering, so there are no more future lives. 
dhamma@sn35.232@1@sn35.232:6.1@Cakkhu vā, āvuso, rūpānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ abhavissa, rūpā vā cakkhussa saṁyojanaṁ, nayidaṁ brahmacariyavāso paññāyetha sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@sn35.232@3@sn35.232:6.1@If the eye were the fetter of sights, or if sights were the fetter of the eye, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering would not be found. 
dhamma@sn35.232@1@sn35.232:6.3@yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ, tasmā brahmacariyavāso paññāyati sammā dukkhakkhayāya …pe…. 
dhamma@sn35.232@3@sn35.232:6.3@the fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering is found. 
dhamma@sn35.232@1@sn35.232:7.1@Jivhā, āvuso, rasānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ abhavissa, rasā vā jivhāya saṁyojanaṁ, nayidaṁ brahmacariyavāso paññāyetha sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@sn35.232@3@sn35.232:7.1@If the ear … nose … tongue … body … 
dhamma@sn35.232@1@sn35.232:7.2@Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, na jivhā rasānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ, na rasā jivhāya saṁyojanaṁ; yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ, tasmā brahmacariyavāso paññāyati sammā dukkhakkhayāya …pe…. 
dhamma@sn35.232@3@sn35.232:7.2@
dhamma@sn35.232@1@sn35.232:8.1@Mano vā, āvuso, dhammānaṁ saṁyojanaṁ abhavissa, dhammā vā manassa saṁyojanaṁ, nayidaṁ brahmacariyavāso paññāyetha sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@sn35.232@3@sn35.232:8.1@mind were the fetter of ideas, or if ideas were the fetter of the mind, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering would not be found. 
dhamma@sn35.232@1@sn35.232:8.3@yañca tattha tadubhayaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo, taṁ tattha saṁyojanaṁ, tasmā brahmacariyavāso paññāyati sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@sn35.232@3@sn35.232:8.3@the fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering is found. 
dhamma@sn35.235@1@sn35.235:7.4@iti cakkhu aniccaṁ, rūpā aniccā, cakkhuviññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ, cakkhusamphasso anicco, yampidaṁ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi aniccaṁ’. 
dhamma@sn35.235@3@sn35.235:7.4@the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also impermanent. 
dhamma@sn35.235@1@sn35.235:8.3@iti sotaṁ aniccaṁ, saddā aniccā, sotaviññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ, sotasamphasso anicco, yampidaṁ sotasamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi aniccaṁ. 
dhamma@sn35.235@3@sn35.235:8.3@the ear, sounds, ear consciousness, and ear contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by ear contact is also impermanent. 
dhamma@sn35.235@1@sn35.235:12.3@iti mano anicco, dhammā aniccā, manoviññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ, manosamphasso anicco, yampidaṁ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi aniccaṁ”. 
dhamma@sn35.235@3@sn35.235:12.3@the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and mind contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also impermanent.’ 
dhamma@sn35.235@1@sn35.235:13.2@yampidaṁ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tasmimpi nibbindati. 
dhamma@sn35.235@3@sn35.235:13.2@They grow disillusioned with the ear … nose … tongue … body … mind … painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact. 
dhamma@sn35.236@1@sn35.236:1.5@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusmiṁ sati cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ …pe… 
dhamma@sn35.236@3@sn35.236:1.5@In the same way, when there’s an eye, pleasure and pain arise internally conditioned by eye contact. 
dhamma@sn35.236@1@sn35.236:1.6@jivhāya sati jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ …pe… 
dhamma@sn35.236@3@sn35.236:1.6@When there’s an ear … nose … tongue … body … 
dhamma@sn35.236@1@sn35.236:1.7@manasmiṁ sati manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ …pe…. 
dhamma@sn35.236@3@sn35.236:1.7@mind, pleasure and pain arise internally conditioned by mind contact. 
dhamma@sn35.236@1@sn35.236:2.5@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusmiṁ asati cakkhusamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ …pe… 
dhamma@sn35.236@3@sn35.236:2.5@In the same way, when there’s no eye, pleasure and pain don’t arise internally conditioned by eye contact. 
dhamma@sn35.236@1@sn35.236:2.7@manasmiṁ asati manosamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhan”ti. 
dhamma@sn35.236@3@sn35.236:2.7@mind, pleasure and pain don’t arise internally conditioned by mind contact.”
dhamma@sn35.237@1@sn35.237:1.5@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusmiṁ sati cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ …pe… 
dhamma@sn35.237@3@sn35.237:1.5@In the same way, when there’s an eye, pleasure and pain arise internally conditioned by eye contact. 
dhamma@sn35.237@1@sn35.237:1.7@manasmiṁ sati manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ …pe…. 
dhamma@sn35.237@3@sn35.237:1.7@mind, pleasure and pain arise internally conditioned by mind contact. 
dhamma@sn35.237@1@sn35.237:2.5@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cakkhusmiṁ asati cakkhusamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhaṁ …pe… 
dhamma@sn35.237@3@sn35.237:2.5@In the same way, when there’s no eye, pleasure and pain don’t arise internally conditioned by eye contact. 
dhamma@sn35.237@1@sn35.237:2.7@manasmiṁ asati manosamphassapaccayā nuppajjati ajjhattaṁ sukhaṁ dukkhan”ti. 
dhamma@sn35.237@3@sn35.237:2.7@mind, pleasure and pain don’t arise internally conditioned by mind contact.” 
dhamma@sn35.238@1@sn35.238:1.2@Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo. 
dhamma@sn35.238@3@sn35.238:1.2@Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain. 
dhamma@sn35.238@1@sn35.238:1.5@Yadā ca kho te, ambho purisa, imesaṁ catunnaṁ āsīvisānaṁ uggatejānaṁ ghoravisānaṁ aññataro vā aññataro vā kuppissati, tato tvaṁ, ambho purisa, maraṇaṁ vā nigacchasi, maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ. 
dhamma@sn35.238@3@sn35.238:1.5@But when one or other of these four poisonous vipers gets angry with you, you’ll meet with death or deadly pain. 
dhamma@sn35.241@1@sn35.241:4.2@Idha, bhikkhu, gihīhi saṁsaṭṭho viharati, sahanandī sahasokī, sukhitesu sukhito, dukkhitesu dukkhito, uppannesu kiccakaraṇīyesu attanā tesu yogaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@sn35.241@3@sn35.241:4.2@It’s when someone mixes closely with laypeople, sharing their joys and sorrows—happy when they’re happy and sad when they’re sad—and getting involved in their business. 
dhamma@sn35.243@1@sn35.243:5.18@Ayaṁ vuccatāvuso, bhikkhu rūpādhibhūto, saddādhibhūto, gandhādhibhūto, rasādhibhūto, phoṭṭhabbādhibhūto, dhammādhibhūto, adhibhūto, anadhibhū, adhibhaṁsu naṁ pāpakā akusalā dhammā saṅkilesikā ponobhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā. 
dhamma@sn35.243@3@sn35.243:5.18@This is called a mendicant who has been mastered by sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas. They’re mastered, not a master. Bad, unskillful qualities have mastered them, which are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, and resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@sn35.243@1@sn35.243:7.17@Ayaṁ vuccatāvuso, bhikkhu rūpādhibhū, saddādhibhū, gandhādhibhū, rasādhibhū, phoṭṭhabbādhibhū, dhammādhibhū, adhibhū, anadhibhūto, adhibhosi te pāpake akusale dhamme saṅkilesike ponobhavike sadare dukkhavipāke āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiye. 
dhamma@sn35.243@3@sn35.243:7.17@This is called a mendicant who has mastered sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas. They’re a master, not mastered. Bad, unskillful qualities have been mastered by them, which are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, and resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. 
dhamma@sn35.244@1@sn35.244:0.3@Dukkhadhammasutta 
dhamma@sn35.244@3@sn35.244:0.3@Entailing Suffering 
dhamma@sn35.244@1@sn35.244:1.1@“Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbesaṁyeva dukkhadhammānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@sn35.244@3@sn35.244:1.1@“Mendicants, when a mendicant truly understands the origin and ending of all things that entail suffering, 
dhamma@sn35.244@1@sn35.244:2.1@Kathañca, bhikkhave, sabbesaṁyeva dukkhadhammānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti? 
dhamma@sn35.244@3@sn35.244:2.1@And how does a mendicant truly understand the origin and ending of all things that entail suffering? 
dhamma@sn35.244@1@sn35.244:2.7@evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabbesaṁyeva dukkhadhammānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti. 
dhamma@sn35.244@3@sn35.244:2.7@That’s how a mendicant truly understands the origin and ending of all things that entail suffering. 
dhamma@sn35.244@1@sn35.244:3.2@Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, aṅgārakāsu sādhikaporisā puṇṇā aṅgārānaṁ vītaccikānaṁ vītadhūmānaṁ. Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhapaṭikūlo. Tamenaṁ dve balavanto purisā nānābāhāsu gahetvā, taṁ aṅgārakāsuṁ upakaḍḍheyyuṁ. So iticīticeva kāyaṁ sannāmeyya. 
dhamma@sn35.244@3@sn35.244:3.2@Suppose there was a pit of glowing coals deeper than a man’s height, filled with glowing coals that neither flamed nor smoked. Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain. Then two strong men would grab each arm and drag them towards the pit of glowing coals. They’d writhe and struggle to and fro. 
dhamma@sn35.244@1@sn35.244:3.4@Ñātañhi, bhikkhave, tassa purisassa imañcāhaṁ aṅgārakāsuṁ papatissāmi, tatonidānaṁ maraṇaṁ vā nigacchissāmi maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhanti. 
dhamma@sn35.244@3@sn35.244:3.4@For that person knows, ‘If I fall in that pit of glowing coals, that will result in my death or deadly pain.’ 
dhamma@sn35.247@1@sn35.247:1.3@Evañhi so, bhikkhave, puriso bhiyyoso mattāya tatonidānaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvediyetha. 
dhamma@sn35.247@3@sn35.247:1.3@And that would cause that person to experience even more pain and distress. 
dhamma@sn35.248@1@sn35.248:8.3@Dukkhadhammā kiṁsukā vīṇā, 
dhamma@sn35.248@3@sn35.248:8.3@
dhamma@sn36.1@1@sn36.1:1.3@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@sn36.1@3@sn36.1:1.3@Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.2@1@sn36.2:1.3@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@sn36.2@3@sn36.2:1.3@Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.2@1@sn36.2:2.1@Sukhaṁ vā yadi vā dukkhaṁ, 
dhamma@sn36.2@3@sn36.2:2.1@Whatever is felt 
dhamma@sn36.2@1@sn36.2:2.2@adukkhamasukhaṁ saha; 
dhamma@sn36.2@3@sn36.2:2.2@internally and externally—
dhamma@sn36.2@1@sn36.2:3.1@Etaṁ dukkhanti ñatvāna, 
dhamma@sn36.2@3@sn36.2:3.1@having known this as suffering, 
dhamma@sn36.3@1@sn36.3:1.3@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@sn36.3@3@sn36.3:1.3@Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.3@1@sn36.3:1.4@Sukhāya, bhikkhave, vedanāya rāgānusayo pahātabbo, dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo pahātabbo, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo pahātabbo. 
dhamma@sn36.3@3@sn36.3:1.4@The underlying tendency to greed should be given up when it comes to pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency to repulsion should be given up when it comes to painful feeling. The underlying tendency to ignorance should be given up when it comes to neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.3@1@sn36.3:1.5@Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno sukhāya vedanāya rāgānusayo pahīno hoti, dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo pahīno hoti, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo pahīno hoti, ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu niranusayo sammaddaso acchecchi taṇhaṁ, vivattayi saṁyojanaṁ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā’ti. 
dhamma@sn36.3@3@sn36.3:1.5@When a mendicant has given up these underlying tendencies, they’re called a mendicant without underlying tendencies, who sees rightly, has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering. 
dhamma@sn36.3@1@sn36.3:3.1@Dukkhaṁ vedayamānassa, 
dhamma@sn36.3@3@sn36.3:3.1@When you feel pain 
dhamma@sn36.3@1@sn36.3:4.1@Adukkhamasukhaṁ santaṁ, 
dhamma@sn36.3@3@sn36.3:4.1@As for that peaceful, neutral feeling: 
dhamma@sn36.3@1@sn36.3:4.4@neva dukkhā pamuccati. 
dhamma@sn36.3@3@sn36.3:4.4@you’re still not released from suffering. 
dhamma@sn36.4@1@sn36.4:1.5@Sārīrikānaṁ kho etaṁ, bhikkhave, dukkhānaṁ vedanānaṁ adhivacanaṁ yadidaṁ ‘pātālo’ti. 
dhamma@sn36.4@3@sn36.4:1.5@‘Hellish abyss’ is a term for painful physical feelings. 
dhamma@sn36.4@1@sn36.4:1.6@Assutavā, bhikkhave, puthujjano sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@sn36.4@3@sn36.4:1.6@When an unlearned ordinary person experiences painful physical feelings they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. 
dhamma@sn36.4@1@sn36.4:1.8@Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno neva socati, na kilamati, na paridevati, na urattāḷiṁ kandati, na sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@sn36.4@3@sn36.4:1.8@When a learned noble disciple experiences painful physical feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. 
dhamma@sn36.5@1@sn36.5:1.3@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@sn36.5@3@sn36.5:1.3@Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.5@1@sn36.5:1.4@Sukhā, bhikkhave, vedanā dukkhato daṭṭhabbā, dukkhā vedanā sallato daṭṭhabbā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā aniccato daṭṭhabbā. 
dhamma@sn36.5@3@sn36.5:1.4@Pleasant feeling should be seen as suffering. Painful feeling should be seen as a dart. Neutral feeling should be seen as impermanent. 
dhamma@sn36.5@1@sn36.5:1.5@Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno sukhā vedanā dukkhato diṭṭhā hoti, dukkhā vedanā sallato diṭṭhā hoti, adukkhamasukhā vedanā aniccato diṭṭhā hoti—
dhamma@sn36.5@3@sn36.5:1.5@When a mendicant has seen these three feelings in this way, 
dhamma@sn36.5@1@sn36.5:1.6@ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu sammaddaso acchecchi taṇhaṁ, vivattayi saṁyojanaṁ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā’ti. 
dhamma@sn36.5@3@sn36.5:1.6@they’re called a mendicant who sees rightly, has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering. 
dhamma@sn36.5@1@sn36.5:2.1@Yo sukhaṁ dukkhato adda, 
dhamma@sn36.5@3@sn36.5:2.1@A mendicant who sees pleasure as pain, 
dhamma@sn36.5@1@sn36.5:2.2@dukkhamaddakkhi sallato; 
dhamma@sn36.5@3@sn36.5:2.2@and suffering as a dart, 
dhamma@sn36.5@1@sn36.5:2.3@Adukkhamasukhaṁ santaṁ, 
dhamma@sn36.5@3@sn36.5:2.3@and that peaceful, neutral feeling 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.1@“Assutavā, bhikkhave, puthujjano sukhampi vedanaṁ vedayati, dukkhampi vedanaṁ vedayati, adukkhamasukhampi vedanaṁ vedayati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.1@“Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person feels pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.2@Sutavā, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sukhampi vedanaṁ vedayati, dukkhampi vedanaṁ vedayati, adukkhamasukhampi vedanaṁ vedayati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.2@A learned noble disciple also feels pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.5@assutavā, bhikkhave, puthujjano dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.5@“When an unlearned ordinary person experiences painful physical feelings they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.11@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.11@In the same way, when an unlearned ordinary person experiences painful physical feelings they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.14@Tassāyeva kho pana dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno paṭighavā hoti. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.14@When they’re touched by painful feeling, they resist it. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.15@Tamenaṁ dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighavantaṁ, yo dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo, so anuseti. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.15@The underlying tendency for repulsion towards painful feeling underlies that. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.16@So dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno kāmasukhaṁ abhinandati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.16@When touched by painful feeling they look forward to enjoying sensual pleasures. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.18@Na hi so, bhikkhave, pajānāti assutavā puthujjano aññatra kāmasukhā dukkhāya vedanāya nissaraṇaṁ, 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.18@Because an unlearned ordinary person doesn’t understand any escape from painful feeling apart from sensual pleasures. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.21@Tassa tāsaṁ vedanānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ appajānato, yo adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo, so anuseti. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.21@The underlying tendency to ignorance about neutral feeling underlies that. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.23@Dukkhañce vedanaṁ vedayati, saññutto naṁ vedayati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.23@If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it attached. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.24@Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṁ vedayati, saññutto naṁ vedayati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.24@If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it attached. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:1.25@Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘assutavā puthujjano saññutto jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, saññutto dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:1.25@They’re called an unlearned ordinary person who is attached to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress; who is attached to suffering, I say. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:2.1@Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati, na kilamati, na paridevati, na urattāḷiṁ kandati, na sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:2.1@When a learned noble disciple experiences painful physical feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:3.4@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati, na kilamati, na paridevati, na urattāḷiṁ kandati, na sammohaṁ āpajjati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:3.4@In the same way, when a learned noble disciple experiences painful physical feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:3.7@Tassāyeva kho pana dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno paṭighavā na hoti. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:3.7@When they’re touched by painful feeling, they don’t resist it. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:3.8@Tamenaṁ dukkhāya vedanāya appaṭighavantaṁ, yo dukkhāya vedanāya paṭighānusayo, so nānuseti. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:3.8@There’s no underlying tendency for repulsion towards painful feeling underlying that. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:3.9@So dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno kāmasukhaṁ nābhinandati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:3.9@When touched by painful feeling they don’t look forward to enjoying sensual pleasures. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:3.11@Pajānāti hi so, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako aññatra kāmasukhā dukkhāya vedanāya nissaraṇaṁ. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:3.11@Because a learned noble disciple understands an escape from painful feeling apart from sensual pleasures. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:3.14@Tassa tāsaṁ vedanānaṁ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ pajānato, yo adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya avijjānusayo, so nānuseti. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:3.14@There’s no underlying tendency to ignorance about neutral feeling underlying that. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:3.16@Dukkhañce vedanaṁ vedayati, visaññutto naṁ vedayati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:3.16@If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:3.17@Adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṁ vedayati, visaññutto naṁ vedayati. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:3.17@If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:3.18@Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘sutavā ariyasāvako visaññutto jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, visaññutto dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi. 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:3.18@They’re called a learned noble disciple who is detached from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress; who is detached from suffering, I say. 
dhamma@sn36.6@1@sn36.6:4.2@Sukhampi dukkhampi bahussutopi; 
dhamma@sn36.6@3@sn36.6:4.2@by feelings of pleasure and pain. 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:6.1@Tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno evaṁ satassa sampajānassa appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:6.1@While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if painful feelings arise, they understand: 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:6.3@‘uppannā kho myāyaṁ dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:6.3@‘A painful feeling has arisen in me. 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:6.8@Aniccaṁ kho pana saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ kāyaṁ paṭicca uppannā dukkhā vedanā kuto niccā bhavissatī’ti. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:6.8@So how could a painful feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’ 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:6.9@So kāye ca dukkhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassī viharati, vayānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:6.9@They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and painful feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:6.10@Tassa kāye ca dukkhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassino viharato …pe… paṭinissaggānupassino viharato, yo kāye ca dukkhāya ca vedanāya paṭighānusayo, so pahīyati. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:6.10@As they do so, they give up the underlying tendency for repulsion towards the body and painful feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:7.1@Tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno evaṁ satassa sampajānassa appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā, so evaṁ pajānāti: 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:7.1@While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if neutral feelings arise, they understand: 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:7.2@‘uppannā kho myāyaṁ adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:7.2@‘A neutral feeling has arisen in me. 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:7.7@Aniccaṁ kho pana saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ kāyaṁ paṭicca uppannā adukkhamasukhā vedanā kuto niccā bhavissatī’ti. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:7.7@So how could a neutral feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on a body that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’ 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:7.8@So kāye ca adukkhamasukhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassī viharati, vayānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:7.8@They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in the body and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:7.9@Tassa kāye ca adukkhamasukhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassino viharato …pe… paṭinissaggānupassino viharato, yo kāye ca adukkhamasukhāya ca vedanāya avijjānusayo, so pahīyati. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:7.9@As they do so, they give up the underlying tendency for ignorance towards the body and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:8.2@dukkhañce vedanaṁ vedayati …pe… 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:8.2@If they feel a painful feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it. 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:8.3@adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṁ vedayati, sā aniccāti pajānāti, anajjhositāti pajānāti, anabhinanditāti pajānāti. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:8.3@If they feel a neutral feeling, they understand that it’s impermanent, that they’re not attached to it, and that they don’t take pleasure in it. 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:8.5@dukkhañce vedanaṁ vedayati, visaññutto naṁ vedayati; 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:8.5@If they feel a painful feeling, they feel it detached. 
dhamma@sn36.7@1@sn36.7:8.6@adukkhamasukhañce vedanaṁ vedayati, visaññutto naṁ vedayati. 
dhamma@sn36.7@3@sn36.7:8.6@If they feel a neutral feeling, they feel it detached. 
dhamma@sn36.8@1@sn36.8:6.2@viharato uppajjati dukkhā vedanā …pe… 
dhamma@sn36.8@3@sn36.8:6.2@
dhamma@sn36.8@1@sn36.8:6.3@uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@sn36.8@3@sn36.8:6.3@if neutral feelings arise, they understand: 
dhamma@sn36.8@1@sn36.8:6.5@‘uppannā kho myāyaṁ adukkhamasukhā vedanā; 
dhamma@sn36.8@3@sn36.8:6.5@‘A neutral feeling has arisen in me. 
dhamma@sn36.9@1@sn36.9:1.3@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@sn36.9@3@sn36.9:1.3@Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.10@1@sn36.10:1.3@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@sn36.10@3@sn36.10:1.3@Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.10@1@sn36.10:1.6@Dukkhavedaniyaṁ, bhikkhave, phassaṁ paṭicca uppajjati dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@sn36.10@3@sn36.10:1.6@Painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful. 
dhamma@sn36.10@1@sn36.10:1.7@Tasseva dukkhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā, yaṁ tajjaṁ vedayitaṁ dukkhavedaniyaṁ phassaṁ paṭicca uppannā dukkhā vedanā, sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammati. 
dhamma@sn36.10@3@sn36.10:1.7@With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, the corresponding painful feeling ceases and stops. 
dhamma@sn36.10@1@sn36.10:1.8@Adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṁ, bhikkhave, phassaṁ paṭicca uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā. 
dhamma@sn36.10@3@sn36.10:1.8@Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral. 
dhamma@sn36.10@1@sn36.10:1.9@Tasseva adukkhamasukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā, yaṁ tajjaṁ vedayitaṁ adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṁ phassaṁ paṭicca uppannā adukkhamasukhā vedanā, sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammati. 
dhamma@sn36.10@3@sn36.10:1.9@With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops. 
dhamma@sn36.11@1@sn36.11:1.4@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@sn36.11@3@sn36.11:1.4@Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.11@1@sn36.11:1.7@‘yaṁ kiñci vedayitaṁ taṁ dukkhasmin’ti. 
dhamma@sn36.11@3@sn36.11:1.7@‘Suffering includes whatever is felt.’ 
dhamma@sn36.11@1@sn36.11:1.9@‘yaṁ kiñci vedayitaṁ taṁ dukkhasmin’”ti? 
dhamma@sn36.11@3@sn36.11:1.9@
dhamma@sn36.11@1@sn36.11:2.3@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@sn36.11@3@sn36.11:2.3@Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn36.11@1@sn36.11:2.6@‘yaṁ kiñci vedayitaṁ, taṁ dukkhasmin’ti. 
dhamma@sn36.11@3@sn36.11:2.6@‘Suffering includes whatever is felt.’ 
dhamma@sn36.11@1@sn36.11:2.8@‘yaṁ kiñci vedayitaṁ taṁ dukkhasmin’ti. 
dhamma@sn36.11@3@sn36.11:2.8@
dhamma@sn36.11@1@sn36.11:2.14@‘yaṁ kiñci vedayitaṁ taṁ dukkhasmin’ti. 
dhamma@sn36.11@3@sn36.11:2.14@
dhamma@sn36.12@1@sn36.12:1.3@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, imasmiṁ kāyasmiṁ vividhā vedanā uppajjanti, sukhāpi vedanā uppajjati, dukkhāpi vedanā uppajjati, adukkhamasukhāpi vedanā uppajjatīti. 
dhamma@sn36.12@3@sn36.12:1.3@In the same way, various feelings arise in this body: pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings. 
dhamma@sn36.12@1@sn36.12:4.3@Sukhadukkhasamuppatti, 
dhamma@sn36.12@3@sn36.12:4.3@pleasant and painful, 
dhamma@sn36.12@1@sn36.12:4.4@adukkhamasukhā ca yā. 
dhamma@sn36.12@3@sn36.12:4.4@and those that are neutral. 
dhamma@sn36.13@1@sn36.13:1.3@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, imasmiṁ kāyasmiṁ vividhā vedanā uppajjanti, sukhāpi vedanā uppajjati, dukkhāpi vedanā uppajjati, adukkhamasukhāpi vedanā uppajjatī”ti. 
dhamma@sn36.13@3@sn36.13:1.3@In the same way, various feelings arise in this body: pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.”
dhamma@sn36.14@1@sn36.14:1.2@Evameva kho, bhikkhave, imasmiṁ kāyasmiṁ vividhā vedanā uppajjanti. Sukhāpi vedanā uppajjati, dukkhāpi vedanā uppajjati, adukkhamasukhāpi vedanā uppajjati. 
dhamma@sn36.14@3@sn36.14:1.2@In the same way, various feelings arise in this body: pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings. 
dhamma@sn36.14@1@sn36.14:1.3@Sāmisāpi sukhā vedanā uppajjati, sāmisāpi dukkhā vedanā uppajjati, sāmisāpi adukkhamasukhā vedanā uppajjati. 
dhamma@sn36.14@3@sn36.14:1.3@Also pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings of the flesh arise. 
dhamma@sn36.14@1@sn36.14:1.4@Nirāmisāpi sukhā vedanā uppajjati, nirāmisāpi dukkhā vedanā uppajjati, nirāmisāpi adukkhamasukhā vedanā uppajjatī”ti. 
dhamma@sn36.14@3@sn36.14:1.4@Also pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings not of the flesh arise.”
dhamma@sn36.15@1@sn36.15:1.5@sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@sn36.15@3@sn36.15:1.5@pleasant, painful, and neutral. 
dhamma@sn36.15@1@sn36.15:1.12@Yaṁ vedanā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṁ vedanāya ādīnavo. 
dhamma@sn36.15@3@sn36.15:1.12@That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

dhamma@sn36.16@3@sn36.16:1.9@pleasant, painful, and neutral.

dhamma@sn36.18@3@sn36.18:1.7@pleasant, painful, and neutral. 
dhamma@sn36.19@1@sn36.19:1.4@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@sn36.19@3@sn36.19:1.4@pleasant, painful, and neutral. 
dhamma@sn36.19@1@sn36.19:1.9@sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā. 
dhamma@sn36.19@3@sn36.19:1.9@pleasant and painful. 
dhamma@sn36.19@1@sn36.19:1.10@Yāyaṁ, bhante, adukkhamasukhā vedanā, santasmiṁ esā paṇīte sukhe vuttā bhagavatā”ti. 
dhamma@sn36.19@3@sn36.19:1.10@The Buddha said that neutral feeling is included as a peaceful and subtle kind of pleasure.”

dhamma@sn36.19@1@sn36.19:3.4@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

dhamma@sn36.19@1@sn36.19:3.9@sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā.

dhamma@sn36.19@1@sn36.19:3.10@Yāyaṁ, bhante, adukkhamasukhā vedanā, santasmiṁ esā paṇīte sukhe vuttā bhagavatā”ti. 
dhamma@sn36.19@3@sn36.19:3.10@
dhamma@sn36.19@1@sn36.19:10.2@Idhānanda, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@sn36.19@3@sn36.19:10.2@It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@sn36.21@1@sn36.21:1.5@‘yaṁ kiñcāyaṁ purisapuggalo paṭisaṁvedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā sabbaṁ taṁ pubbekatahetū’ti. 
dhamma@sn36.21@3@sn36.21:1.5@‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.’ 
dhamma@sn36.21@1@sn36.21:2.5@‘yaṁ kiñcāyaṁ purisapuggalo paṭisaṁvedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā sabbaṁ taṁ pubbekatahetū’ti.

dhamma@sn36.30@3@sn36.30:1.3@Pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings. 
dhamma@sn36.31@1@sn36.31:8.2@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā, dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. 
dhamma@sn36.31@3@sn36.31:8.2@It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@sn37.3@1@sn37.3:0.3@Āveṇikadukkhasutta 
dhamma@sn37.3@3@sn37.3:0.3@Particular Suffering 
dhamma@sn37.3@4@sn37.3:0.3@Āveṇikadukkhasutta → āveṇikā (pts1ed)
dhamma@sn37.3@1@sn37.3:1.1@“Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, mātugāmassa āveṇikāni dukkhāni, yāni mātugāmo paccanubhoti, aññatreva purisehi. 
dhamma@sn37.3@3@sn37.3:1.1@“Mendicants, there are these five kinds of suffering that particularly apply to females. They’re undergone by females and not by men. 
dhamma@sn37.3@1@sn37.3:1.4@Idaṁ, bhikkhave, mātugāmassa paṭhamaṁ āveṇikaṁ dukkhaṁ, yaṁ mātugāmo paccanubhoti, aññatreva purisehi. 
dhamma@sn37.3@3@sn37.3:1.4@This is the first kind of suffering that particularly applies to females. 
dhamma@sn37.3@1@sn37.3:1.6@Idaṁ, bhikkhave, mātugāmassa dutiyaṁ āveṇikaṁ dukkhaṁ, yaṁ mātugāmo paccanubhoti, aññatreva purisehi. 
dhamma@sn37.3@3@sn37.3:1.6@This is the second kind of suffering that particularly applies to females. 
dhamma@sn37.3@1@sn37.3:1.8@Idaṁ, bhikkhave, mātugāmassa tatiyaṁ āveṇikaṁ dukkhaṁ, yaṁ mātugāmo paccanubhoti, aññatreva purisehi. 
dhamma@sn37.3@3@sn37.3:1.8@This is the third kind of suffering that particularly applies to females. 
dhamma@sn37.3@1@sn37.3:1.10@Idaṁ, bhikkhave, mātugāmassa catutthaṁ āveṇikaṁ dukkhaṁ, yaṁ mātugāmo paccanubhoti, aññatreva purisehi. 
dhamma@sn37.3@3@sn37.3:1.10@This is the fourth kind of suffering that particularly applies to females. 
dhamma@sn37.3@1@sn37.3:1.12@Idaṁ kho, bhikkhave, mātugāmassa pañcamaṁ āveṇikaṁ dukkhaṁ, yaṁ mātugāmo paccanubhoti, aññatreva purisehi. 
dhamma@sn37.3@3@sn37.3:1.12@This is the fifth kind of suffering that particularly applies to females. 
dhamma@sn37.3@1@sn37.3:1.13@Imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañca mātugāmassa āveṇikāni dukkhāni, yāni mātugāmo paccanubhoti, aññatreva purisehī”ti. 
dhamma@sn37.3@3@sn37.3:1.13@These are the five kinds of suffering that particularly apply to females. They’re undergone by females and not by men.”
dhamma@sn38.4@1@sn38.4:1.2@“Dukkhassa kho, āvuso, pariññatthaṁ bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ vussatī”ti. 
dhamma@sn38.4@3@sn38.4:1.2@“The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand suffering.” 
dhamma@sn38.4@1@sn38.4:1.3@“Atthi panāvuso, maggo atthi paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyā”ti? 
dhamma@sn38.4@3@sn38.4:1.3@“But, reverend, is there a path and a practice for completely understanding this suffering?” 
dhamma@sn38.4@1@sn38.4:1.4@“Atthi kho, āvuso, maggo atthi paṭipadā, etassa dukkhassa pariññāyā”ti? 
dhamma@sn38.4@3@sn38.4:1.4@“There is.” … 
dhamma@sn38.4@1@sn38.4:1.5@“Katamo panāvuso, maggo katamā paṭipadā, etassa dukkhassa pariññāyā”ti? 
dhamma@sn38.4@3@sn38.4:1.5@
dhamma@sn38.4@1@sn38.4:2.1@“Ayameva kho, āvuso, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, etassa dukkhassa pariññāya, seyyathidaṁ—
dhamma@sn38.4@3@sn38.4:2.1@
dhamma@sn38.4@1@sn38.4:2.3@Ayaṁ kho, āvuso, maggo ayaṁ paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyā”ti. 
dhamma@sn38.4@3@sn38.4:2.3@
dhamma@sn38.4@1@sn38.4:2.4@“Bhaddako, āvuso, maggo bhaddikā paṭipadā, etassa dukkhassa pariññāya. 
dhamma@sn38.4@3@sn38.4:2.4@
dhamma@sn38.7@1@sn38.7:1.5@Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—
dhamma@sn38.7@3@sn38.7:1.5@Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn38.9@1@sn38.9:1.3@“Yaṁ kho, āvuso, dukkhe aññāṇaṁ, dukkhasamudaye aññāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhe aññāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya aññāṇaṁ—
dhamma@sn38.9@3@sn38.9:1.3@“Not knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. 
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:0.3@Dukkhapañhāsutta 
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:0.3@A Question About Suffering 
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.1@“‘Dukkhaṁ, dukkhan’ti, āvuso sāriputta, vuccati. 
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.1@“Reverend Sāriputta, they speak of this thing called ‘suffering’. 
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.2@Katamaṁ nu kho, āvuso, dukkhan”ti? 
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.2@What is suffering?” 
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.3@“Tisso imā, āvuso, dukkhatā. 
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.3@“Reverend, there are these three forms of suffering. 
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.4@Dukkhadukkhatā, saṅkhāradukkhatā, vipariṇāmadukkhatā—
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.4@The suffering inherent in painful feeling; the suffering inherent in conditions; and the suffering inherent in perishing. 
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.5@imā kho, āvuso, tisso dukkhatā”ti. 
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.5@These are the three forms of suffering.” 
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.6@“Atthi panāvuso maggo atthi paṭipadā, etāsaṁ dukkhatānaṁ pariññāyā”ti? 
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.6@“But, reverend, is there a path and a practice for completely understanding these forms of suffering?” 
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.7@“Atthi kho, āvuso, maggo atthi paṭipadā, etāsaṁ dukkhatānaṁ pariññāyā”ti. 
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.7@“There is.” … 
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.8@“Katamo panāvuso, maggo katamā paṭipadā, etāsaṁ dukkhatānaṁ pariññāyā”ti? 
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.8@
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.9@“Ayameva kho, āvuso, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, etāsaṁ dukkhatānaṁ pariññāya, seyyathidaṁ—
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.9@
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.11@Ayaṁ kho, āvuso, maggo ayaṁ paṭipadā, etāsaṁ dukkhatānaṁ pariññāyā”ti. 
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.11@
dhamma@sn38.14@1@sn38.14:1.12@“Bhaddako, āvuso, maggo bhaddikā paṭipadā, etāsaṁ dukkhatānaṁ pariññāya. 
dhamma@sn38.14@3@sn38.14:1.12@
dhamma@sn38.16@1@sn38.16:2.6@bhavo dukkhañca sakkāyo. 
dhamma@sn38.16@3@sn38.16:2.6@']

['‘idha bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati. ', '‘It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. ', 'So khvāhaṁ, āvuso, sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāmi. ', 'And so … I was entering and remaining in the fourth absorption. ', 'So khvāhaṁ, āvuso, aparena samayena sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ. ', 'And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the fourth absorption. ']
['Tena kho pana samayena citto gahapati ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. ', 'Now at that time the householder Citta was sick, suffering, gravely ill. ']

['“sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desetū”ti. ', '“Please, sir, teach me the origin and cessation of suffering.” ', '“Ahañce te, gāmaṇi, atītamaddhānaṁ ārabbha dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca deseyyaṁ: ', '“Chief, if I were to teach you about the origin and ending of suffering in the past, saying ', 'Ahañce te, gāmaṇi, anāgatamaddhānaṁ ārabbha dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca deseyyaṁ: ', 'If I were to teach you about the origin and ending of suffering in the future, saying ', 'Api cāhaṁ, gāmaṇi, idheva nisinno ettheva te nisinnassa dukkhassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desessāmi. ', 'Rather, chief, I will teach you about the origin and ending of suffering as I am sitting right here and you are sitting right there. ', 'atthi te uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti? ', 'Are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?” ', '“Atthi me, bhante, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ me vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti. ', '“There are, sir.” ', '“Atthi pana te, gāmaṇi, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti? ', '“But are there any people here in Uruvelakappa who, if they were executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, it would not cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?” ', '“Atthi me, bhante, uruvelakappe manussā yesaṁ me vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti. ', '“There are, sir.” ', '“Ko nu kho, gāmaṇi, hetu, ko paccayo yena te ekaccānaṁ uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti? ', '“What’s the cause, chief, what’s the reason why, if this was to happen to some people it could cause you sorrow, while if it happens to others it does not?” ', '“Yesaṁ me, bhante, uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā, atthi me tesu chandarāgo. ', '“The people regarding whom this would give rise to sorrow are those I desire and love. ', 'Yesaṁ pana, bhante, uruvelakappiyānaṁ manussānaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā nuppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā, natthi me tesu chandarāgo”ti. ', 'The people regarding whom this would not give rise to sorrow are those I don’t desire and love.” ', '‘yaṁ kho kiñci atītamaddhānaṁ dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajji sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ. ', '‘All the suffering that arose in the past was rooted and sourced in desire. ', 'Chando hi mūlaṁ dukkhassa. ', 'For desire is the root of suffering. ', 'Yampi hi kiñci anāgatamaddhānaṁ dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjissati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ. ', 'All the suffering that will arise in the future will be rooted and sourced in desire. ', 'Chando hi mūlaṁ dukkhassā’”ti. ', 'For desire is the root of suffering.’” ', '‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ. ', '‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire. ', 'Chando hi mūlaṁ dukkhassā’ti. ', 'For desire is the root of suffering.’ ', 'ciravāsissa kumārassa vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti? ', 'If Ciravāsi was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?” ', '“Ciravāsissa me, bhante, kumārassa vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṁ, kiṁ pana me nuppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti. ', '“How could it not, sir?” ', '‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ. ', '‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire. ', 'Chando hi mūlaṁ dukkhassā’ti. ', 'For desire is the root of suffering.’ ', 'ciravāsimātuyā te vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti? ', 'If Ciravāsi’s mother was executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned, would it cause you sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?” ', '“Ciravāsimātuyā me, bhante, vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṁ, kiṁ pana me nuppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti. ', '“How could it not, sir?” ', '‘yaṁ kiñci dukkhaṁ uppajjamānaṁ uppajjati, sabbaṁ taṁ chandamūlakaṁ chandanidānaṁ. ', '‘All the suffering that arises is rooted and sourced in desire. ', 'Chando hi mūlaṁ dukkhassā’”ti. ', 'For desire is the root of suffering.’”']

['yo cāyaṁ kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogo hīno gammo pothujjaniko anariyo anatthasaṁhito, yo cāyaṁ attakilamathānuyogo dukkho anariyo anatthasaṁhito. ', 'Indulgence in sensual pleasures, which is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And indulgence in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless. ']

['‘yo koci pāṇamatipāteti, sabbo so diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedayati. ', '‘Everyone who kills living creatures experiences pain and sadness in the present life. ', 'Yo koci adinnaṁ ādiyati, sabbo so diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedayati. ', 'Everyone who steals … ', 'Yo koci kāmesu micchā carati, sabbo so diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedayati. ', 'commits sexual misconduct … ', 'Yo koci musā bhaṇati, sabbo so diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedayatī’ti. ', 'lies experiences pain and sadness in the present life.’ ', '‘yo koci pāṇamatipāteti, sabbo so diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedayatī’ti, saccaṁ vā te āhaṁsu musā vā”ti? ', 'everyone who kills living creatures experiences pain and sadness in the present life: are they right or wrong?” ', '‘yo koci adinnaṁ ādiyati, sabbo so diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedayatī’ti, saccaṁ vā te āhaṁsu musā vāti …pe… ', 'everyone who steals experiences pain and sadness in the present life: are they right or wrong? … ', '‘yo koci kāmesu micchā carati, sabbo so diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedayatī’ti, saccaṁ vā te āhaṁsu musā vāti …pe… ', 'everyone who commits sexual misconduct experiences pain and sadness in the present life: are they right or wrong? … ', '‘yo koci musā bhaṇati, sabbo so diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedayatī’ti, saccaṁ vā te āhaṁsu musā vā”ti? ', 'everyone who lies experiences pain and sadness in the present life: are they right or wrong?” ']

['“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti? ', '“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?” ', '“Dukkhaṁ, bhante”. ', '“Suffering, sir.” ', '“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ: ', '“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: ', '“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti? ', '“But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?” ', '“Dukkhaṁ, bhante”. ', '“Suffering, sir.” ', '“Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ: ', '“But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus: ', 'Pubbe cāhaṁ, anurādha, etarahi ca dukkhañceva paññāpemi dukkhassa ca nirodhan”ti. ', 'In the past, as today, what I describe is suffering and the cessation of suffering.”']

['‘acchecchi taṇhaṁ, vivattayi saṁyojanaṁ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā’ti. ', 'cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit have made an end of suffering.’ ']

['Dukkhatāsutta ', 'Forms of Suffering ', '“Tisso imā, bhikkhave, dukkhatā. ', '“Mendicants, there are these three forms of suffering. ', 'Dukkhadukkhatā, saṅkhāradukkhatā, vipariṇāmadukkhatā—', 'The suffering inherent in painful feeling; the suffering inherent in conditions; and the suffering inherent in perishing. ', 'imā kho, bhikkhave, tisso dukkhatā. ', 'These are the three forms of suffering. ', 'Imāsaṁ kho, bhikkhave, tissannaṁ dukkhatānaṁ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya …pe… ayaṁ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti. ', 'The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these three forms of suffering.”']
['Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—', 'Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. ']
['bhavo ca dukkhatā khilā; ', nan]

['Mamañhi, ānanda, kalyāṇamittaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti; jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti; maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti; sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti. ', 'For, by relying on me as a good friend, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things. ']
['Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—', 'Pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling. ']

['Mamañhi, sāriputta, kalyāṇamittaṁ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti; jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti; maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti; sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti. ', 'For, by relying on me as a good friend, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things. ']

['“Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo viraddho, viraddho tesaṁ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī. ', '“Mendicants, whoever has missed out on the noble eightfold path has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering. ', 'Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo āraddho, āraddho tesaṁ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī. ', 'Whoever has undertaken the noble eightfold path has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering. ', 'Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, ayaṁ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo viraddho, viraddho tesaṁ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī. ', 'Whoever has missed out on the noble eightfold path has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering. ', 'Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, ayaṁ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo āraddho, āraddho tesaṁ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī”ti. ', 'Whoever has undertaken the noble eightfold path has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.”']

['‘dukkhassa kho, āvuso, pariññatthaṁ bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ vussatī’ti. ', '‘The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand suffering.’ ', 'Dukkhassa hi pariññatthaṁ mayi brahmacariyaṁ vussati. ', 'For the purpose of leading the spiritual life under me is to completely understand suffering. ', '‘atthi panāvuso, maggo, atthi paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyā’ti, evaṁ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ evaṁ byākareyyātha: ', '‘Is there a path and a practice for completely understanding that suffering?’ You should answer them like this: ', '‘atthi kho, āvuso, maggo, atthi paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyā’ti. ', '‘There is.’ ', 'Katamo ca, bhikkhave, maggo, katamā paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyāti? ', 'And what is that path? ', 'Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, maggo, ayaṁ paṭipadā etassa dukkhassa pariññāyāti. ', 'This is the path and the practice for completely understanding suffering. ']

['Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṁ—', 'Knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering. ', 'Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati—', 'Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. ']

['Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahākassapo pippaliguhāyaṁ viharati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. ', 'Now at that time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying in the Pipphali cave, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill. ', '“Kacci te, kassapa, khamanīyaṁ kacci yāpanīyaṁ? Kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti? ', '“I hope you’re keeping well, Kassapa; I hope you’re getting by. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.” ', '“Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṁ, na yāpanīyaṁ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti. ', '“Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.” ']

['Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahāmoggallāno gijjhakūṭe pabbate viharati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. ', 'Now at that time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was staying on the Vulture’s Peak mountain, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill. ', '“Kacci te, moggallāna, khamanīyaṁ kacci yāpanīyaṁ? Kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti? ', '“I hope you’re keeping well, Moggallāna; I hope you’re getting by. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.” ', '“Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṁ, na yāpanīyaṁ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṁ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti. ', '“Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.” ']
['Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno. ', 'Now at that time he was sick, suffering, gravely ill. ']

['“Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, satta bojjhaṅgā viraddhā, viraddho tesaṁ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī. ', '“Mendicants, whoever has missed out on the seven awakening factors has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering. ', 'Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, satta bojjhaṅgā āraddhā, āraddho tesaṁ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī. ', 'Whoever has undertaken the seven awakening factors has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering. ', 'yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, ime satta bojjhaṅgā viraddhā, viraddho tesaṁ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī. ', 'Whoever has missed out on these seven awakening factors has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering. ', 'Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, ime satta bojjhaṅgā āraddhā, āraddho tesaṁ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī”ti. ', 'Whoever has undertaken these seven awakening factors has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.”']

['“Sattime, bhikkhave, bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ariyā niyyānikā nīyanti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya. ', '“Mendicants, when these seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated they are noble and emancipating, and bring one who practices them to the complete ending of suffering. ', 'ime kho, bhikkhave, satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ariyā niyyānikā nīyanti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti. ', 'When these seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated they are noble and emancipating, and bring one who practices them to the complete ending of suffering.”']

['Kammassa pahānā dukkhaṁ pahīyati …pe… ', 'When deeds are given up, suffering is given up. … ', 'Kammassa pahānā dukkhaṁ pahīyati. ', 'When deeds are given up, suffering is given up. ', 'Iti kho, udāyi, taṇhakkhayā kammakkhayo, kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo”ti. ', 'And so, Udāyī, when craving ends, deeds end; when deeds end suffering ends.”']

['So khvāhaṁ, bhante, suññāgāragato imesaṁ pañcupādānakkhandhānaṁ ukkujjāvakujjaṁ samparivattento ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ. ', 'Then, while staying in an empty hut, I followed the churning of the five grasping aggregates. I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. ']

['Dukkhasutta ', 'Suffering in Impermanence ', 'Dukkhasutta → anicce dukkhasuttāni (bj)', '“Anicce dukkhasaññā, bhikkhave …pe…” ', '“Mendicants, when the perception of suffering in impermanence is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”']

['Anattasutta ', 'Not-Self in Suffering ', 'Anattasutta → dukkhe anattasuttāni (bj)', '“Dukkhe anattasaññā, bhikkhave …pe…” ', '“Mendicants, when the perception of not-self in suffering is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”']

dhamma@sn48.35@3@sn48.35:2.2@There are ascetics and brahmins who do understand the faculty of pain … 
dhamma@sn48.36@1@sn48.36:1.3@Sukhindriyaṁ, dukkhindriyaṁ, somanassindriyaṁ, domanassindriyaṁ, upekkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.36@3@sn48.36:1.3@The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity. 
dhamma@sn48.36@1@sn48.36:3.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhindriyaṁ? 
dhamma@sn48.36@3@sn48.36:3.1@And what is the faculty of pain? 
dhamma@sn48.36@1@sn48.36:3.2@Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṁ dukkhaṁ, kāyikaṁ asātaṁ, kāyasamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ—
dhamma@sn48.36@3@sn48.36:3.2@Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact. 
dhamma@sn48.36@1@sn48.36:3.3@idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.36@3@sn48.36:3.3@This is called the faculty of pain. 
dhamma@sn48.36@1@sn48.36:5.2@Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ, cetasikaṁ asātaṁ, manosamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ—
dhamma@sn48.36@3@sn48.36:5.2@Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact. 
dhamma@sn48.37@1@sn48.37:1.3@Sukhindriyaṁ, dukkhindriyaṁ, somanassindriyaṁ, domanassindriyaṁ, upekkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.37@3@sn48.37:1.3@The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity. 
dhamma@sn48.37@1@sn48.37:3.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhindriyaṁ? 
dhamma@sn48.37@3@sn48.37:3.1@And what is the faculty of pain? 
dhamma@sn48.37@1@sn48.37:3.2@Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṁ dukkhaṁ, kāyikaṁ asātaṁ, kāyasamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ—
dhamma@sn48.37@3@sn48.37:3.2@Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact. 
dhamma@sn48.37@1@sn48.37:3.3@idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.37@3@sn48.37:3.3@This is called the faculty of pain. 
dhamma@sn48.37@1@sn48.37:5.2@Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ, cetasikaṁ asātaṁ, manosamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ—
dhamma@sn48.37@3@sn48.37:5.2@Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact. 
dhamma@sn48.37@1@sn48.37:7.2@Tatra, bhikkhave, yañca dukkhindriyaṁ yañca domanassindriyaṁ, dukkhā sā vedanā daṭṭhabbā. 
dhamma@sn48.37@3@sn48.37:7.2@The faculties of pain and sadness should be seen as painful feeling. 
dhamma@sn48.37@1@sn48.37:7.3@Tatra, bhikkhave, yadidaṁ upekkhindriyaṁ, adukkhamasukhā sā vedanā daṭṭhabbā. 
dhamma@sn48.37@3@sn48.37:7.3@The faculty of equanimity should be seen as neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn48.38@1@sn48.38:1.3@Sukhindriyaṁ, dukkhindriyaṁ, somanassindriyaṁ, domanassindriyaṁ, upekkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.38@3@sn48.38:1.3@The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity. 
dhamma@sn48.38@1@sn48.38:3.1@Katamañca, bhikkhave, dukkhindriyaṁ? 
dhamma@sn48.38@3@sn48.38:3.1@And what is the faculty of pain? 
dhamma@sn48.38@1@sn48.38:3.2@Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, kāyikaṁ dukkhaṁ, kāyikaṁ asātaṁ, kāyasamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ—
dhamma@sn48.38@3@sn48.38:3.2@Physical pain, physical unpleasantness, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from physical contact. 
dhamma@sn48.38@1@sn48.38:3.3@idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.38@3@sn48.38:3.3@This is called the faculty of pain. 
dhamma@sn48.38@1@sn48.38:5.2@Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ, cetasikaṁ asātaṁ, manosamphassajaṁ dukkhaṁ asātaṁ vedayitaṁ—
dhamma@sn48.38@3@sn48.38:5.2@Mental pain, mental displeasure, the painful, unpleasant feeling that’s born from mind contact. 
dhamma@sn48.38@1@sn48.38:7.2@Tatra, bhikkhave, yañca dukkhindriyaṁ yañca domanassindriyaṁ, dukkhā sā vedanā daṭṭhabbā. 
dhamma@sn48.38@3@sn48.38:7.2@The faculties of pain and sadness should be seen as painful feeling. 
dhamma@sn48.38@1@sn48.38:7.3@Tatra, bhikkhave, yadidaṁ upekkhindriyaṁ, adukkhamasukhā sā vedanā daṭṭhabbā. 
dhamma@sn48.38@3@sn48.38:7.3@The faculty of equanimity should be seen as neutral feeling. 
dhamma@sn48.39@1@sn48.39:1.3@Sukhindriyaṁ, dukkhindriyaṁ, somanassindriyaṁ, domanassindriyaṁ, upekkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.39@3@sn48.39:1.3@The faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity. 
dhamma@sn48.39@1@sn48.39:2.1@Dukkhavedaniyaṁ, bhikkhave, phassaṁ paṭicca uppajjati dukkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.39@3@sn48.39:2.1@The faculty of pain arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful. 
dhamma@sn48.39@1@sn48.39:2.2@So dukkhitova samāno ‘dukkhitosmī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@sn48.39@3@sn48.39:2.2@When in a state of pain, you understand: ‘I’m in a state of pain.’ 
dhamma@sn48.39@1@sn48.39:2.3@Tasseva dukkhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā ‘yaṁ tajjaṁ vedayitaṁ dukkhavedaniyaṁ phassaṁ paṭicca uppannaṁ dukkhindriyaṁ taṁ nirujjhati, taṁ vūpasammatī’ti pajānāti. 
dhamma@sn48.39@3@sn48.39:2.3@With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, you understand that the corresponding faculty of pain ceases and stops. 
dhamma@sn48.39@1@sn48.39:7.1@Dukkhavedaniyaṁ, bhikkhave, phassaṁ paṭicca …pe… 
dhamma@sn48.39@3@sn48.39:7.1@The faculty of pain … 
dhamma@sn48.40@1@sn48.40:1.3@Dukkhindriyaṁ, domanassindriyaṁ, sukhindriyaṁ, somanassindriyaṁ, upekkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.40@3@sn48.40:1.3@The faculties of pain, sadness, pleasure, happiness, and equanimity. 
dhamma@sn48.40@1@sn48.40:1.4@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati dukkhindriyaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.40@3@sn48.40:1.4@While a mendicant is meditating—diligent, keen, and resolute—the faculty of pain arises. 
dhamma@sn48.40@1@sn48.40:1.6@‘uppannaṁ kho me idaṁ dukkhindriyaṁ, tañca kho sanimittaṁ sanidānaṁ sasaṅkhāraṁ sappaccayaṁ. 
dhamma@sn48.40@3@sn48.40:1.6@‘The faculty of pain has arisen in me. And that has a foundation, a source, a condition, and a reason. 
dhamma@sn48.40@1@sn48.40:1.7@Tañca animittaṁ anidānaṁ asaṅkhāraṁ appaccayaṁ dukkhindriyaṁ uppajjissatī’ti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati. 
dhamma@sn48.40@3@sn48.40:1.7@It’s not possible for the faculty of pain to arise without a foundation, a source, a condition, or a reason.’ 
dhamma@sn48.40@1@sn48.40:1.8@So dukkhindriyañca pajānāti, dukkhindriyasamudayañca pajānāti, dukkhindriyanirodhañca pajānāti, yattha cuppannaṁ dukkhindriyaṁ aparisesaṁ nirujjhati tañca pajānāti. 
dhamma@sn48.40@3@sn48.40:1.8@They understand the faculty of pain, its origin, its cessation, and where that faculty of pain that’s arisen ceases without anything left over. 
dhamma@sn48.40@1@sn48.40:1.9@Kattha cuppannaṁ dukkhindriyaṁ aparisesaṁ nirujjhati? 
dhamma@sn48.40@3@sn48.40:1.9@And where does that faculty of pain that’s arisen cease without anything left over? 
dhamma@sn48.40@1@sn48.40:1.11@ettha cuppannaṁ dukkhindriyaṁ aparisesaṁ nirujjhati. 
dhamma@sn48.40@3@sn48.40:1.11@That’s where the faculty of pain that’s arisen ceases without anything left over. 
dhamma@sn48.40@1@sn48.40:1.12@Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ‘bhikkhu aññāsi dukkhindriyassa nirodhaṁ, tadatthāya cittaṁ upasaṁharati’. 
dhamma@sn48.40@3@sn48.40:1.12@They’re called a mendicant who understands the cessation of the faculty of pain, and who applies their mind to that end. 
dhamma@sn48.40@1@sn48.40:4.7@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati, 
dhamma@sn48.40@3@sn48.40:4.7@It’s when, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. 
dhamma@sn48.53@1@sn48.53:3.2@Idha, bhikkhave, sekho bhikkhu ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti—
dhamma@sn48.53@3@sn48.53:3.2@It’s when a mendicant who is a trainee truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

dhamma@sn51.2@1@sn51.2:1.1@“Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, cattāro iddhipādā viraddhā, viraddho tesaṁ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī. 
dhamma@sn51.2@3@sn51.2:1.1@“Mendicants, whoever has missed out on the four bases of psychic power has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@sn51.2@1@sn51.2:1.2@Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, cattāro iddhipādā āraddhā, āraddho tesaṁ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī. 
dhamma@sn51.2@3@sn51.2:1.2@Whoever has undertaken the four bases of psychic power has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@sn51.2@1@sn51.2:1.8@Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro iddhipādā viraddhā, viraddho tesaṁ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī. 
dhamma@sn51.2@3@sn51.2:1.8@Whoever has missed out on these four bases of psychic power has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@sn51.2@1@sn51.2:1.9@Yesaṁ kesañci, bhikkhave, ime cattāro iddhipādā āraddhā, āraddho tesaṁ ariyo maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī”ti. 
dhamma@sn51.2@3@sn51.2:1.9@Whoever has undertaken these four bases of psychic power has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.”
dhamma@sn51.3@1@sn51.3:1.1@“Cattārome, bhikkhave, iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ariyā niyyānikā niyyanti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya. 
dhamma@sn51.3@3@sn51.3:1.1@“Mendicants, when these four bases of psychic power are developed and cultivated they are noble and emancipating, and bring one who practices them to the complete ending of suffering. 
dhamma@sn51.3@1@sn51.3:1.7@Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ariyā niyyānikā niyyanti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti. 
dhamma@sn51.3@3@sn51.3:1.7@When these four bases of psychic power are developed and cultivated they are noble and emancipating, and bring one who practices them to the complete ending of suffering.”
dhamma@sn51.11@1@sn51.11:8.1@Evaṁ bhāvitesu kho, bhikkhu, catūsu iddhipādesu evaṁ bahulīkatesu, anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati. 
dhamma@sn51.11@3@sn51.11:8.1@When the four bases of psychic power have been developed and cultivated in this way, they recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
